Don't listen to what they say. 


Look at their calendar.

Free hacks to stand out in your career: 




- Be the first one there.
- Do what you say you'll do.
- Prepare before meetings.
- Ask questions, then actually listen.
- Make everyone feel important.
- Follow up without being asked.

All free to do. Yet ignored by most.

The fastest way to spot a successful person: 

Watch how quickly they make decisions, respond to messages, and turn ideas into action. Speed is king.

You don't lose A-players to competition.
You lose them to frustration when they're forced to carry D-players.

Leadership isnâ€™t doing the job for your team. Itâ€™s giving them the tools to succeed with clear expectations, measurement, and feedback.
The more uncertainty you can tolerate the more success you will have.
Every great thing Iâ€™ve achieved in life started with fear and ended with confidence.

People love to say:
â€œDonâ€™t work hard, work smart.â€

Instead of trying to get rich. 
Do this. 

Try not being poor.
This is what poor people do:

1. Start many projects, finish none.
2. Think that understanding the basics and doing the basics are the same thing.
3. They assume friends will act like friends when it comes to money.
4. They make promises and break them, especially to themselves.
5. They assume anyone making money is smarter than them.
6. They are easily distracted.
7. They prioritize looking smart over acting smart.
8. They think asking for help means that they are helpless.
9. They expect things to be easy.
10. They blindly trust people they know.
11. They blame anything besides themselves for their problems.
12. They look for one thing to solve all of their problems.
13. They believe their own bullshit.
14. They get married to someone who spends more money than they make.

Brutal truth about accomplishing your dreams: 



Fear fades when you face it.
Doubt dies when you do it.
Success rings when you stop waiting.
Youâ€™re not good enough.
And neither was anyone else you look up to when they got started.

if you create money models, you systematically generate higher upfront profits, acquire customers more effectively, and consistently outspend competitors.

I hit 10K followers today.
Took me 3 damn years.
Here's everything I learned

Back in 2020, my friend Manish told me
â€œBro, LinkedIn is where you build businesses.â€

I didnâ€™t get it.
But I made an account anyway.

For 2 years I was just throwing random shit here.
NFT art, tiny wins, some cringe posts.
Nobody cared.

But it gave me confidence.
Confidence that I can hit publish without overthinking.
Confidence that I can talk my mind.

Most people donâ€™t post because theyâ€™re scared of looking stupid.
Guess what... you will look stupid.

Your first 100 posts will be trash.
But thatâ€™s the price of getting better.

Then my company died.
Elite NFT shut down.

Thatâ€™s when I said fu*k it, letâ€™s build in public.

I started posting everything.
The downfall, the broke days, the rebuild.
People actually started listening.

And thatâ€™s when it clicked.
Consistency is the real hack.
Show up. Drop value.

Miss a day? Cool.
Just come back. Donâ€™t ghost.

I also learned the game.
First 3 lines decide if your post lives or dies.

Wins work.
Struggle stories work.
Underdog arcs kill.

And the biggest cheat code?
Stop gatekeeping.

When I started sharing raw,
how I was building BeHooked,
what flopped, what actually worked,
thatâ€™s when people connected.

Because LinkedIn doesnâ€™t reward polish.
It rewards honesty.
It rewards consistency.
It rewards storytelling.

10K feels nice.
But honestly... the best part?
Knowing it all started with one shitty, imperfect post that I was too tired to overthink.

So yeah. Stop thinking. Start posting.

Scaling is simple. Not easy, but simple. 

Do these 3 things well and you'll grow faster than 99% of competitors.



Most founders overcomplicate everything.

They chase 47 growth hacks instead of mastering fundamentals.

I built 2 billion dollar companies doing the opposite.

3 boring things. Done obsessively.

Here's what actually works:


1. Pick One Thing

Not three priorities.

Not five goals.

One obsession.

Most companies die from doing too much, not too little.


2. Measure Daily

What gets tracked gets improved.

If you can't measure it daily, you can't manage it.


3. Build Systems

Your business should run without you.

If it doesn't, you don't have a business.

You have a job.


Most founders chase 47 different strategies.

The winners do 3 things perfectly.

Simple beats complex every time.

Iâ€™m 45. 

Iâ€™ve made decades of mistakes. 

If youâ€™re under 37, donâ€™t make the same ones.

This is what Iâ€™d tell young Sharran...

The boring stuff is where the beautiful happens.

While everyone else is hunting for shortcuts...

Winners are doing the same boring things every single day.

They're not sexy.

They don't get likes on social media.

But they compound into extraordinary results.

Compound interest doesn't feel exciting when you're saving $500/month.

It feels incredible when your kids never have to worry about college tuition.

Daily workouts don't feel rewarding when you're sore and tired.

They feel amazing when you're 50 and stronger than most 30-year-olds.

Reading 20 pages a day doesn't seem like much.

It's life-changing when you've consumed 50 books in 2 years.

If you can fall in love with the process instead of chasing outcomes, you become unstoppable.

The magic isn't in finding the perfect strategy.

It's in doing the imperfect strategy consistently.

Stop asking for permission to be ambitious.

You don't need everyone to understand your vision.

The moment you start caring more about what strangers think, youâ€™ve already lost.

The opinions of strangers don't pay your bills, fund your dreams, or build your legacy.

However you slice it...

Your success doesn't require their approval.

Success doesn't create self-worth. 

Self-worth creates success.

The entrepreneurs who last:

They do the inner work first.
They build systems for their emotions.
They know their identity isn't their bank account.

The ones who crash and burn:

They chase external validation. They mistake achievement for identity.
They sabotage what they don't think they deserve.

You can't outrun your limiting beliefs with revenue.

If you don't fix what's between your ears, you'll find a way to lose what's in your bank account.

Work on yourself as hard as you work on your business.
Which money belief hurt you most?

Don't fill your calendar. 
Protect your highest leverage time. 

Don't glorify hustle.
Optimize for outcomes.

Don't chase opportunities.
Create systems that attract the right ones.

Most people mistake motion for progress.

Running around all day isnâ€™t going to move your business forward.

Busy people are often avoiding the 2-3 things that would actually change their trajectory.

Because those things are hard, uncertain, and require deep focus.

Stop asking:
"What can I do today?"

Start asking:
"What's the ONE thing that, if I nail it, makes everything else easier?"

Protect that ONE thing like your life depended on it.
If youâ€™re a parent and youâ€™ve never had â€˜the money talkâ€™ with your kids, this is for youâ€¦

The gap between where you are and where you want to be isnâ€™t luck.

Itâ€™s intention.

Most people treat their biggest goals casually.

They hope things will work out instead of designing a future worth living.

Wealth, freedom, legacy...

They all require intention so strong it shapes every decision you make.

A plan so dialed in it feels almost criminal.

Decades from now, your life will be the proof of the intentions you set today.

Here's how you grow an 8 figure business without burning out. 

Every founder says they want to scale.

Few can do it without turning their business into a stress factory.

The ones who win?

â€¢ Ruthless focus on revenue-first systems

â€¢ Document everything so the business isnâ€™t dependent on any one person

â€¢Say â€œnoâ€ to 90% of opportunities to protect the 10% that actually drive growth

This isnâ€™t about running small for the sake of small.

Itâ€™s about building a business that can take a punch and still print profit.

If you stripped away every non-essential role tomorrow, would your business still run?

Scaling isn't hard. 

Scaling without culture is.

Most founders obsess over growth metrics.

ARR.
Headcount.
Funding rounds.

But they forget the invisible foundation that holds everything together.

Culture isn't ping pong tables and free snacks.

Culture is belonging.

And belonging comes from one thing:

Cadence.

The Monday email you send to your team.

The weekly culture call where someone shares a book they love.

The consistent appreciation you show for the janitor and the COO equally.

Every Monday.
Every week.
Every interaction.

When systems break (and they will), culture forgives.

When you write that email on a bad day...

Culture gives you the benefit of the doubt.

When market conditions shift...

Culture rallies around the vision.

Here's the truth most leadership gurus won't tell you:

You can't define culture before it happens.

You can only build it through the daily cadence of communication and care.

I write my top 10 wins every Friday.

We used to have 30-minute culture calls every week.

Someone would share one thing they loved. Could be a book, a story, a Wikipedia page.

Simple? Yes.
Easy? No.
Transformative? Absolutely.

While your competitors chase vanity metrics...

You're building something that scales infinitely:

People who believe in the mission more than the paycheck.

The fastest way to waste months hiring? 

Start with a generic job description.

Thatâ€™s how most leaders treat high-stakes roles.

They search online, copy-paste a template, â€œput their spin on it,â€ and hope the right candidate shows up.

When I hired a General Counsel, I did the opposite:

I took 20 minutes to write every bullet point myself.

That simple act did two things:

1 - It forced me to clarify exactly what the role needed to achieve.

2 - It filtered out the wrong candidates before we even started interviews.

The interview process became faster, cleaner, and more decisive.

Why?

Because clarity came first.

Before you hire your next key role, will you take the time to make the description bulletproofâ€¦

â€¦or will you let the wrong candidates flood your inbox?

One quality I look for when I pick someone to be a leader:
Itâ€™s not how much they already know.

When I pick someone to lead, I donâ€™t expect them to know everything.

Because nobody knows everything. Not me, not you, not the smartest guy in the room.

The difference between a follower and a leader is simple:
What do they do when they donâ€™t know?

Some people freeze.
They wait for instructions.
They push responsibility upwards.
And thatâ€™s how you know they arenâ€™t ready.

But the ones who are ready?

They donâ€™t stop.
They figure it out.
They ask the right questions, call the right people, test, fail, test again until the problem is solved.

Thatâ€™s one quality I really care about.

Because everything changes markets, tech, rules, information.

But if you have the ability to move forward even when you donâ€™t know whatâ€™s next, then youâ€™ll never be stuck for too long.

Thatâ€™s the kind of person I want leading.
Someone who refuses to let â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€ stop them.

0% income tax but world-class infrastructure.

So how does Dubai ACTUALLY work? ğŸ¤”

Most countries rely heavily on income tax to function.
The UAE doesn't.

Yet they build jaw-dropping services at crazy speed.

Here's the economic model that makes it possible:

___

1/ Oil revenue provides only 1% of Dubai's GDP today.

This surprised me the most.
They've diversified brilliantly away from oil dependency.

___

2/ Corporate taxes on foreign banks and oil companies (20-55%).

While most businesses pay zero corporate tax, these sectors contribute significantly.

___

3/ Value-Added Tax (5% since 2018).

Lower than the UK's 20%, but generates substantial revenue across a massive consumer base.

___

4/ Tourism fees and hotel taxes (5-7% per night).

With 14+ million tourists annually, this adds up quickly.

___

5/ Knowledge fees, innovation fees, and municipality charges (2-5%).

Small percentages added to utility bills, business licenses, visa applications, car registrations, and add up to billions annually.

___

6/ Government-owned businesses generate massive profits.

Emirates Airlines, DP World (ports), Emaar (real estate) - the government owns stakes in all major industries.

___

7/ Real estate registration fees (4% of property value).

With some of the world's most valuable real estate, this is a goldmine.

___

8/ Business license fees ($1,000-$10,000+ annually).

With thousands of new businesses launching yearly, this creates steady revenue.

___

9/ Customs duties (5% on most imports).

As a global trade hub, the volume makes this significant.

___

10/ Road tolls (Salik) + parking fees throughout the city.

Small individual amounts but massive scale.

___

The genius?

It's in the diversification.

Instead of taking 20-40% from individual salaries, Dubai collects lots of small percentages across a wide range of activities.

This attracts talent and investment.

While STILL funding the infrastructure.

Would this model work in the UK?

Probably not entirely.

Different history.
Different resources.
Different social systems.
Different population size.

... and don't get me started on the UK mindset towards money, ambition, and entrepreneurship ğŸ¤¦ğŸ½â€â™‚ï¸

But there are defo lessons we could apply.

Like efficiency, diversification and encouraging entrepreneurship.

Anyone else agree?

PS. Let me know if you enjoyed this post and I'll do more like it (I studied Economics at uni ğŸ˜…)

While the UK puts up red tape...

Dubai rolls out the red carpet.

I've spent a week here and am starting to understand why entrepreneurs are flocking here.

It's not just the zero income tax.

It's the entire system:

___

1/ Free zones are entrepreneurial playgrounds.

Dubai has 40+ specialised free zones where you get:

100% foreign ownership
0% corporate tax (often guaranteed for 15-50yrs)
100% repatriation of capital and profits
No currency restrictions

Each zone focuses on a specific industry - fintech, media, healthcare, logistics.

___

2/ Banking is designed for global business.

UK banking for businesses? Weeks of scrutiny, limited international services, and CONSTANT compliance headaches.

Dubai's banks offer multi-currency accounts almost instantly.

Global payment solutions, and minimal paperwork.

They WANT your business.

___

3/ Visa processes that make sense.

UK visas for entrepreneurs are extremely selective and bureaucratic.

Dubai offers entrepreneur visas for as little as Â£3,000, processed in days, not months.

They're literally inviting you in.

___

4/ Government services that function like companies.

Every service is available via apps.

Need a business license? 15 minutes on your phone.
Utility connections? Same day.
Tax filing? Almost non-existent.

The mindset difference is striking:

In the UK, the default answer is "no, unless..."
In Dubai, it's "yes, and here's how..."

___

There's a reason thousands of UK entrepreneurs have relocated here.

The system is designed to help you win...

Not hold you back.

Is Dubai perfect? Absolutely not.

But they've created the most frictionless business environment I've ever experienced.

The UK could learn a lot from this approach.

Anyone else agree?

We know technology is transforming our world â€“ we know that the transformation is getting ever faster.

Where is Africa? In the conversation or left outside?

Young Africans are digitally native, entrepreneurial, and hungry to build. What we need are more opportunities for partnership, more belief in our potential, and platforms to amplify our voices. Africa has led in digital banking, in payments, our value chains can be transformed. We know that many of the minerals that are techsâ€™ foundation are found in Africa. But is Africa getting the benefit? Africa needs to capture the moment â€“ ensure we have digital sovereignty â€“ that African priorities are understood and met.

I joined global tech leaders at an exclusive dinner at the Ã‰lysÃ©e Palace in Paris, with President Macron. I wanted to ensure there was an African voice at the table.

I had enriching conversations global tech CEOs, including Jensen Huang, CEO of NVIDIA, about how innovation can and must be used to solve humanityâ€™s most pressing challenges, including those facing Africa.

Atwe are deeply invested in Africaâ€™s digital transformation. Africa needs to win this battle. We are building and backing African tech champions likeandthat are not only serving African markets but are also capable of competing globally.

For me, last night was about reinforcing the message that Africa is ready and our time is now. Our young population is digitally native, entrepreneurial, and hungry to build. What we need are improved infrastructure, more opportunities for partnership, more belief in our potential, and platforms to amplify our voices.

Tech knows no borders. Innovation thrives where talent meets investment. And Africa, with the right support, should be the next frontier of global tech growth.

I say, let us choose Africa for tech, for partnerships, for the future.

Global economies are undergoing a massive transformation, shaped by shifts in geopolitics, culture, demographics, technology, and volatile trade dynamics. Old certainties are gone; new certainties yet to emerge.

Where is Africa in this new world order? Africa, a continent rich in potential, with its youthful population, natural resources, and dynamic entrepreneurial spirit. Too often overlooked, the future of the world is going to be increasingly influenced by Africa and Africans. How can the world partner with Africa to unlock the huge opportunities present, for mutual and lasting benefit?

The African Development Bank forecasts that Africa's GDP will grow at an average of 4% per year over the next decade, largely driven by entrepreneurship and innovation. With internet penetration reaching 45% in 2023, Africa is enjoying a digital revolution, opening vast opportunities for connectivity and commerce. The African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) aims to create a unified market for goods and services across the continent, and according to the IMF, it is projected to boost intra-African trade by 52% by the year 2025. Traditional trade models, which have often excluded or marginalised Africa, must evolve. AfCFTA represents a bold step towards redefining trade dynamics. By uniting 55 countries into a single market of 1.3 billion people, AfCFTA has the potential to add $450 billion to Africaâ€™s GDP by 2035.

This initiative is critical for establishing the infrastructure necessary for accelerated development. In 2022 alone, African tech startups raised a record $5 billion, a figure that continues to rise, highlighting the continent's vibrant entrepreneurial landscape. Technology is revolutionising trade and economies in ways we could not have imagined a decade ago. African innovators are creating solutions tailored to our unique challenges. Mobile money platforms have transformed financial systems, enabling millions to access banking services. E-commerce platforms are breaking down traditional barriers to trade.

These statistics illustrate the immense potential Africa offers, particularly in entrepreneurship, the backbone of the continent's economic growth. However, to harness these opportunities fully, Africa's economic growth must be equitable: Africans need to get real value from their commodity supply chain by participating, barriers to agricultural exports need to be removed, the impact of climate change acknowledged by the polluters: and inclusive: benefiting women, youth, and marginalised communities.

With over 60% of its population under the age of 25, Africa's youth represent a vast reservoir of talent and creativity. Yet, women entrepreneurs face particularly significant barriers in accessing capital, markets, and networks, while our young grapple with high unemployment rates.

My Goodwill Message at the 3rd Anniversary of Nigerian Upstream Petroleum Regulatory Commission (NUPRC):

Firstly, I congratulate the leaders of NUPRC for this momentous occasion.

As Chairman of, an integrated and indigenous energy group playing a key role in facilitating energy sufficiency in Nigeria, and Chairman of thewhich provides substantial funding across the energy value chain, amounting to several billions of US Dollars, to both indigenous and international oil and gas operators and oil trading companies, I stand before you at the intersection of finance and energy, two pillars that are crucial to our nation's prosperity.

Today's theme, "Transformation, Innovation & Excellence," resonates deeply with the challenges and opportunities facing Nigeriaâ€™s energy space.

We are faced with the threat of declining production and investment. We must acknowledge the elephant in the room. Nigeria's oil production has been on a downward trajectory, falling from peaks of over 2 million barrels per day to recent lows, below 1.5 million. This decline translates to lost revenues, reduced global market share, and missed opportunities for national development.

At Heirs Energies, we are actively contributing to the solution. In the first 100 days after we took over operational control of our OML-17 asset in 2021, we doubled our production from 28,000 to over 50,000 barrels per day.

We suffered a setback with unabated crude theft, which caused us to shut-in and work collaboratively with the NNPC Limited to better secure the pipeline system.

With the improvement in the operating environment, we have restarted our investment and production growth journey, and have now successfully reversed the fall in production that we suffered in 2022 and 2023, as a consequence of the evacuation challenges. A few days ago, OML-17 attained over 51,000 barrels per day, and we continue our production growth journey.

I am not just an oil and gas investor â€“ I am an investor across the Nigerian â€“ and indeed Arican â€“ economy. I have a very clear vision of where Africa should be and needs to be. A vision to address the promise of our enormous youth population and to ensure Africa reaps the rewards, finally and fittingly, of her resource wealth. That younger generation is why I invest in entrepreneurs.

That is why I speak of Africapitalism. My belief that the private sector has the power to transform the continent through long-term investments, but that it must work collaboratively with the public sector.

Africapitalism advocates shared prosperity, ensuring environmental sustainability, and fostering community development. This philosophy aligns perfectly with NUPRC's vision and the objectives of Project 1MMBOPD.

Let us all be Africapitalists! Doing good and doing well! Read full speech on my blog.

I've uploaded 800+ YouTube videos since 2017.

But it took me 7 years to upload my first video.

I thought I needed the perfect plan - that if I waited and prepared for long enough, I'd feel ready.

Perfect content strategy.
Perfect production quality.
Perfect camera confidence.

So when I read about the pottery class paradox, it hit home.

A ceramics teacher split his class into two groups.

Group A had to make one perfect pot in 30 days.
Group B had to make as many pots in 30 days.

At the end of the month, the teacher judged the quality of the pots.

Without exception, every one of the most beautiful and well-made pots came from Group B - the quantity group.

For me too, the moment I shifted to just making one video every week no matter what, everything changed.

My writing started flowing better.
My editing got better through repetition.
I developed better instincts for what worked.

800+ uploads later, I still fall into perfectionist habits sometimes.

But I try to trick my brain into starting.

I ask "What would this look like if it were fun?"
I tell myself, "Just record - no need to publish."
I focus on serving others, not protecting my ego.

And once I hit record and start talking, the creative spirit moves within me, even when the process feels messy.

P.S. If you want more insights on productivity and overcoming perfectionism, I share my best thinking here ğŸ‘‰

Last year, I was invited to speak at Google.
 
After my talk, an employee asked me a question.

"Whatâ€™s the most surprising productivity experiment you've tried on yourself?"

My answer was the unreasonable power of a leveling-up meter.

I actually got this from playing videos games back in the day, especially World of Warcraft.

These days I'm playing Horizon: Forbidden West on PS5. Leave a comment if you are into it too :)

So, in video games, as you complete missions, three things happen:

Your experience bar fills up.
You get new skills.
You level up.

And that's a trick video game designers use to keep us hooked to the game.

So I tried this while writing my book, "Feel-Good Productivity."

Writing a book was often confusing and draining and so every day, I started tracking my word count and suddenly, writing became a game.

Those random 7-minute gaps between meetings? Instead of scrolling YouTube, I'd think: "7 minutes is enough to make progress on this chapter."

In fact, I made the most progress on the book when we had a 6 day team retreat and I gave myself the challenge of writing one chapter per day.

And finally the simple act of tracking word count turned a draining task into something energising.

Obviously productivity is deeply personal so what works for me might not work for you.

If tracking word count energises me but drains you, that's fine.

Try something else that helps you gamify the process.

The goal isn't to find the "perfect" system.

It's to keep experimenting until you find what makes your work fun.

â†³ Formal recognition for impactful changes

Most content fails because it's too generic.

Here's an example I read in my feed: 

------

"Do you want to attract more leads on LinkedIn?

Follow these 8 simple steps:

1. Pick a professional pic

A picture says more than 1,000 words. Make it representative

2. Write a catchy headline

Your headline is your business card. Make it appealing.

3. Make your About section personal and interesting

Tell your story:" ... etc

------

Great tips. But what now?

Most people take 1 big topic and make it:

- Too generic and broad
- Too hard or vague to apply
- Too complex (because too much to tell)

What you can do instead (let's use the example above):

1. Take one specific topic (let's use "About section")
2. Break down and simplify so everybody gets it
3. Use real examples to make it tangible

Here's how I'd write a short and actionable About post:

------

"How I optimize my client's About copy to attract leads.

Most About sections look like this:

- Talking about me, me, me (like a resume)
- Fluff like education, hobbies, passions
- They mention jobs but not real results

Some even talk in the 3rd person (please don't).

Use the PAIS framework instead and talk about:

1. Pains (the people you want to attract)
2. Agitate (results of wrong actions/inaction)
3. Ideal Situation (a desirable outcome vs. pains)
4. Solution (your offer + tangible positive outcomes)

Bonus: use this as a post to write your next post.

(One client got 8 inbound leads with 1 PAIS post)

Analyze and grab my profile's About framework.

Stop telling. Start showing."

------

Recap:

â†’ Show 1 topic
â†’ Show examples
â†’ Show experiences
â†’ Show real-life context
â†’ Show how they can do it

------

I love creating resources on content ideation, but sometimes even I feel lost on what to write.

It happened right before I was writing this.

Ironically, you can get rusty by doing the same thing a lot of times.

Things start to feel off, casual, perhaps even boring and regurgitated.

Then I remembered creating an infographic about a year ago.

I had no idea what I was going to create. I literally started with a single line.

It resulted in an infographic with a timeline of what my journey as a creator looked like. It did surprisingly well.

Today, it's a visual I show clients when they feel stuck writing content.

I tell them that you can be surprisingly productive and creative if you just start.

Sometimes it's best to let it all go:

No frameworks, no AI, no hacks, no rules, no nothing.

Just start writing and get the creative juices flowing.

It doesn't have to win awards, go viral, or get clients right out of the gate.

It's just another rep that trains your creativity muscle.

To me personally, it feels quite liberating and therapeutic, especially on an easy Sunday afternoon.

Write because it feels good. Write to keep the axe sharp. Write to resonate with people who might read this.

Just start.

"Just write for 1 audience."

That advice works... 

... if your audience behaves like one.

But they often don't.

One audience is usually two overlapping groups:

1. Your peers â†’ interact, amplify, apply
2. Your ideal customers â†’ observe, consider, decide

Your peers share your content and increase your reach exponentially. That reach puts you on your ICP's radar.

Your ideal customers rarely comment or engage. But they read everything.

They're qualifying you in silence.

If you only write for buyers, your reach suffers.
If you only write for peers, you won't convert.

So your content has to do both:

1. Peers need guidance â†’ "Here's how to solve this"
2. Buyers need recognition â†’ "This is your pain. I solve it"
3. Both need proof â†’ "Here's how it works in practice"

Same message. Different activation.

That's why reach + resonance aren't opposites.

They're allies if you design your content for both roles.

I once had a portfolio that nobody knew about.

It was 2018, and I was still running a branding agency.

On paper, we were doing great:

- Fancy office with a canal view in Amsterdam
- A fairly large team with different disciplines
- Plenty of referrals coming in (or so we thought)

We built a website showcasing our work, and it looked great.

But our website analytics? Embarrassing.

We probably got 10-20 visits per week.

Why? Because we did absolutely nothing to drive visibility.

No SEO. No paid ads. No email marketing. No content.

"We get referrals, so we don't need all that."

But we were fooling ourselves. The referrals werenâ€™t as great as we thought.

I noticed a pattern:

- Weâ€™d work on projects for 2-3 months
- No time for client acquisition
- Then we'd hustle for 1-2 months
- Finally, weâ€™d close a few clients

And then the cycle would start over again (feast and famine).

Fast forward to post-2022: Iâ€™ve posted over 600 times on LinkedIn. The opportunities have been incredible:

- Coaching and training
- Speaking engagements and partnerships
- More content design inquiries than we can handle

Heck, I amassed 74,000 followers along the way (starting with 900).

Now Iâ€™m about to launch a private group for creators and founders who want to learn how to create content that attracts their ideal audience.

Becoming the â€˜creatorâ€™ guy was never the goal.

But I refused to go back to that state of invisibility.

You could have the best work in the world:

If nobody knows about it, you wonâ€™t sell.

â€œWe were in before the callâ€. 

Had a sales call this week.

Amazing agency. Great founders. They create beautiful work.

We had been following each other on LinkedIn for a while.

Even discussed a potential collaboration about a year ago.

Then we reconnected in the DMs.

We had a 25-min call where I walked them through our process.

They were excited.

â€œAre you in?â€ I asked.

â€œWe were in before the callâ€ they said.

My content had done the heavy lifting. The â€˜nurturingâ€™.

Thatâ€™s what I like so much about organic content marketing.

Itâ€™s not the fastest way to ROI. And definitely not the only way.

But if you share the right content for the right people long enough, they get to know you before you ever even talk to them.

They are sold by your work without pitching.

They are being attracted vs being chased.

And now weâ€™ll do the same for our new client.

Share your work.

(And sometimes a selfie)

â€œMy content doesnâ€™t sell.â€

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s usually happening:

Youâ€™ve posted before.
You just didnâ€™t get results.

Not because your ideas were bad.
But because the structure was missing.

Hereâ€™s what I changed (for myself and clients):

1) Stop talking about everything
â†’ One category. One message.
â†’ Repetition builds recognition.

2) Stop hiding your offer
â†’ Mention it weekly (subtle AND clear).
â†’ The best content educates and entertains.

3) Use the PAIS structure
â†’ Pain, Agitation, Ideal Situation, Solution
â†’ Clear, actionable. Built for conversion.

4) Make it readable
â†’ Short lines. Skimmable bullets.
â†’ Think phone, not desktop.

5) Share results, not just opinions
â†’ Screenshots. Case studies. Proof.
â†’ Authority comes from teaching, not telling.

The format is simple.
But most people wing it.

This is how I turn content into leads â¬‡ï¸

(Without starting from scratch every week)

The thing that REALLY grinds my gears and so many organisations get wrong when it comes to hiring generalists ğŸ‘‡ğŸ½ğŸ‘‡ğŸ½

That a generalist hire = junior hire

Let me say this as clearly as I can...

**Hiring generalists for mid, senior, and leadership roles makes GREAT business sense**

I spend ALOT of time sourcing & curating jobs for ournewsletter. Every Tuesday, 30k people read it. Loads have been hired from it. IT'S GREAT!

But I've noticed a dark pattern..

âœ… I'll see a job posting specifically looking for a generalist. YAY!
âœ… It looks like they value a wide breadth of experiences. YAY!
âœ… It looks like a fun, varied, challenging scope. YAY!
âŒ But, they're looking for 1-2 years experience ğŸ¤”

Now, don't get me wrong.. I'm glad these junior jobs exist! But there's a danger in boxing the 'generalist role' to being only suitable for folks early in their career (and therefore slacking on compensation too)

This is all messily tied up in the underlying stigma of generalism.

But, mark my words, there's going to be a day (soon!) where the smartest companies *explicitly hire senior generalists*

I mean, we're already seeing it with CEO's of+shouting about the value of generalism.

Because people with this non-traditional, squiggly career have it all:

- proven experience across multiple roles, industries and domains
- proven ability to learn fast, ship quality, with a keen operating sense
- proven scaling organisations through rough seas
- proven 'get it done' / 'make it happen' people
- proven problem-solves and fixers

They're the ones you want in today's world.

They're senior. They're generalists.

And they're hella valuable.

Do you see this pattern too?

I don't know if I've seen a SINGLE POST IN MY ENTIRE LinkedIn DAYS that speaks about this:
(so, let's get into it ğŸ’… )

Planning for motherhood as a business owner

2 years ago, I had the extraordinary experience of being a part of my best friends birth of her first baby. Something clicked in my spirit. I went from "hmm not sure about kids because the state of the world etc etc" to every inch of my body saying.. YES. THIS.

(I then went borderline insane; completely fixated on this for a while. The biological clock is REAL. That's a diff story lol)

Where I'm at now: within the next year or so, I hope to become a Mum.

Even writing that feels scary!!! Some literal thoughts that have held me back from sharing this with you have been:

- people won't invest so much energy into GW 'cos they think I'll disappear
- I'll get judged for choosing motherhood over my career
- what if they think I'm not serious about GW anymore?

I know these things are all irrational, but I'm sharing because if I'm thinking them, I know others will be too.

But like.. why on earth is this so taboo? We have an aging population, birth rates are down EVERYWHERE. Surely this should be a ripe, urgent convo to help support women to find sustainable pathways to raise a family, and if they choose, continue building their businesses / grow their career?!

So I thought.. f* it. Let's talk about it.

Do you know what my ABSOLUTE DREAM is?

I went through a phase where I would near pee myself from nerves if I had to do a presentation (not cute ğŸ˜‚). Now 'speaker' is a part of my job. Here's how I prep for talks and have LOADS OF FUN doing it

1. Get booked, obvs

Pitch yourself in. DM event organisers or communities who run events. Give them a few titles which clearly would be a value-add for their audience. Do this till it doesn't feel scary. Then do it 100x more.

2. Speak aloud the outline

I recently did a training withwhere I learned to TRUST my voice-brain connection. I'll now open a blankdoc, getfired up, and speak aloud my thoughts, one point at a time.

Importantly: I'm not judging anything at this point, or trying to make it perfect. I'm trusting myself to know that the content that needs to come out, will emerge.

3. Get critical feedback from Claude

Use a prompt like: "You're an renowned speaker, an expert in delivering engaging and memorable talks. Give me critical feedback on what's working well, and how I could make it stronger"

4. Use

I feed my notes into Gamma, and it literally generates me the bones of a presentation in 3 seconds. Magic!! My top tip: replace all AI images with GIFs ğŸ˜‰ Btw, get one month of Gamma Pro for free with the code GENERALIST

5. I lean MORE into being me

My slides, my notes, my transitions. They all need to feel like you're in the room with the *real* Milly. I used to get caught up in trying to be too polished and it honestly just made the whole process stressful and my talks not as effective.

6. Be more honest

This is a tip from the wonderfulthat's stuck with me. Just be REALLY honest. I also used to get caught up on saying the "right" thing or hitting the points I thought I "should" say. But really, I'm in the room holding that microphone because my lived experience has taught me perspectives only I have. Honesty resonates.

7. Run through once, then close the tab and touch some grass

Give it space to breathe & your ideas to percolate. Come back to it with fresh eyes 24hrs later. Make tweaks. Run through again. I actually don't like to run through it on the day-off. I'll look over it, but save my energy for the talk itself

8. ğŸ BONUS: during your talk your *main* job is to create contagious energy

Maybe you're creating excitement, hope, possibility, awe, focus. The best talks don't have the perfect slides or the perfect script. They create a feeling in the room. And people never forget that.

For a $1B+ HR tech CEO I achieved: 2.2M impressions, 84 days, with 2 posts per week. How did I get them there? Here's my 5-step LinkedIn playbook (and why most founders are doing it completely wrong):

1. I maximized reach WITHOUT diluting resonance

Most HR tech CEO write ONLY for HR people. I write specifically for HR leaders too. But this CEO has very large (and very valuable) â€œsideâ€ audiences in sales and engineering. So I structure every post so engineers get value, and sales teams find nuggets.

Not diluting anything - just maximizing who can learn from it. The result? Our best posts show 0.1% engagement because they're reaching WAY beyond the founder's followers. Low engagement % = massive reach. Once I understood this, everything clicked.

2. I threw out the "post daily" playbook.

Everyone screams about daily posting. I knew better. For them, just 2 posts per week - but each one meticulously crafted. Obsessed over. Refined until perfect. Better to post nothing than post garbage. â€œQuality over quantityâ€ isn't just a saying - it's the entire strategy.

3. I made specificity their superpower.

"Last quarter we..." "In March 2024..." Every hook anchored in time or data. No generic wisdom. No platitudes. Real stories, real numbers, real moments. I started treating the first 3 lines like million-dollar real estate. Because on LinkedIn, they are.

4. I made authenticity their unfair advantage.

I record every conversation with the founder. Use their exact words with necessary editing. When you've built something worth $1B+, authenticity IS your differentiator. Most ghostwriters try to sound smarter than their clients. I do the opposite - I preserve their voice completely. That's the whole point.

5. I rejected growth hacks.

No engagement pods. No tag-spamming. No automation. Just pure value, consistently delivered. While everyone else chases shortcuts, I focused on one thing: making every post worth the founder's time to share. Turns out that's all you need.

TAKEAWAY:

For any B2B founder, 2.2M impressions in <90 days is a dream.

But as long as you have the credibility, thereâ€™s no reason your CEO/founder/CRO canâ€™t get it either.

The problem: most founders on LinkedIn are stuck because they're following outdated playbooks.

I've worked with 50+ B2B leaders.

The struggle for "more" feels the same whether you're at 10K or 10M impressions.

But here's the good news...

If you lead a successful company, you ALREADY have everything you need. You donâ€™t need hacks, pods, automations, or anything game-y.

If you're stuck at low visibility, just know that you CAN break through.

I was right where you are - posting into the void, wondering why nothing hit.

And I got to 230k followers. No tricks. Just strategy.

You can get there too.

Just keep refining :)

In early 2024, I lost a $5,500/month client backed by Andreessen Horowitz in the most painful way possible.

The CEO of my biggest account sent me a message that changed everything:

"I don't feel my voice is being captured. I'm going back to writing my own content."

Here's what happened:

Months earlier, I'd signed my dream client: a finance SaaS soon-to-be-unicorn. Their CEO had never worked with anyone on LinkedIn before. He chose me over all others.

$5,500/month.
Six-figure contract.
The kind of client that puts you on the map.

I thought I'd cracked the code. Built a "scalable" content agency. Had writers handling the actual writing while I focused on strategy.

Everything seemed perfect.
Engagement was up.
Quality comments flowing.

Then came that message.

I panicked. Got defensive.

Instead of listening, I fired back with metrics. â€œLook at your engagement rates! The data says we're dominating!:

He stopped responding.

$66,000+ annual contract â€¦ gone.

When I talked to a mentor about it, his words stung:

"Sam, this isn't going to be good for your ego, but you screwed up. Clients don't pay for metrics. They pay to be understood. And you stopped understanding them the day you stopped writing."

He was right. A part-time freelancer had been writing for this client. Not me.

She was (very) talented, but she didn't have the time to immerse herself in each client's voice the way I could.

That loss forced me to face a very uncomfortable truth: I'd scaled too fast and lost what made my service special.

So I went back to my roots:

Started writing every single post myself again. Became obsessed with capturing each client's exact voice in the most compelling way possible.

The transformation was basically immediate.

Clients started saying things like:

"He helped me reach 400K+ enterprise professionals with a single post." â€”SaaS founder, $1B+ company

"Sam's ability to understand the nuances of who you are and become an extension of you online is second to none." â€”Exited founder, Forbes 30 Under 30

Today:

- Premium clients only
- Extraordinarily high profit margins
- Haven't lost a client to quality concerns since

What's the takeaway?

Especially in the AI era, relationships are your only real moat. Soft skills matter more than systems.

You can scale, but slow is fast.

Stay lean. Build deep understanding with clients before you build processes around them.

I learned this the hard way: A client who feels truly understood will pay 10x more than one who just gets good metrics.

That lost client taught me excellence isn't about choosing between scale and quality.

It's about never scaling faster than your ability to maintain relationships.

Always be coachable. Especially when it hurts your ego.

My sister Lauren Szuchan just crossed 12,000 LinkedIn followers, up from under 10,000 two months ago. She landed a new role at SourceWhale, and has people constantly DMing her for LinkedIn advice.

Here's what she's doing right that most get wrong:

1. She Stuck to One Topic: Sales. Only Sales. Forever.

She wanted to mix in fitness content, personal development, and general business thoughts. I told her: "People followed you for enterprise sales. Post about random stuff and they're gone."

She listened. Now every follower knows exactly what they're getting. No surprises. No wild pivots. Just pure sales expertise.

2. She Only Posts When She Has Something Real to Say

Most advice says "post daily." She posts 2-3 times per week, max. Here's why it works: Every post comes from something that genuinely surprised her. A deal that should've been lost but didn't. A tactic that worked when nothing else would.

When her name shows up in your feed, you know it's going to be worth the read. That makes a massive difference in audience quality over time vs. creators just running the hamster wheel.

3. Every Post Reads Like a Sales War Story

She's not writing basic "5 Ways to Handle Objections" posts. She's writing, "Being likable in sales is overrated. Being respected is what actually moves deals forward." Real strategy is built on real-life experience.

No theoretical frameworks. No recycled advice. Just actionable feedback.

4. She Shares What Actually Happens in Sales Calls

No fluff about "mindset" or "hustle." She writes about real moments: when the CFO suddenly joins unannounced. When your champion gets laid off mid-deal. When legal throws a curveball on terms.

She captures the messy reality of enterprise sales and how exactly she handles it.

5. She Writes Like She's Mentoring You Over Coffee

No buzzwords. No "synergistic value propositions." She writes exactly how she'd explain something to a new rep who's struggling.

Simple language. Clear examples. Zero pretense.

â€”â€”

Most important: she never set out to build a "personal brand."

She just started documenting what actually works in sales.

The follower count opened doors.

The engagement proved expertise.

In her posts, people can see exactly how she thinks, sells, and solves problems.

Most people chase vanity metrics. She chased clarity.

When you nail the second one, the first follows :)

How did I grow past 100k+ followers in my first year on LinkedIn?

Through following these 5 key principles:

1. Mentally preparing to succeed

You need to establish a specific area where you can build expertise and authority.

I feel jealous of my friends flying business.

The photos, the reels, the airport lounges that look like art galleries - it gets to me.

It's the freedom to choose it.
Yes, 5-star hotels are nice.

But so is butter toast with a mountain view and cardamom tea made by a stranger who smiles like your grandmother.

The world will tell you that success is about upgrades.

But maybe, real success is the ability to feel joy even when you donâ€™t upgrade.
Maybe itâ€™s sitting in economy, feet a little cramped, heart completely full.
Maybe itâ€™s choosing what feels real over what looks rich.

As a creator, itâ€™s exhausting to be judged for your clothes.

If you wear casuals > youâ€™re â€œnot serious enough.â€
If you wear formals > youâ€™re â€œtrying too hard.â€

Thereâ€™s no winning.

But hereâ€™s the truth:

People donâ€™t actually judge your clothes.
They judge the story they attach to your clothes.

In marketing, and in life, perception is the reality we deal with.
Every color you wear. Every style you choose. Every tiny visual cue ~ people are subconsciously assigning it meaning.

Casual? â€œMaybe sheâ€™s too laid back to trust with serious work.â€
Formal? â€œMaybe sheâ€™s desperate for validation.â€
Trendy? â€œMaybe sheâ€™s superficial.â€
Minimalist? â€œMaybe sheâ€™s boring.â€

The story people build about you isnâ€™t about you at all.
Itâ€™s about them: their biases, their experiences, their projections.

And if you try to shape-shift for every opinion, youâ€™ll spend your life in a never-ending costume change for an audience that doesnâ€™t even know what it truly wants.

As a marketer, Iâ€™ve learned: your brand isnâ€™t what you wear.
Itâ€™s the consistency with which you show up, regardless of how youâ€™re perceived.

People might remember your outfit for a second.
But they will remember your energy for much longer.

Choose energy.
Choose consistency.
Choose authenticity.

Let the clothes be an accessory, not the conversation. What do you think?

I have clients who pay me $20K - $50k on a retainer. So, sharing my 5-step lead gen process that I use to get quality leads:


1.    Niche
It is the very first step, no matter what you do. Pick 2-3 categories and niche down.
Ex: From marketing, I narrowed it down to personal branding.

2.    Find 2-3 clients first
Donâ€™t run towards high-paying clients. Find small clients first.
My first client paid me INR 5000 and I used to manage all of the socials including content, engagement, and everything. But the client was famous and it gave me an added advantage to score big clients.

3.    Build your socials
Always have a good social media presence on 1 platform. I started on Twitter and now I have 95K followers there.
So start with 1 platform and keep sharing your story on that social.

4.    Create an irresistible offer
Value = Benefit â€“ Cost
Create your offer so good that people will feel like a fool by saying No to you.
Ex: I could help you grow your revenue to $50K/m but you need to pay me $2000/m. Would you do that? Obviously YES.

5.    Cold outreach
I use LinkedIn Sales Navigator and filter out my leads. Send your potential clients a cold DM or email and give them a reason to work with you. Consistency is very important for this.

6.    Follow-ups
Make a spreadsheet and track all the people you have DMed. Keep following up. Donâ€™t just DM, spice it up with witty one-liners.
Ex; â€œHey, just bumping this up in case you missed itâ€ Or â€œHi, just following up to see if you want to make an extra $20K/m with your personal brandâ€. Or "I know must be busy, but this will only benefit you"

Now, keep track of everything. Create solid SOPs to keep them in check.

Also donâ€™t forget to add AI wherever possible.

It isnt as hard as it sounds but it isnt as easy as it looks.

If you are consistent for 6 months, I am sure you can get quality leads from LinkedIn itself.

Here's a mini guide on 5 game-changing rules that helped me grow to 150K followers: 


1.    Catchy hook
No LinkedIn post works without a catchy, emotional, or relatable hook.
The first line is what grabs the attention and makes readers read the rest.

âŒ â€œAs I was walking through the streets of London, I realized these things about moneyâ€
âœ… â€œI went to London last week and here are a few things I realized that can save you $$$â€.

2.    Use simple words
Simplicity and relatability work the best.
So donâ€™t use complex words, keep it as simple as possible.

âŒ â€œI didnâ€™t anticipate this would happen when I started LinkedInâ€
âœ… 7 things you are not focusing on LinkedIn that can make you lose out on $2000.â€

3.    Community
Yes, engagement is important but not for the sake of it.

I donâ€™t engage much, but I do engage intentionally. I only reply or DM to the people who either engage with my posts or have some relevant things to say.

After 100s of posts, you should by now know how to cold DM. So donâ€™t send â€œI am interestedâ€, or â€œAny job openingâ€, to me or to anyone.

Instead, write why you want to work, and in which area youâ€™re looking for a job.

4.    Write as you speak
A lot of people would disagree with it but it actually works.
It helps you get connected to your audience much faster.
Just be yourself.

Authenticity >> Fake persona

5.    Punchy CTA

Add a CTA that is relatable and makes people feel good about the post.
A small TLDR that refocuses your entire post on the main reason.

On LinkedIn, itâ€™s all about keeping it real.

Ask anything about LinkedIn in the comments and I'll answer.

Everyone says marketing is about creativity.

But the real problem is:

â€¢â€“ Most marketers focus on trends, fancy visuals, and flashy campaignsâ€¦ and forget the psychology that actually drives buying decisions.

â€¢â€“ Stop guessing what works. Start using human behavior to guide every move.

Think about it:

If you only follow trends, your campaigns will blend in and fade fast.

But when you use proven psychology triggers like Loss Aversion, Social Proof, or the Halo Effect suddenly, your marketing connects deeper, feels familiar, and drives action.

Hesitant to start writing on LinkedIn?

Hereâ€™s a roadmap to simplify your personal brand-

1/ Ask yourself, â€œWhat do I want to be known for?â€

2/ And then, consistently create content around that for 30 days.

3/ Research small and big creators who broadly write around similar topics. Actively engage with their content.

4/ Consume their content religiously to decode their patterns and strategies.

5/ Engage with their followers and invite them to your feed.

6/ Look for close-knit groups for mutual growth. Honestly, being a part of communities brings a real- difference. You literally have a mini personal squad at all times.

AND,

If you could follow only 2 tips of many, Iâ€™d say: Go ahead with 2 & 6, and figure out the rest along the way.

Most people ignore how LinkedIn search actually works, then wonder why nobody can find them.

Fixing profiles day in and day out taught me this:

1) LinkedIn's algorithm prioritizes RELEVANCE over popularity.

- Your profile must match what people are searching for
- Generic keywords = generic ranking

2) Your headline is search gold.

- LinkedIn weights headline terms 3x more than other sections

- Yet most people waste it on "Founder | CEO | Coffee Lover"

(Those aren't search terms!)

3) You're keyword stuffing (and it's backfiring).

- LinkedIn penalizes obvious stuffing
- Natural integration > forced repetition

4) You're ignoring the "Skills" section.

- Each endorsed skill is a direct search signal
- Arrange them strategically (top 3 matter most)

5) Your content doesn't reinforce your keywords.

- Posts/comments strengthen your search relevance
- Inconsistent messaging confuses the algorithm

6) You're not leveraging your Experience section.

- Each role description = prime keyword real estate
- Most people just list responsibilities

7) You haven't completed your profile.

- LinkedIn rewards completeness
- Every empty field reduces your search potential

You just need to approach LinkedIn search like a STRATEGIST, not someone hoping to get lucky in search results.

And once you master that?

Your profile won't just get occasional views.
It'll become a client-generating machine that works 24/7.

LinkedIn's algorithm prioritizes relevance over follower count.

Fix: Focus on being found by the right people, not everyone.

And never ignore your Skills section ... it's search gold! ğŸ˜‰

Hope this helps. (If so, repost for others, please â™»ï¸)

PS: What industry are you in, and what search terms matter most to you?

If you want to revive a "dead" LinkedIn account in 7 days without posting daily, gather here:

I once had only 1,000 impressions and got zero traction or leads... until I realized I was doing LinkedIn all wrong.

Meanwhile, my clients were jumping to 100,000+ impressions using my exact system.

Here's exactly how I'd revive it in 7 days:

1. Engage before you post

Leave 70-80 comments daily for 6 days a week.
This primes the algorithm to recognize you as valuable.
Your future posts will get pushed to more feeds as a result.

2. Post with strategic intention

3-5 posts weekly (different formats) beats daily posting.
One story, one value post, one authority-builder.
Quality always trumps quantity on LinkedIn.

3. Own your comments section completely.

Own your comments section (active for 45+ mins)
Reply to EVERY comment (make them conversations).
Add 2-3 bonus comments with extra insights.

4. Build connections with purpose

10-15 targeted connection requests/DMs daily.
Not selling - just connecting authentically.
Mix peers, prospects, and re-engaging old connections.

5. Create a sustainable rhythm.

Consistency matters more than intensity.
Some can post daily, others can't. That's fine.
The goal is sustainability, not burnout.

Give yourself 30-60 days if you're starting fresh.

Literally, just follow this system â†’ watch your impressions grow â†’ see 1,000 become 100,000+ in weeks.

I do this every... single... day. ğŸ˜Š

Pro tip: The algorithm needs to be "primed" before your posts will perform well.

(Repost this advice for others â™»ï¸)

P.S. Did your LinkedIn account ever "die"? How long did it take you to revive it?

P.P.S. Save this + come back when you're ready to commit.

Why your headline isn't selling you on LinkedIn 

Your LinkedIn headline is your digital first impression. But most people get it completely wrong.

1) They focus on job titles instead of outcomes.
2) They list skills instead of solutions.

3) They speak about themselves instead of their audience.

Your headline should answer ONE question:

"What problem do I solve for others?"

This is why your current headline isn't selling you:

It's too vague ("Marketing Professional")
It's all about you, not your audience
It lacks specificity on WHO you help

It doesn't highlight the transformation you provide
It blends in with thousands of others

Turn "Marketing Manager" into "I help LinkedIn creators monetize their audience through my Connection-to-Cash System"

See the difference?

One is a title. The other is a promise.

Bonus:

The 'Problem-Solution Method':

Each headline I write has:

The audience â†’ makes it targeted
The problem â†’ shows understanding
The solution â†’ demonstrates value

Your headline should make people WANT to click your profile.

Because they see the value you offer immediately.

- Stop wasting prime digital real estate on job titles.
- Start selling your unique value proposition instead.

Your audience has a 5-second attention span.

(That's it.)

They won't scroll down.
They'll scroll AWAY.

I've been shouting this from the rooftops:
â†’ Clear messaging is EVERYTHING.

You can be insanely talented
You can offer the best service
You can dominate the perfect niche

But with a complicated message?
You're practically invisible.

I discovered Donald Miller's StoryBrand framework and realized:

I had been making myself the hero of my brand's story.
But that role belongs to the customer.

The truth is:

Your customers don't care about your journey
They don't care about your values
They don't care about your "why"

(At least not until you solve their problem)

They care about ONE thing:
"Can you help me get what I want?"

This realization changed everything for me.

Your hook is the storefront in a crowded mall.

(And most LinkedIn creators have empty stores)

The hard truth about hooks that nobody wants to admit:

People decide to read your post in 2-3 seconds
(That's literally the time it takes to scroll past)

Your brilliant insights mean nothing with a weak hook
(It's like having amazing products in a store nobody enters)

Clarity beats creativity every single time
(Nobody stops for "clever" - they stop for value)

Problem-focused hooks outperform solution-focused hooks
(Pain is a stronger motivator than pleasure)

Your first line should feel like it's speaking directly to ONE person
(The "that's literally me" effect is powerful)

When your hook works, everything else works.
When your hook fails, nothing else matters.

(This is why the best creators spend more time on hooks than the actual post)

Next time you write, remember: You're not just writing content.
You're designing a storefront that makes people stop scrolling.

Brands building writersâ€™ rooms and entertainment houses has evolved from a bold experiment into a full-blown movement. Whatâ€™s striking is that many of the brands excelling now have been honing their craft for over a year.

The rest are waking up to the fact that, in an oversaturated space, you canâ€™t just depend on the algorithm.

Case in point: the flood of brands turning their logos orange for Taylor Swiftâ€™s new album.

Itâ€™s time for brands to reclaim ownership of their worlds instead of merely renting space on the algorithm.

I was struggling to put the right words behind this phenomena until I stumbled upon â€œThe Etymology Nerdâ€ by Adam Aleksic.

In his most recent article, he explores how our forms of communication have evolved from ritual to transmission. In the ritual view, communication is about shared identity and community, rooted in oral tradition and fellowship. With technology, this shifted toward a transmission view, where the focus became the efficient delivery of information rather than connection.

Thereâ€™s something really powerful about reclaiming that ritual. The first brand to truly do it well will set a new standard. Because when you sacrifice connection for the rush, people inevitably start craving the very thing theyâ€™ve lost.

A lot of people don't realize that witty & whip-smart copy has been at the epicenter of Duolingo's virality for a long time. 

As of right now at Duolingo, we only have one brand copywriter (and now Associate Creative Director) -. He wrote the script for Duolingo's Love Language, Duolingo on Ice and so many of our large brand campaigns.

As we got more budget and buy-in, I wanted to see what would happen if we had a dedicated writer's room of people that...

1) Understood social but had long-form writing experience.
2) Weren't precious about their work.
3) Could move fast & get actual output in the world.
4) Were like Kev. We always need more Kevs. (this is actually my very public confessional about how much I look up to his work)

Thank you to,,, (and so many others) for joining me on this ride.

One of the most terrifying (and exhilarating) parts of working in social is when the internet gives you an opportunity to capitalize on a cultural moment.

With TikTok being banned, we saw a ~216% growth in new Chinese (Mandarin) learners in the US compared to this time last year. And, people were creating UGC about their new found interest for the language.

As one of the most loved brands on TikTok, we knew we wanted to give it one final farewell and this opportunity was just too good.

We approached it in the way we do best: minimal time from ideation to post.

hopped in with a classic Duo sassy tweet and we followed it up with help from our localization teams to teach a very specific lesson. Check it out here:

But, we weren't going to let the fun end on X when it was TikTok that was disappearing.

and I were already on a flight to New York for work, and when we encountered a snow delay, we grabbed our spare masks & decided to film content. With the help of our team from China (<3), we taught some helpful phrases for TikTok Refugees.

Our final farewell to TikTok resulted in over 20M+ impressions, capitalized on a natural moment where people were learning Mandarin, and showed the world one last time that there's always a way to be strategically out of pocket.

See you on YouTube Shorts!

Jamsetji Tata - book now in Hindi !

I am delighted to inform you that the book "Jamsetji Tata - powerful learnings for corporate success" has now been published in Hindi.

This book, co-authored byand me, discusses the essential ideas of Jamsetji Tata, founder of the Tata group and father of modern Indian industry.

Through stimulating essays and engaging stories, the book highlights how and why these ideas have flourished for over 150 years now, and what lessons we can take away into our own companies and careers.

The Hindi translation has been carried out by eminent Hindi journalist and author,. It has taken Dr. Mishra more than 400 hours of work to complete this translation. And I know this has been a labour of love for him.

Why were my co-author and I keen on this Hindi translation? Because less than 10% of India reads in English. Whereas around 45% of India reads in Hindi. And the simple, powerful ideas of this book deserve to be known across our country.

We are also working on translations into other Indian languages. It takes time to ensure that the essence of the book is captured in every language. But we are determined to deliver as many translations as possible.

This Hindi edition can make for a wonderful gift to your parents, relatives, friends, team members, and of course to yourself - to anyone who loves reading in the Hindi language.

I would be delighted if you decide to pick up this book for yourself or gift it. Here is a link on Amazon.

Thank you very much. Wish you a lovely Sunday !

How to chair a meeting

Last week, I had the privilege of being part of the jury for the Hindu Business Line Changemaker awards, at Chennai.

Our jury was chaired by Duvvuri Subbarao, renowned economist and former Governor of the Reserve Bank of India. He is widely credited with steering the Indian economy through the 2008 financial crisis.

At these jury deliberations, however, the lesson I learnt from him was not from the realm of economics. It was about how to effectively chair a meeting.

He provided us a masterclass on this subject.

First, he clearly defined the objective of the discussion at hand.

Second, he requested every member of the jury to state their views, listening intently all the time.

Third, only after having listened to all of us on the jury, did he state his own views.

Fourth, if there was no emerging consensus, he defined the issues that were on the table, posed a couple of key questions around these issues, and encouraged us to respond. This helped clarify and share our thinking.

Finally, he took the considered opinion of all jury members, and enabled us to reach a conclusion, either by consensus or by majority.

In-between these steps, he also encouraged (or perhaps tolerated) the occasional storytelling and humour from some of us, that keeps such serious meetings light and peppy.

And, to top it all, he ensured that we concluded the jury deliberations well in time !

I came away with many learnings - from his disciplined approach, patience, sharp listening skills and his ability to synthesise the issues and thoughts coming up from across the table. Thank you, Mr. Subbarao !

Sometimes, when you watch a master in action, your learnings are far more powerful than from any textbook or classroom. Do you agree?

Look forward to your kind comments. Even a few words is fine. Thanks !

The sheer joy of a favourite food

There are some meals that I simply lust for. One of them is parotta with Chettinad style egg curry (Muttai curry, in Tamil).

So, when I was in Chennai two days ago, I was sort of dreaming of this dinner throughout the day. Pictures of eggs kept appearing in my mind, from time to time.

When my dinner did arrive, it was simply delicious. The egg curry was made with a spicy tomato-onion gravy, flavoured with coconut and dry chilly. The chef had also added a few small onions (shallots), which was a surprise, and gave it a lovely mouthfeel.

The parotta was made in typical Madras style, with a crispy, flaky texture. I asked for one, but the chef gave me two. Because he said that two eggs deserved two parottas. How can you argue with that logic?

Parotta & egg curry is a culinary match made in heaven. Just like idlis & coconut chutney, or appam & stew, or kulcha & chole. Here is a combination that teases your senses, delivers a melange of beautiful flavours and then lulls you into a state of happy satisfaction. That is what any great meal should do.

For all of us who travel often on work, seeking out and eating the best of local food gives us such a well-deserved break between all the long meetings, waiting at airports, lugging bags and wondering about the impact of AI. I believe that we, the nomads of this modern corporate era, owe these small treats to ourselves. Do you agree?

Look forward to your kind comments. Even a few words is fine. Here's hoping that you treat yourself to one of your favourite meals, this weekend !

(Picture below : Parotta & Chettinad style muttai curry, at the Rain Tree Restaurant, Taj Connemara Hotel, Chennai.)

Guru Poornima - respects to R.K. Krishna Kumar

On this auspicious day of Guru Poornima, I would like to pay my respects to a person who has taught me so much in my professional life - late R.K. Krishna Kumar, a veteran of the Tata group.

He was my first boss, when I joined Tata Tea as a young officer, way back in 1988. He was a hard taskmaster, and I have been thrown out of his office several times, because he was dissatisfied with my work. But he was also a very kind and caring person, who took the effort to come all the way from Kolkata to Mangalore to attend my marriage.

Amongst all the lessons I have learnt from him, there are three learnings I have carried with me throughout my life and career -

all the work that you do, aim for excellence. Demand the best from yourself. Only then can you achieve your true potential.

kind and compassionate to the people you work with. Nothing matters more in life.

the right thing. When you do what you think is right as per your conscience, you lead a truly good life and you can also sleep well at night.

Guru Poornima greetings to you, Sir. I miss you every single day.

17. Be Kind

This week, take a few minutes to be kind to someone.

Be kind to someone who is struggling with a project, or who is going through a tough professional or personal patch. Take a few minutes to listen to them.

Call a team member who needs an emotional lift-up, and tell them how proud you are of the work they have done recently.

Or reach out to a colleague who is recovering from an illness and speak to them about their day.

Kindness is not just a good act towards others. It also helps us, because when we engage in an act of kindness, we become happier. And when we are happier, we are more creative, and more productive.

This is what I have learnt during my working life, over the past four decades. Let me know what you think.

Look forward to your kind comments. Even a few words is fine. Thank you and wish you a lovely week ahead !

Japanese cake

I spent a few years of my early school life in Coimbatore. My Mother would sometimes take me to a wonderful bakery at Dewan Bahadur Road in R.S. Puram, where I would drool at all the cakes through the glass windows. The cake I would long for the most was the Japanese cake. But I also knew that it was quite expensive.

Sometimes, on special days (eg. after the last day of the final exams), she would buy one or two pieces of Japanese cakes for us, as a treat. We would take them home and cut them up. My grandmother, parents, sister and I would then eat these lovely cakes with great relish, licking the sweet butter that was layered within them.

After I grew up and began working, I have eaten many splendid cakes, from famous bakeries - La Patisserie of the Taj, or Theobroma in Mumbai and Bangalore. I have not kept count, but I must have eaten atleast 200 different varieties of rich cakes during my life.

But always, in my mind, the Japanese cake has remained the most special treat. Because it was the cake that my Mother rewarded us with on special days.

So, recently, when I was visiting Coimbatore, I found the Japanese cakes once again in that very same bakery. All those beautiful memories of childhood came right back into my mind.

I wished my Mother were here by my side, to buy me these cakes once again - but she was at home in Bangalore. I wished my grandmother was still alive, to eat them along with me. I wished I were a carefree school boy once again, having completed the last day of my exams.

I stared at these cakes for a long time, quite wistfully. More than once, I nearly asked the bakery guy to pack a few for me. But finally, I walked out of that bakery without buying them.

Because these cakes were my Mother's special treat for me, a symbol of her love and affection for her child. How could I buy them for myself?

43. Re-skilling lessons

In a remarkable turn of events, our neighbourhood tailor in Bangalore has very recently begun a new line of business - making and selling South Indian snacks such as butter murukku and lace pakodas.

This bespoke tailor has been stitching garments for my wife for over 20 years. But now, her snacks are delicious. We have been eating them for the past few days as if we have never eaten murukkus ever before.

There are different interpretations of this unexpected move by our tailor.

I pointed out (mainly so that I look clever to my wife) that this diversification is a clear example that lots of re-skilling can still happen without any AI. Natural hunger beats artificial intelligence, any day.

I also highlighted (using my MBA analytical skills) that perhaps there is deeper business strategy at work here. Maybe eating all these fried snacks will soon lead to our requiring many more new tailored clothes.

My wife pointed out that if a tailor can learn how to make snacks, then a semi-retired marketer can learn how to use the washing machine at home.

I like to be direct in these matters, so I asked her whether she was referring to me. She said that the guilty always know.

I resumed eating the snacks made by our tailor, and offered some to my wife as well.

But I know that my task for the weekend has been well defined. It is quite remarkable how any thread of conversation with my wife generally ends up in the same place - which is, a new task for me.

Look forward to your kind comments. Wish you a lovely weekend !

Reflections in a hospital room

My 89-year old Mother was hospitalised for four days. She received excellent treatment, was discharged yesterday and is now back home to her own room and bed.

Sitting in her room at a small hospital in Bangalore, I reflected on the following points.

1. I am grateful that I have the ability to access good private healthcare in India. This has happened because my parents invested in providing me excellent education - which in turn gave me a good job and career at the Tata group, and enabled me to build some financial security for my family. Good education gives us the wings to fly, and enables us to build our nests for the future.

2. The Doctors and nursing staff at this hospital were extraordinary. They were so dedicated, responsive and caring. They treated my Mother like their own. There was a sense of ownership and responsibility which is rare to see in these modern times. The diagnosis was thoughtful, and the treatment was sharply tailored. To all of them, and to all medical professionals, I am grateful for the efforts they invest in patient care. Good Doctors and nursing staff are the lifeline of our world. We don't appreciate them enough.

3. When a medical emergency happens, it takes over everything else in our lives. For my wife and me, the rest of our world came to a pause for four days, while we ran between home and hospital and home. Health of our family members, and our own health, determines so much of the trajectories of our lives. Health is the most important investment we can ever make.

It was lovely to see the smile on my Mother's face when she returned home. All my other reflections stopped at that point. When our parents are healthy and happy, that means the world to us.

I would like to dedicate this post to all the Doctors and Nurses who spend their entire professional lives ensuring the good health of everyone who comes into their care. We owe so much to you. Thank you.

I was at the Builder's Summit by Founder's Connect today and while there were a lot of great conversations, one fireside chat really stuck with me.

It was anchored byof ReneÃ© PR and featuredof Big Cabal Media. The topic was The Media Advantage: How Perception Shapes Growth for both Founders and Talents.

For me, it wasnâ€™t your typical event talk, it was a reminder that how we tell our stories matters, and it often starts closer to home than we think.

A few things he said wouldn't be leaving me in a hurry. One was you donâ€™t need to be in big publications to be visible. Start where you are. At work, in your communities, in your group chats. Thatâ€™s where real visibility begins. Word of mouth still matters. Donâ€™t be shy about what youâ€™re working on. Talk to everyone who cares to listen. One added advantage is that your idea actually gets sharper the more you speak about it.

Peer-to-peer networks are also underrated. We spend so much time chasing â€œtop peopleâ€ when the real growth often comes from building with those on our level. And then thereâ€™s storytelling. I can't stress its importance enough. Tomiwa is big on design because design helps bring a story to life. Whether itâ€™s your pitch deck, your website, or even a tweet, how you present what you're building makes a difference.

He also shared some truths about getting media attention.

First, lead with substance. A lot of people get caught up in chasing visibility too early. But if what youâ€™re building isnâ€™t grounded in something real, the spotlight wonâ€™t do much for you.

Second, keep people in the loop. Donâ€™t wait until youâ€™ve hit a major milestone to talk about what youâ€™re doing. Share your process. Let people see the journey.

And then, build relationships with the media the same way you would with collaborators or friends. If you meet a journalist who covers your space, donâ€™t just reach out when you need a story. Stay in touch. Check in. Share what youâ€™re working on from time to time.

To sign off, shoutout toand the entire team for creating a space where these conversations can happen. I left with a lot to think about and even more to build on.ğŸ¤ğŸ¾

People donâ€™t choose whatâ€™s best.

And value is rarely objective. Itâ€™s psychological.

Whether someone is buying a product, following a personal brand, or signing up for a newsletter, theyâ€™re asking: â€“ Does this improve my life?
â€“ Does it solve a real problem?
â€“ Is it different in a way that matters?
â€“ Do I trust it?
â€“ Is it clear what Iâ€™ll get?

If youâ€™re a founder, creator, or operator, your job isnâ€™t just to build something good. Itâ€™s to make the value unmistakable.

Three years ago, Founders Connect hosted its first live event; a simple experiment in bringing online energy into a physical room. Since then, weâ€™ve run events across four cities, each one a reminder that community isnâ€™t static; it grows, shifts, and asks more of you.
