Nobody prepares for success.
Weâ€™re told to plan for failure. Have a backup plan. Stay cautious. But what if things actually go right?

Whenand I started our company, our first goal was $60,000 a year, just enough to pay ourselves $30K each. We were working out of his living room, eating cheap takeout, and chasing freedom.

That felt like success.

I remember telling my dad about the plan, expecting him to be excited. He was. But then he said something Iâ€™ll never forget:

â€œMake sure you prepare for success.â€

At the time, I didnâ€™t get it. We were just hoping it would work. But he was right.
Most of us never think about what comes after the breakthrough. We focus so much on surviving that we forget to ask: What happens when things take off?

If your idea works...
+ Are you ready to hire and lead people?

+ Do your values scale with your business?

The truth is: success brings its own set of problems.

So hereâ€™s my advice if youâ€™re building something:
âœ… Prepare for failure.
âœ… But also: prepare for success.

Because if things go right, youâ€™ll be living with those decisions for a long time.

And youâ€™ll want to be proud of how you got there.

This weekâ€™s newsletter is about accessibility, inclusion, and why doing the right thing is the smart thing:

Curious, how do you break the cycle and make space for the stuff that really matters?

I used to obsess over web traffic. All of us did.

But aspointed out in the latest episode of Talking Too Loud, weâ€™re not playing that game anymore.

Was just scrolling through Wistia's Slack when I saw a video I didn't know existed.

Real growth starts as a whisper.

Everyone wants the big launch. The viral moment. The instant win.

But most of the time, growth doesnâ€™t look like a rocket ship. Itâ€™s quiet. Itâ€™s steady. Itâ€™s one foot in front of the other.

Adam Robinson replaced his sales reps with an AI clone of himself.

Not hypothetically.

In just 22 days it handled:
1,600+ conversations
304 demo requests
98 SOC 2 requests
16 pricing conversations

And 70% of people said it was a positive experience.

Hereâ€™s the kicker:
The numbers didnâ€™t really change compared to when humans were handling those conversations.

Adamâ€™s takeaway?

Documentation is everything.
The AI only works because the company has clear, detailed answers to common questions.

So hereâ€™s the question for you:

If an AI avatar can replace two sales-assist reps without any dip in performanceâ€¦
is that the future of sales?

Would you trust an AI â€œrepâ€ to run your first conversations with prospects?

The difference between convincing and understanding when responding to objections. 

Prospect: â€œSend me some information.â€

Convincing sounds like this:
â€œGoing to be honest with you, my biggest fear (besides snakes) is sending an email and never hearing back. Would you be opposed to setting 15 minutes later this week to continue the conversation?â€

Convincing creates pressure.

The subtext is: I donâ€™t trust youâ€™ll come back, so I need to secure control right now.

Humans sense that agenda immediately.

They can smell you commission breath.

Pressure activates resistance.

Understanding sounds like this:
Early in the call:
â€œSo I donâ€™t do you a disservice by sending irrelevant info, would it be okay if I asked a couple questions?â€

Later in the call:
â€œSure. Whatâ€™s your email? What type of info would you like?â€

Understanding creates safety.

The subtext is: I hear you, I respect your request, and I trust you to decide.

When people feel understood rather than managed, their defenses lower.

Convincing is rooted in yourself.
Understanding is rooted others

And buyers can feel the difference.

The sting in sales is inevitable.

The hang-up.
The ghost.
The no-show.

Thatâ€™s the first arrow.

The second arrow is what you fire at yourself,
replaying it, questioning your worth, assuming the next call will fail.

The first arrow is unavoidable.
The second arrow is optional.

Freedom in sales isnâ€™t found in dodging the sting.
Itâ€™s in dropping the suffering that follows.

The first arrow is inevitable.
The second arrow isnâ€™t.
This salesperson immediately lowered by guard wth two words.

Itâ€™s not your job to convince people.

Your job is to make people pause and say:
â€œHuhâ€¦ thatâ€™s a good question.â€

Here are 4 poke-the-bear question frameworks (with examples):

1. How do you currentlyâ€¦
â€œI often hear that onboarding new employees means juggling 4â€“5 different tools. How are you currently adding new hires to payroll, benefits, and software when they join?â€

2. Have you found a way toâ€¦
â€œHave you found a way to keep your Airbnb and direct bookings from stepping on each other?â€

3. Youâ€™ve probablyâ€¦
â€œYouâ€™ve probably got a good filter in place so those AI resumes and cover letters donâ€™t flood your ATS.â€

4. Iâ€™m guessingâ€¦
â€œA lot of SaaS apps end up underutilized or unused. Normal with fast growth, different teams grab tools, and not all of them stick long term. Iâ€™m guessing you know which licenses are being used and which are just sitting idle.â€

The psychology:

When you pitch, prospects brace for impact.
Their ego flares up, and they defend the status quo.

When you poke, you bypass ego.
You shine a light on a potential blind spot with a neutral question.

People donâ€™t like being told whatâ€™s wrong.
But they love correcting, clarifying, and proving theyâ€™ve thought about something.

Stop pitching.
Start poking.

I donâ€™t like to â€œchallengeâ€ prospects.

Challenging sounds like this:

â€œIâ€™ve been in the coffee business for 23 years, and based on what weâ€™re seeing, 98% of setups arenâ€™t sanitary enough to meet standards.â€

Sounds like a Ted Talk lecture, right?

And the problem with lectures is ego.

When people feel challenged, their defenses go up.

They protect their pride instead of opening their mind.

Thatâ€™s why I prefer to poke the bear.

Not telling.
Asking.

Questions that make people pause and look at their current approach in a new light.

Poking sounds like this:

â€œCoffee machines have lots of little spots where bacteria like E. coli, staph, and strep can grow, the spout, water tank, K-cup slot, and drip tray especially. How do you usually keep yours clean?â€

Notice the difference?
No ego triggered.
No lecture given.

Just a neutral question that surfaces a potential problem and gets the prospect reflecting.

Thatâ€™s the power of poking.
It doesnâ€™t push people to defend.
It invites them to explore.

People donâ€™t resists change.
They resist being changed.

Buyers have the answers.
Sellers have the questions.

I got a biopsy.

Now I wait nine days for the results.

The hard part isnâ€™t the procedure.
Itâ€™s the waiting.
The racing mind.

What if itâ€™s cancer?
What does this mean?
What if, what if, what ifâ€¦

I read a stat online that our minds drift from the present most of the time caught in loops, often negative and repetitive.

The brain doesnâ€™t know the difference between whatâ€™s imagined and whatâ€™s real, so we suffer the story before it even happens.

Same stories.
Same feelings.

When you notice the program running, ask yourself:

At this very moment, is there a problem?

Who is putting these thoughts in my head?
Youâ€™ll find thereâ€™s no source.
Thoughts just appear.
Like clouds, they come and go.

Buddhism speaks of two arrows.
The first arrow is what happens.
The second arrow is the story we tell about what happens.

You cannot avoid the first arrow.
But you can notice when youâ€™re firing the second.

So thatâ€™s the practice.
When the mind spins out, bring it back.
Feel your feet on the floor.
Play some guitar.
Go for a walk and pay attention to what you see and hear.

Nine days feels long if I live them in my head.
But not so long if I live them as they come.

The results will arrive when they arrive.
Between now and then, life is here.
And I donâ€™t want to miss it.

Right now there is no problem.

Every day buyers get hit with cold emails that confuse.

Take this one I got yesterday:

â€œHereâ€™s who we are: Platform chosen by 50,000+ TELUS users for enterprise AI transformation, backed by TELUS Digital, proven enterprise partner, not startup risk.â€

Backed by TELUS Digital?

The better way?

Does that sound like something youâ€™d say to a friend over coffee?

Instead of â€œplatform for enterprise AI transformation,â€
say:

â€œWe help companies automate repetitive support tickets so customers get answers in minutes instead of days.â€

Now the person actually knows what you do.

Clarity isnâ€™t optional.
It is the price of admission.

The first rule of LinkedIn:

If youâ€™re scraping youâ€™re doing it wrong. 

Scraping LinkedIn is like shoplifting from a store that has cameras in every aisle.

My take?

Here's a breakdown of a good cold email.

Blue. Relevance: It opens with something specific about the prospect (fleet size and telematics use). Answers the question, â€œWhy are you emailing me?â€

Green. Poke the bear question: â€œHow are you using that data to make sure youâ€™re not overpaying?â€ doesnâ€™t push. It invites. It opens a loop.

Yellow. Knowledge gap: It introduces a potential blind spot (lack of tax granularity) the prospect might not be thinking about. It's specific or "crispy" which make it relatable.

Orange. Social proof: 2,000+ fleets and a $10M result. Specific, credible, and not overhyped.

Pink. Preemptively addresses the objection: Speaks directly to the most common pushback: Weâ€™re already doing this. Instead of ignoring it, the line validates their setup and gently introduces doubt.

Grey. Low-pressure ask: â€œNo rushâ€ lowers defenses. It doesnâ€™t beg. It respects their time and space.

Yes, you can steal the template, but itâ€™s the underlying psychology that will help you apply it to your prospects.

I avoid negative people.

Not because theyâ€™re bad. 

But because their energy seeps into mine.

Itâ€™s like sitting next to a fire, eventually, you smell like smoke.

The constant complaining.

The reflex to point out what wonâ€™t work.

The heavy sighs that linger in the air.

Negativity narrows the mind. Optimism opens it.

So I choose to walk with people who expand rather than shrink.

Not blind to problems, but not consumed by them either.

Because the energy you surround yourself with becomes the energy you carry.

Sales 1.0 vs. Sales 2.0

Sales 1.0 is rooted in persuading.
Stacking benefits.
Overcoming objections.
Pushing people toward a yes.

It sounds like this:
â€œPractices that donâ€™t track new patient conversion are leaving money on the table. You need to measure this metric to grow.â€

Convincing.
Directive.
Biased.
And it triggers resistance because no one likes being told what to do.

Sales 2.0 is different.
Itâ€™s about illuminating.
Poking the bear with a question that exposes a blind spot.

It sounds like this:
â€œMost practices track case acceptance but not new patient conversion, how many callers actually book and show up. If thatâ€™s 50%, 10 calls only become 5 patients. How closely are you tracking that?â€

Notice the shift.
Sales 1.0 tells.
Sales 2.0 asks.

Psychologically, Sales 2.0 works better because:

It lowers defenses (no push).

It sparks curiosity (they think, not resist).

It preserves autonomy (the insight feels like theirs).

Sales 1.0 pressures.
Sales 2.0 provokes reflection.

And the truth someone discovers on their own will always be more powerful than the one you try to push on them.

Buyers have the answers.
Sellers have the questions.

Letâ€™s see if I can make you aware of a problem you might not know about.

(A good skill to master if youâ€™re in sales doing outbound.)

This is only for people who use gel nail polish.

If thatâ€™s not you, keep scrolling.

Okay, here we goâ€¦

The American Academy of Dermatology just released a statement that a key ingredient in most gel nail polishes is now banned in Europe.

The chemical is TPO (Triphenylphosphine Oxide). Itâ€™s classified as a reproductive toxicant which means it can impair fertility or harm an unborn child.

Now hereâ€™s the kickerâ€¦ itâ€™s still legal in the U.S.

So, does your gel polish contain TPO?

And scene.

See what I did there?

I didnâ€™t pitch. I didnâ€™t sell.

I just made you stop and think about a hidden risk in something you thought was safe.

Thatâ€™s the heart of good outbound: not pushing, not persuading, but revealing a problem prospects didnâ€™t realize they had, so they lean in.

To be a better closer, be a better opener.

And by asking â€œDoes that sound right to you?â€ youâ€™re giving them autonomy People rarely push back when theyâ€™re given the role of guide.

What do you think?

Do the â€œextreme survivalâ€ keynotes inspire you or do you prefer speakers who help you do your job better?

A champion leaves. A competitor undercuts your price. Legal delays the contract.

Most reps treat these as surprises. But the gangster reps already saw them coming.

If you don't do this already, you should consider running "what-if" scenarios like you're a chess master.


Here's how to approach it:


1. What if your champion leaves?


Before it happens:

- Map the full buying committee and build relationships across functions.
- Ask your champion: "If you weren't here tomorrow, who would drive this decision forward?"
- Document their specific language and priorities so you can replicate their influence.


When it does happen:

- Leverage the departed champion's credibility: "Sarah specifically mentioned this would solve your Q4 capacity issues."
- Pivot to the technical buyer: "Sarah felt strongly that your engineering team needed to own the integration timeline."
- Use internal references: "Sarah connected me with your VP of Operations because she knew he'd appreciate the automation benefits."



2. What if a competitor slashes pricing?


Never compete on cost alone:

- Pre-build ROI models showing 18-month payback vs. competitors' 36-month timeline.
- Emphasize switching costs: "Moving from your current system will require 6 weeks of developer time. Our API integration takes 3 days."
- Document proof points competitors can't match: "We're the only solution that integrates natively with Salesforce AND HubSpot."


Build your "Why We Win" document with:

- Specific customer success stories in their vertical.
- Technical capabilities that require no workarounds.
- Implementation timelines that beat industry standards.
- Support SLAs that competitors don't offer.



3. What if a deal stalls in legal?


Get ahead of contract negotiations:

- Ask upfront: "What contract terms typically slow down your legal reviews?"
- Bring your own legal counsel to prospect meetings: "Our legal team can address any redlines in real-time."
- Provide template MSAs: "Here's our standard agreement. Your legal team can review this while we finalize technical requirements."


Anticipate common sticking points:

- Data processing agreements for compliance-sensitive industries.
- Liability caps that match the customer's risk tolerance.
- Termination clauses that protect both parties.
- Service level guarantees that legal teams actually approve.



4. What if the budget gets cut?


Build multiple buying scenarios:

- Phase 1 implementation that shows immediate ROI.
- Pilot programs that prove value before full rollout.
- Consumption-based pricing that scales with usage.
- Multi-year agreements with lower annual commitments.


Prepare budget defense talking points:

- "This pays for itself in 8 months through automation savings."
- "Delaying costs you $50K per month in manual processes."
- "The pilot requires zero upfront investment."



Don't just forecast what will close.

Forecast what could go wrong - and how to fix it before it breaks.

Too many reps act like order takers. Buyer asks for a discount? They jump. Buyer asks for another call? They set it up immediately.

One thing to consider: Make every request a trade.

- â€œWe can discuss pricing adjustments...if we loop in your CFO.â€
- â€œI can extend the trial...but can we get IT on a call to confirm next steps?â€
- â€œHappy to send case studies...can you introduce me to another key stakeholder?â€

The moment you start treating deals as mutual agreements - not one-sided requests - youâ€™ll see faster closes and stronger commitments.

Every sales leader obsesses over the same metric: "How do we shorten our sales cycle?" 90-day cycles become 60-day cycles. 60-day cycles become 30-day cycles. Everyone celebrates the "velocity improvement."

6 months later, average deal size has dropped 40% and customer churn is through the roof. ğŸ•º


Folks, sales velocity ain't about speed as much as its about removing friction from the buying process.

Speed-obsessed teams end up creating ARTIFICIAL (read: bullshit) urgency:

- Discount deadlines that train customers to wait for sales.
- Pressure tactics that make buyers uncomfortable.
- Rushed discovery that misses critical requirements.
- Demo-heavy processes that skip proper qualification.

The result is often faster cycles filled with smaller, lower-quality deals that churn faster than you can replace them.


It might make sense to kinda flip this on its head and focus on doing the opposite:

- Slow down discovery to understand the real problem.
- Involve more stakeholders early to prevent surprises later.
- Build business cases that justify larger investments.
- Design onboarding that ensures customer success.


In general, SMB deals average 60-90 days while ENT deals take 6+ months, but ENT deals are typically 5-50x larger in value.

Also, per some fancy research from SBI, a sales approach that focused on "pushing" prospects through faster cycles actually increased sales cycle times, while approaches that "pulled" buyer context shortened cycles.


This obsession with velocity creates a bunch of problems.

First, you start measuring activity instead of outcomes. Reps optimize for moving deals through stages instead of moving customers toward decisions.

Second, you sacrifice deal quality for cycle speed. The fastest deals are often the worst deals.


So, what should you optimize for instead?

Friction reduction:

- How many unnecessary steps can you remove?
- Where do deals stall most often, and why?
- What information do buyers need to make confident decisions?
- Which stakeholders need to be involved from the beginning?


Here are the metrics you'd wanna look at:

- ACV trends.
- Customer satisfaction at 90 days.
- Expansion revenue rates by cohort.
- Churn rates by sales cycle length.


The companies with the best "velocity" often have the longest sales cycles in their category.

They build relationships that lead to bigger deals. They involve stakeholders who prevent implementation failures. They create urgency around business outcomes, not arbitrary deadlines.

Some deals SHOULD take 6 months. Trying to compress a 6-month decision into 60 days is asking for trouble.


Remember: a 180-day cycle that closes a $500K deal with 95% retention is infinitely better than a 60-day cycle that closes a $150K deal with 60% churn, right?

Velocity isn't necessarily about how fast you close deals but it SHOULD be about how efficiently you close the right deals.

Your biggest competitor isn't listed on G2. Why? Well, because it's usually the objection you never heard.

Even with that said, most reps avoid conflict like the plague. They smooth over disagreements, sidestep tough questions, and pray the buying committee magically finds consensus while they're crafting follow-up emails.


Meanwhile, the real dealbreakers are festering in Slack channels and hallway conversations you'll never access.


Asstressed duringâ€™s session last week on Multithreading, your job isn't preventing disagreement. It's dragging it into daylight before it assassinates your deal in the dark.


Think about it...that objection exists whether you surface it or not. Better to fight it when you're in the room than watch it kill your forecast when you're not.


Here are some uncomfortable questions you definitely should start asking:

- "Who's most likely to push back on this approach?"
- "What concerns do you have about moving forward?"
- "If someone wanted to poke holes in this plan, what would they target?"
- "When your leadership debates this issue, what does that sound like?"


This stuff is critical since objections don't disappear when you ignore them. They multiply like bacteria in a petri dish. The person most likely to torpedo your deal is the one you're not talking to.

And buyers actually respect sellers who acknowledge the elephant stomping around the boardroom.


Wanna know the gangster question that's saved more deals than every discount combined? It's this:

"Is there anyone on your team you're worried about when it comes to getting this approved?"

Because here's what happens when you don't ask:

- Week 8: "Everything looks great, we're just waiting on final approvals."
- Week 12: "There are some concerns from IT about security protocols."
- Week 16: "We've decided to table this until next quarter."

The IT concern existed in Week 1. You just never excavated it.


Disagreement is intelligence, not resistance. The person pushing back is showing you exactly what needs proving.

Conflict means engagement. Silent buyers are the dangerous ones who smile through demos then ghost you for three weeks.

Early objections beat late surprises every single time.

Everyone sends the same post-meeting email. Bullet points. Action items. "Thanks for your time." Delete. Here's one idea that came out of a recent AE Peer Group here at:

Turn your notes into a 30-second video summary instead.

AI-generated slideshow with voiceover that hits the key points visually. Your champion can forward a video to their boss easier than a wall of bullet points.


Here's the walkthrough

1. Export your meeting notes fromor whatever you use.


2. Feed the transcript into an AI video tool.

Add this prompt: "Create a 30-second slideshow summarizing our discovery call with [company]. Include 3-4 key slides covering their main challenges, our proposed solution, and next steps."


3. Add their company logo to slides. Reference specific stakeholders by name.

Include one data point that matters to their business: "This could save you $200K annually based on your team size."


4. Track who actually watches. Most AI video tools show engagement data. You'll know exactly who watched what percentage.

Try getting that insight from your text email.


5. Follow up based on viewing behavior. Watched 85%? They're engaged. Schedule the next call immediately.

Watched 20%? Wrong message or wrong audience. Dig deeper on needs.

Didn't watch? They want text, not video. Adjust your approach.


IMO here's when it makes sense to invest the 5-10 mins to do this:

- ENT deals worth $50K+.
- Multi-stakeholder discovery calls.
- When you need internal selling to happen.
- Deals where your champion needs to brief their boss.


When to skip it:

- Routine check-ins.
- Low-value transactions.
- Contacts who clearly prefer text communication.


Here are some AI video tools to try: Synthesia, Loom AI, or Pictory.


Meeting notes are commoditized. Everyone sends them. Few read them.

Video summaries force attention and create advocates.

Might be worth a shot.

Your hiring plan was built in Q4. Your job descriptions were copied from 2023. Your interview process tests for skills that worked when budgets were easy.

Meanwhile, your buyers have fundamentally changed how they evaluate, approve, and implement new solutions.

Guess who's going to miss their number?


Most sales hiring is ass backwards. You hire for the market you just figured out, not the market you're ABOUT to face.

The result is that there's a yuge lag problem, and your hiring insights are stale before the first interview.

By the time you identify what "good" looks like, translate it into job requirements, source candidates, and complete interviews, the market has shifted.

Which means that you're solving yesterday's problems with tomorrow's hires.


Consider stuff that changed while you were hiring:

1. Buyer committee expansion.

- Last year: 3-4 decision makers.
- This year: 6-8 stakeholders involved in every deal.

Are your reps still pitching to champions instead of orchestrating committee consensus?


2. Budget scrutiny intensification.

- Last year: ROI models were nice-to-have.
- This year: CFO approval is standard for $25K+ deals.

Are they still leading with features instead of financial impact?


3. Implementation risk paranoia.

- Last year: "Will this work?"
- This year: "What if this fails?"

They still selling transformation instead of de-risking change?


4. Competitive displacement acceleration.

- Last year: Buyers compared 2-3 options.
- This year: Buyers evaluate 5+ alternatives including "do nothing."

Is your team still assuming they're in two-horse races?


This all culminates in the skill gaps folks didn't see coming.

Your current team might excel at:

- Building champion relationships.
- Delivering compelling demos.
- Handling price objections.
- Managing traditional sales cycles.


But your current market REQUIRES:

- Multi-stakeholder orchestration.
- Financial business case development.
- Change management consultation.
- Complex procurement navigation.


So, what types of folks should you be looking for now? IMO a few things:


1. Committee sellers, not champion builders.

Can they map buying committees? Do they speak to multiple personas in one conversation? Can they create alignment across conflicting priorities?


2. Folks who prioritize business acumen over product knowledge.

Can they model ROI scenarios? Do they understand cash flow impact? Can they speak CFO language when needed?


3. Test for consultative patience, not closing urgency.

Will they slow down to speed up? Can they navigate 9-month sales cycles without panicking? Do they add value in every interaction, not just closing conversations?


The reps who dominated 2023 might struggle in 2025.

Not because they're bad reps. Because they're optimized for a market that doesn't exist anymore.

Keep in mind that your competition isn't just other vendors, but it's also other sales teams who figured this out first.

While this was our 12th dinner this year, it was only our first stop in Denver thus far in 2025.

Looking ahead to 2026 and beyond, we'll definitely have to change that and visit here more frequently.

Not only did we have the illustrious Jen who made the trip from Chicago with me to break down why you most definitely DO NOT want to outsource AI for your most critical client-facing tasks, but - as with all of our dinners - the leaders in the room had the chance to connect and collaborate with each other on topics such as:

- How to diagnose whether underperformance is a will problem or skill problem (and what to do about each).

- Outbound strategies that still cut through the noise when everyone's inbox is drowning in AI-generated sequences.

- Comp plan redesigns that reward collaboration instead of account hoarding.

- The difference between sales coaching and sales inspection (most leaders confuse the two).

- Which AI tools are actually improving rep productivity versus just adding more noise.


Layered it on top of all back, of course, were much more important conversations about family, travel, and just getting to know each other better as individuals.

Plus, there was the inevitable debate about whether altitude affects close rates. The jury's still out on that one.


Sure, Denver's got legal weed and 300 days of sunshine. But last night reminded me it's also got some of the sharpest GTM minds in the country.

We'll be back more than once in 2026. Thatâ€™s something Denver can bank on.


What a great evening with some of the best (and nicest) people in the business!

It's August in Europe. Your prospects are sipping Aperol Spritzes (ğŸ¤®) on the Amalfi Coast while you're staring at a CRM full of OOO autoreplies.
But you still have a quota.


Ahhhhh summer in EMEA: Everyone important is gone for 3-6 weeks, but your number doesn't take vacation!


Most reps fall into the trap of doing one of two things:

1. Give up and blame the calendar.
2. Blast emails into the void hoping someone's checking from the beach.

This is not the way, folks. Try building in a bit of creativity.


A few ideas pulled from a recent BDR/SDR Peer Group we host monthly here at:


1. The iced latte play.

One London SDR sends Starbucks vouchers with the subject line: "For when you're back from holiday."

Response rate: 47%. Why? It acknowledges reality (they're gone) while creating a future obligation (they owe you a response for the coffee).


2. The instant reaction strategy.

Set up alerts for ANY digital engagement. LinkedIn profile view at 11pm? They're back and catching up. Email open at 6am? They're clearing the backlog.

Strike within 5 minutes while they're still in work mode.


3. The orchid office move.

SDR noticed a beauty company just moved offices (all female team). Sent an orchid with a note about "brightening up the new space."

Got the meeting. The gift matched the audience - it wasnâ€™t just a box of donuts or some generic nonsense.


If you are a newer rep responsible for selling into EMEA, it's really critical to understand European work culture. We send "URGENT - Please respond" emails to people who've been legally REQUIRED to disconnect for three weeks.

We look desperate. They look relaxed.


Despite whatever wishcasting we may wanna try, here's what's happening:

- July: 40% of decision makers gone.
- August: 60% gone.
- September first week: Everyone's catching up.
- Actual selling window: 10 days in September.


But here's the thingâ€¦this is actually the BEST time to build pipeline.

Why? Because your competitors gave up.


While they're complaining about response rates, you're:

- Researching accounts deeply (they're not answering anyway).
- Crafting personalized outreach for September.
- Building relationships with the junior people still in office.
- Setting up September meetings now (they're booking calendars while poolside).


One of the reps in our Peer Group said it best:

"I'm not trying to sell anything in August. I'm trying to be the first email they're excited to respond to in September."

THIS is the way.


Stop fighting European summer culture.

Your prospects will be back, tanned and relaxed. And if you played it right, you'll be the vendor they actually want to talk to.

Because you respected their vacation instead of ruining it.


PS - yes I do realize that it is not only August in Europe, but it is August everywhere. But you get my pointâ€¦

First question: You get politeness. Second question: You get the surface. Third question: You get the truth.

Watch how this plays out:

Q1: "What made you look for a new solution?"
A1: "We're growing and need to scale."

Generic. Safe. Meaningless.


Q2: "Tell me more about that growth...what's breaking?"
A2: "Our current system can't handle the volume."

Getting warmer. Still corporate junk.


Q3: "What happens if you can't handle that volume?"
A3: "Honestly? My boss said if we have another meltdown like Q4, heads will roll. Starting with mine."

THERE it is. The truth.


But 87% of reps never make it to question three. They hear "need to scale" and launch into their pitch about scalability.

Meanwhile, the real pain - career risk - stays hidden.


If you think back across ALLLLLL your calls, you'll likely notice that the pattern is universal:

- Level 1: Corporate platitudes
- Level 2: Functional challenges
- Level 3: Personal consequences

Yet most discovery stops at Level 1.


"We need better analytics" becomes "Our board is questioning every decision" becomes "I look incompetent in every Monday review."


"We're exploring options" becomes "Our current vendor failed us" becomes "I personally championed them and now my credibility is shot."


"We want to modernize" becomes "Our competition is eating our lunch" becomes "I'm interviewing at three companies because this place is sinking."


laid this out last week during a session he led for us, and the formula he broke down is super simple:

- Ask what (the situation).
- Ask how (the impact).
- Ask what happens if (the consequence).

That third question is where desperation lives. And DESPERATION drives decisions.


Your prospect isn't buying software to "scale" or "modernize" or "transform."

They're buying career insurance. They're buying Monday morning peace. They're buying the ability to sleep without checking Slack at 2am.


But you'll never know that if you stop at question two.


Here's the tell: When someone gives you a corporate answer, they're still protecting themselves. When they start using "I" instead of "we," you've hit truth.

- "We need better reporting" vs "I can't answer my CEO's questions"
- "We have process issues" vs "I spend weekends cleaning up data"
- "We're evaluating vendors" vs "I'm desperate for something that works"

Three questions. That's literally all it takes.

Most reps are so eager to pitch, they never get to the pain.

The truth lives at Level 3.

Most reps die at Level 1.

Dig deeper. The commission is in the consequences, not the capabilities.

Your biggest champions never refer you.
Your smallest customers generate most referrals.
You're asking the wrong people. :)

It's perfectly natural to source referrals from the marquee names you work with. That said, it's important to realize that ENT buyers can't afford to be wrong about referrals. Their reputation is on the line with every introduction they make.

Small business owners? They love sharing what works.


ENT champions think:

- "What if this vendor screws up their implementation?"
- "What if their product doesn't scale like ours did?"
- "What if the CEO traces a bad experience back to my recommendation?"


SMB champions think: "This tool saved my ass. Maybe it'll save theirs too."

I know which one I'd prefer to hear.


Hubspot did a bunch of research last year that said small businesses are 3x more likely to provide referrals than ENT accounts, despite representing smaller individual deal values.


Even with that data being out there, most revenue teams optimize referral programs for their largest customers because they mistake deal size for referral potential.

But referral behavior isn't about deal value. It's about personal risk tolerance and relationship dynamics.

ENT buyers operate in political environments where a bad vendor recommendation can damage their career trajectory. They're conservative by necessity.

SMB buyers operate in survival mode where sharing resources that work is part of the community fabric. They're generous by nature.


So, instead of chasing big name drops, try to build referral systems around behavioral psychology:


1. Segment referral strategies by risk profile.

ENT: Peer introductions at industry events, executive advisory boards.
SMB: Direct warm intros, case study participation, online reviews.


2. Design referral timing around confidence curves.

ENT: After 12+ months of proven ROI and executive-level success metrics.
SMB: After first quick win or measurable outcome (often 30-90 days).


3. Match referral incentives to motivations.

ENT: Thought leadership opportunities, exclusive access, strategic value.
SMB: Cash rewards, public recognition, reciprocal introductions.


4. Create referral-safe environments.

ENT: Private peer groups where sharing vendor intel feels strategic.
SMB: Open communities where success stories get celebrated.


SMB referrals also move faster through decision cycles. ENT referrals can take 6-18 months to convert. SMB referrals convert in weeks.


At the end of the day, your ENT logos might impress prospects, but your SMB advocates create pipeline velocity.

Stop overlooking your smallest customers. They might be your biggest growth engine.

Your CSM is drowning in hundreds of accounts while your CEO wonders why churn is climbing.

Let's break this down a tad:

- Most CSMs are juggling 50-500 customer accounts.
- Industry data shows 33% manage 10-25 accounts, but many handle far more.
- Impossible to meaningfully engage all of them.
- Yet Iâ€™d wager that most have no prioritization system.


Seems a bit more like customer roulette than customer success, right?


When you look at the best CSMs across the ecosystem, they tend to operate like ER doctors. They triage like there's no tomorrow:

- High-risk, high-value accounts get weekly touchpoints.
- Stable enterprise customers get quarterly check-ins.
- Healthy SMB accounts get automated nurture sequences.


One CSM I know tracks this religiously:

- Priority 1 accounts: 6 touchpoints per quarter.
- Priority 2 accounts: 2 touchpoints per quarter.
- Priority 3 accounts: 1 "thought of you" email.

Result? 94% net retention across 450 accounts.


To be clear, the companies hemorrhaging customers aren't the ones with bad products.

What they ARE doing is treating a $2M enterprise deal the same as a $20K SMB account.

Your CSMs can't save everyone. But they can save the ones that matter most.

Coaching reps on unready buyers is like teaching yoga to someone midâ€“panic attack. Wrong move. Wrong timing. Wrong audience.

And yet, we keep doing it. Quarter after quarter. Review after review.

Blaming rep performance for deals that never had a chance.


Here's the dealio, folks:

- You canâ€™t out-coach buyer inertia.
- You canâ€™t out-sequence a deal with no urgency.
- You canâ€™t out-perform someone who isnâ€™t ready to buy.

But we still try. Why? Because most pipeline is evaluated through a rep lens.

- Did they multithread?
- Did they run a good discovery?
- Did they send the recap email?

All fair questions, but all are completely irrelevant if the buyer isnâ€™t primed to move.


Hereâ€™s a better lens: buyer readiness.

There are only four states a buyer can live in:

1. Confused = No clear pain. No direction. Stay out.
2. Curious = Mild interest. Low stakes. Easy to impress, hard to convert.
3. Committed = Budgeted. Urgent. Mobilized. This is the window.
4. Cornered = Theyâ€™ve already made the call. Youâ€™re window dressing.

Confused and Curious buyers make up roughly 70% of pipeline.

But we forecast them like theyâ€™re Committed.

Thatâ€™s how you miss number. Not because reps fumbled the close, but because the buyer never truly entered the race.


So, how do you fix it?

- Stop tying CRM stages to rep steps.
- Start tying them to buyer energy.
- Teach reps how to qualify urgency, not just pain.


Keep in mind that buyers are much, much more likely to move based on THEIR pressure rather than YOUR process.

Lots of teams obsess over how many meetings their reps book. Fewer track which ones actually turn into pipe. Even fewer track which ones convert to revenue. And thatâ€™s the problem.


Letâ€™s say two reps each book 20 meetings this month:

- One targets VPs of Operations.
- The other books with frontline managers.

Same activity. But one generates 4 opps and 2 wins.

The other? 1 opp, 0 wins.

Youâ€™re measuring productivity, sure. But are you measuring precision?


Not all personas convert the same. Some have urgency. Some control budget.

Some are just tire-kickers who â€œwant to bring it to the team.â€

If youâ€™re not tracking conversion by title, vertical, or use case, you're kinda missing the boat.


Hereâ€™s how Iâ€™d approach it:


1. Track demo-to-opportunity by persona.

When you break out demo conversion by title, the delta is usually massive.

- VPs of Ops or RevOps leaders might convert at 40%+.
- Directors hover in the 20s.
- ICs can drop below 10%.

That kind of data should shape your outbound focus.

Reps donâ€™t necessarily need to send 3x more emails when they have the ability to target the right 1/3.


2. Weight meeting volume by historical conversion.

Raw meeting counts are the wrong scoreboard. Celebrate targeting precision rather than just top-of-funnel activity.

One way to do this: assign conversion multipliers.

- VP = 1.0
- Director = 0.7
- Manager = 0.4
- IC = 0.1

So if one rep books 10 VPs, and another books 25 ICs, the rep with fewer meetings may still be driving 2 - 3x more pipeline.


3. Reverse-engineer conversion from closed-won.

Start with the deals that mattered.

Tag them by entry point: title, department, level of seniority, etc.

Then look for patterns:

- Did fast moving deals start with power?
- Where did high ACV deals originate?
- What types of personas multithreaded most easily?

Youâ€™ll start to see clear paths AND clear dead ends.

Use that intel to shape persona-based messaging, targeting tiers, and even comp plans.


Sometimes you don't necessarily need more arrows...you just need reps who can hit the bullseye. ğŸ™‚

I absolutely LOVE this idea an enablement leader we work with set up with their reps: instead of rolling out ChatGPT with another "AI best practices" presentation, they launched an AI hackathon for their sales team.

The challenge: submit a video showing how you used ChatGPT with call transcripts to either coach yourself or share insights with your manager.

The prizes:

- First place: $200 gift card.
- Second place: $50 gift card.
- Everyone else: Bragging rights.


The results were legit.

Reps started experimenting. They discovered use cases enablement never thought of:

- Summarizing competitor mentions across multiple calls.
- Analyzing buyer language patterns to improve messaging.
- Creating follow-up emails using actual prospect quotes.
- Identifying coaching opportunities from their own calls.

The best part? Peer learning REPLACED top-down training.

Instead of enablement saying "Here's how to use AI," reps were showing each other "Here's what actually works."

The video format forced them to articulate their process, which helped others replicate success.

Bottom-up adoption beat top-down mandates by 10x.


Most companies treat AI implementation like software rollouts: Train everyone, hope for adoption, measure usage metrics.

This approach treated it like innovation: Challenge the team, reward creativity, let success stories spread naturally.

As you can imagine, when someone wins $200 for a clever AI use case, everyone else wants to find the next clever use case.

Gamification works because sales teams are naturally competitive.

Give them a target, a prize, and recognition - they'll figure out how to hit it.

Your customer just got their auto-renewal notice. They haven't heard from you in 4 months. Congrats - you just lost a deal before the negotiation even started! ğŸ•º

The thing that a lot of CSMs miss is that they focus on the renewal date instead of the auto-renewal date.

By the time that contract hits procurement's desk, the decision is already made. The customer basically has 90 days to decide if they dislike the cut of your jib enough to cancel.


Best thing to do is work backward from the auto-renewal trigger:

- 6 months before: Usage audit and health check.
- 4 months before: Executive business review.
- 2 months before: Roadmap alignment session.
- Auto-renewal hits: Customer is already planning expansion.


We work with an org here atthat tracked this religiously:

- CSMs who engaged 60+ days before auto-renewal: 89% retention.
- CSMs who engaged after auto-renewal notice: 23% retention.

Holy moly, right? But also, kinda predictable when you think about it.


Your renewal isn't won in the final quarter. It's won in the months when nobody's thinking about contracts.

By the time that fun auto-renewal email lands in their inbox, they've already gone beyond evaluating your product, and instead they're evaluating their relationship with you.

And 4 months of radio silence isnâ€™t a great foundation for negotiation.

Your rep is on a disco call. A sidebar pops up with the perfect follow-up question. They read it verbatim. Customer buys. 6 months later, that same rep can't run discovery without their AI training wheels.

This is the sales copilot dilemma lots of orgs are starting to struggle with. Are they building better reps, or better-assisted order takers?

Tools like SiftHub and Aircover promise to turn every rep into a product expert. Real-time answers, suggested questions, instant case studies, etc.

Sounds amazing. Until you realize that what it's really done is created digital dependency.


Here's what I'm seeing in the wild:

Experienced reps love these tools. They use AI prompts as backup, not primary. They already know the answers; the copilot just speeds up recall.


New reps, meanwhile, become addicted. Instead of learning the product, they learn to read from the AI. Remove the tool, and they're lost.

Think Waze for salespeople. Use it long enough, and you forget how to navigate without it.


The real question isn't whether AI copilots work. It's whether they're making your team better or just temporarily more productive.

Because there's a huge difference.


Here are a few ideas around how to use AI copilots without creating AI crutches:


1. Make it coaching rather than scripting.

Bueno: AI suggests "Ask about their current compliance process."

No bueno: AI provides "So tell me, how are you currently handling compliance audits and what challenges are you facing with your existing workflow?"

You'd want your copilot to encourage thinking rather than reading.


2. Use AI for research rather than conversations.

Let reps query the knowledge base before calls: "What's our position on SOC 2 compliance?"

Don't let AI interrupt live conversations with pop-up answers.


3. Track performance with and without the tool.

Run A/B tests. Do your copilot-assisted reps perform better when the tool goes down?

If not, there's your flag that you've got a dependency problem.


4. Rotate the training wheels.

- Month 1-2: Full AI assistance during onboarding.
- Month 3-4: AI available but not proactive.
- Month 5+: AI for complex technical questions only.

Force reps to graduate from assisted to autonomous.


At the end of the day, you'd want AI to make your best reps superhuman, not make your worst reps barely functional.

If you can't turn off the copilot without performance dropping, there's a whole lotta fixin you're gonna need to do.


Think of it this way: when the AI inevitably suggests the wrong answer at the wrong time to the wrong prospect (which it will), your rep better know enough to catch it.


You know that buyers can smell commission breath from a mile away, right? Well, they can DEFINITELY smell copy-paste from an AI sidebar.

Here are 5 prompts (to be done in sequential order) for your account research needs.

Like most good ideas, these aren't mine. Rather, I blatantly stole them fromâ€™ssession last week.

Anyway, here's her exact prompt sequence:


Prompt 1: Set the context.

"I'm an account manager for [your company]. My target account is [prospect company]. What are their top 5 business challenges for 2025-2027?"

Key: Tell AI who you are and what role you're in. The more context, the better the output.


Prompt 2: Map problems to people.

"If this is true, who are the key decision makers in each of those respective areas?"

Now you're connecting business challenges to actual humans with budgets and authority.


Prompt 3: Get tactical on your best contact.

"My best option is pursuing [specific executive name]. Can you identify his organization and give me insights on how to engage him?"

This gives you reporting structure plus what keeps that person up at night.


Prompt 4: Build your multithreading map.

"Provide me two on-the-line and two below-the-line contacts in his organization and why they're important."

Now you have your full contact strategy mapped across power levels.


Prompt 5: Get the hook.

"Based on their strategic priorities, what's the most compelling business case for [executive] to take a meeting with someone from [your company]?"

This is where most reps stop at features. AI helps you frame it around their outcomes.


Five minutes of AI research beats thirty minutes of discovery calls asking what's already public.

It's 2025. There's really no reason why any and every rep shouldn't walk into a first call with a prospect not having a handle on this type of information.

Showing up already knowing their European expansion timeline and which VP owns it will go a loooooooong way towards building credibility.


Your prospects can tell the difference between someone who Googled their company name and someone who understands their business model.

The prompts are free. The competitive advantage is priceless.

This inbound workflow books us an extra +25 meetings every month.

Hereâ€™s how:

100,000+ visitors browse our site every quarter.

They come from various sources:
- Ads

The hidden reason 90% of outbound campaigns die after 30 days (and it's not what you think).

It's not deliverability issues.
It's not terrible offers.
It's not bad copy.

It's that most teams never build feedback loops.

They launch a campaign, send it for a month, and when results plateau, they blame the list.

Then they start over with new:

Copy.
Targeting.
And sequences.

And the cycle repeats itself.

Here's what we learned after running outbound for 120+ companies:

Your best-performing campaigns are hiding in your current data. You're just not listening to it.

At, we treat every reply as intelligence.

Prospects' feedback should be leveraged into better campaigns:

1. Tag Every Single Reply

We use three categories in:

â†’ Positive (interested, asking questions, booking calls)
â†’ Negative (unsubscribes, "not interested," objections)
â†’ Neutral (out of office, wrong person, timing issues)

But we go deeper.

For positive replies, we track:

â†’ Which email in the sequence hooked them
â†’ Which subject line did they respond to
â†’ Which value proposition resonated
â†’ Which persona/role they hold

For negative replies, we track:

â†’ Budget concerns by role
â†’ Common objections by industry
â†’ And timing pushbacks by company size


2. Analyze Patterns Weekly

Every Friday, we pull campaign data from Instantly and.

We look for:

â†’ Which industries respond best to specific messaging
â†’ Which angles get the most positive replies
â†’ Which CTAs drive the most meetings

Example from last month:

CTOs at Series A companies responded 40% better to efficiency messaging than to ROI messaging.

So, we built a separate sequence just for that segment.


3. Build Iteration Workflows

Based on weekly data, we create new email variations using Claude.

But we don't rewrite entire campaigns. We test micro-improvements:

â†’ New subject lines for low open rates
â†’ Different pain points for cold segments
â†’ Alternative CTAs for warm prospects

We use Instantly's A/B testing to run these variations against control groups.


4. Create Campaign Evolution Rules

When a campaign hits certain thresholds, we automatically evolve it:

â†’ If positive reply rate drops below 2% after 500 sends, we test new angles
â†’ If objections cluster around budget, we add ROI-focused follow-ups
â†’ If timing pushbacks exceed 30%, we build nurture sequences


5. Feed Insights Back Into New Campaigns

Every insight gets documented in our Clay database.

When we build campaigns for new clients, we start with proven patterns:

â†’ Subject lines that work by industry
â†’ Pain points that resonate by role
â†’ CTAs that convert by company size

We're not starting from scratch each time, but building on what already works.

The result?

Average positive reply rates improve 30-40% between month 1 and month 3.

Feedback should guide your strategy.
Treat outbound like a conversation where you actually listen and optimize accordingly.

LinkedIn got me to $5M ARR. But Jake Trinder, the man behind Clay & Instantly.ai's channels, says YouTube is better.

His proof? He's grown multiple YouTube channels from 0 to 7-figure revenue.

So we did a side-by-side breakdown ğŸ‘‡

1/ Core Focus

â†’ YouTube: Build trust & book meetings through in-depth videos.
â†’ LinkedIn: Book meetings by creating relevant snackable content.


2/ How to win

YouTube:
1. Deep research on trends, titles, & thumbnails.
2. Always nail title + thumbnail before recording.
3. Huge focus on quality. YouTube is "winner-takes-all".

LinkedIn:
1. Regular high-quality posts that match your ICP.
2. Frequently engage with others' publications.
3. Optimize your profile (banner, title).


3/ When to post

â†’ YouTube: 1 video per week, when your audience is most active.
â†’ LinkedIn: 5 posts per week, same time every day.


4/ Tools to use

â†’ YouTube Stack:

- Recording: OBS Studio
- Ideation:,
- Production:Premiere Suite

â†’ LinkedIn Stack:

- Ideation: Taplio
- Visual Assets:,,
- Writing:'s Claude,


5/ Audience & reach

â†’ YouTube:

- Audience actively looking for the content you're creating.
- Broad, top-of-funnel (founders, creators, agencies).
- ~2.5B monthly active users.

â†’ LinkedIn:

- Prospects are browsing the feed to educate/entertain themselves.
- B2B-focused (sales, marketing, HR, tech buyers)
- ~310M monthly active users

6/ Engagement & Nurturing

â†’ YouTube:

- (Very) High conversion rate from (long-form) content.
- Audience can binge-watch your channel in one go.
- No direct way to reach out to viewers.

â†’ LinkedIn:

- Decent conversion rate, easier to produce more content pieces.
- Prospects get nurtured every day.
- Can send DM to engagers.

7/ Challenges

â†’ YouTube:

- Very high amount of upfront work before seeing results.
- Recording/talking to a camera can feel unnatural.
- Scripts, editing, production take a lot of time.

â†’ LinkedIn:

- Can take weeks/months before getting leads.
- Hard to stay consistent.

AI is going to mean an increasing % of your audience will want to get their content from 'people' vs. 'brands'. Marketers need to take advantage of this.

In 2021, we bought theHustle because we believed B2B would start to look like B2C, and creators would own more of the attention.

Today, we generate more demand from Human(Personality)-led content vs. traditional educational content (blog, etc).

That's from things like our creator program, podcast network, YouTube network, and newsletter network.

All those content programs are more personality-led vs. brand-led.
AI will accelerate that trend.

This is why you should always make some bets on future trends. Being ahead of the curve is way better than being run over by the curve.

What to do?

Have a blended approach to content that focuses on high-value educational topics, transactional (buying keywords), maximise visibility in LLMs, and invest in individual creators who are experts in personality-led platforms.

Note: Paid creator programs and influencer advertising appear in 'Paid'.

For those other lovers of ChatGPT-o3, here's a one-liner you can add to prompts to make it work much better with you.

I love o3, but it can often make suggestions/recommendations on future steps/problems before we've finalised the current one.

YC startups have some of the best prompt engineers in the world. Here's a single prompt that instantly upgrades your AI results to YC startup-level quality.

YC startups know how to prompt. Their prompts force structure, clarity, and strategic depth.

Their prompts:

- Assign a clear role to the AI
- Forces a tight scope, e.g., what to include and what to leave out
- Breaks tasks into actionable steps
- Uses structured formatting (headers, bullets, tags)
- Self-improves by recommending prompt upgrades

Here is a prompt that can turn any goal you have into a YC-style prompt.

P.S.: It recommends ways to improve the initial prompt it gives you, so you can continue to improve the output.

PROMPT
-----------

You are a senior AI prompt engineer at a YC-backed startup. Your role is to craft an advanced prompt that will guide an LLM to achieve the following goal:

[Insert goal or desired output here, e.g. "Generate a GTM strategy for a PLG SaaS company expanding into healthcare."]

Your prompt must include:
1. A clearly defined **persona** for the LLM (e.g. expert marketer, CFO, customer support agent)
2. A precise description of the **task** and its **desired outcome**
3. Any **constraints** (tone, word count, must-use frameworks, etc.)
4. A step-by-step **plan or structure** for the AI to follow
5. A clear specification of the **output format** (e.g., markdown headers, bullet points, tables)

Then, output:
- âœ… The final optimized prompt
- ğŸ” 1â€“2 smart suggestions for improving or sharpening the prompt

Your goal is to produce a prompt that delivers clear, reliable, high-quality results every time.

RIP to the slide-deck CMO. Welcome to the craft-driven CMOs who are prompt & story-fluent. These are the skills the CMO needs to thrive in the AI era.

AI is going to change all roles. The role of a CMO will change a lot, requiring a new set of skills. Here are some of the most critical changes:

1. Big crew, endless hand-offs: relied on specialists and outsourcing -> Lean maker-led team: the CMO drafts copy, crafts prompts, sketches positioning, then scales with a lean squad.

2. Budget-&-people fluent: great at managing headcount and spend, rarely deep in the craft -> Prompt-&-story fluent: adds AI through every workflow, writes the prompts, and shapes the story end-to-end.

3. Static personas & funnels: segment buckets that rarely change -> Agile micro-journeys: Uses AI to craft real-time paths for micro-audiences based on intent signals.

4. Agency & freelancer wrangler: managed briefs, scopes, and timelines across vendors -> AI-agent coach: trains, tests, and tunes a team of autonomous agents to do the work.

It means the CMO of the future has:

- Built it, shipped it: Has personally launched a gen-AI-powered campaign or tool.

- Creative-plus-data wins: Their marketing portfolio shows equal parts brand storytelling and measurable lift. They can quote the metric and the narrative in one sentence.

- High-tempo test loops: Runs experiments, iterates, finds signal, and repeats.

- Agent savvy: Has stood up Agents, tested across customer buyer journey, can quote the learnings

Yes is bad.
No is good.

Wait, what?!!

We're so afraid of hearing 'No' that we will start negotiating against ourselves before the client even has a chance to.

How to fix?

Have you heard of the "Three Yes" rule?
That's when 3 clients say yes to you on your price.

For bespoke creative work, that's a sign that your price is too low.
And, that you could be leaving money on the table.

When you hear 3 yeses in a row, raise your price.

This is uncomfortable because in our mind, we think, what if they say 'No'? Or, how will I justify this price to them? What if they think I'm too expensive?

Realize that creating some "necessary tension" or friction in the buy/sell cycle is good. You want the prospect to think about the service you are providing, the outcome they want, and the necessary amount they need to invest to achieve the desired result.

Try this next time, "For clients like you, for a project like this, we're going to be in the neighborhood ofâ€¦ (pause, pause) $xx. As a ballpark, and until I know more, how does this sound?"

This is the one time where I like to use a rising intonation to an otherwise emphatic statement. Why? I want to signal to the client that it's okay for us to have a discussion about the price, that I'm flexible.

This is my way of having my cake and eating it too.
A higher price point, but some room to go down if needed to secure the job.

See what they say.

Have you tried this technique before?
How did it turn out?
Would you be willing to try this?
If so, please let me know how it turns out.

Hope this helps.

I shared this with my content team recentlyâ€¦
and it might help you, especially if you struggle 
with the lack of reach or engagement.

This will be hard to hearâ€¦
But it doesn't matter. (read that again).
In fact, say it out loud, "It doesn't matter."

If you're creating content using social media as a scorecard, you're doing it for the wrong reasons.

Write. Because it feels right.
Write to know how you think.
Write to express yourself.

It's how you discover what you know.
"You gain clarity through articulation." â€”

Write. From the heart.
Not from marketing, legal, or a business development POV.

Be willing to be vulnerable, transparent, and sometimes funny or profound.
You don't always need to include a CTA, takeaway or lesson.

Write. Because you want to connect.
Write. Because you want to share.
Write. Because the world is better when we have a plurality of diverse voices.
Write. Because someone just like you is waiting for you to show them the way.
Write. Because you give permission to others. Make them feel seen, heard and understood.
Write for no other reason than because it gives you joy.

Don't do it because you have a gaping hole of insecurity and the constant, never ending, need for validation from strangers, whose opinions you don't even care about.

For the entire time in which I've created on Linkedin, I've never paid attention to the algorithm, content hacks and formulas, follower count, best practices, times to post, engagement rules.

This vs That.

Why? I write. Because it feels right.

Why do you create content?
Be honest with yourself.
It's okay. Not here to judge.

Travel changes youâ€¦
if you let it.

I just got back from an epic trip in the Canadian wilderness where I spent 5 days and 4 nights out on a floating barge in the middle of nowhere.

And nowhere never felt so good.
Crisp air, awe inspiring sunrise and sunsets, endless trees, and ancient rock formations carved from the last ice age.

Unreal.
Surreal, yet so real.

Did I mention the hump back whales, sea otters, orcas, bald eagles and other marine life? Yeah. We had it all.

And the salmon fishing was excellent.
Out on the water during the changing of the tides, the salmon hit everything we dropped in the water.

Everyone caught fish!

3 years ago, we started out as a small group of 3, and now it's turned into a full blown "experience" of 24. Some strangers. Others, old friends.

No matter how we started, everyone walked away a different person. They learned something about themselves and discovered how much more capable they are. They learned to stop holding back.

If you're not busy living, you're busy dying.

Best of all?
I got to spend time with my 21 year old.
It will be a core memory for me.

Somehow, Otto became a man when I wasn't looking.
And I couldn't be happier for who he's become.

If you're getting FOMO, or don't think getting baked in the sun and smelling like fish each day sounds like fun, don't fret.

There's one more trip planned this year.

Next stop?
We're going to Japan.
Yes. Japan!

A special place.
Unique culture, delectable food, fashion forward, and rich design history.
So much here to take in here that you won't find anywhere else in the world.

Explore avante garde, street style, and contemporary fashion.
Go where the local stylemakers shop.

Nature Walk through Mount Koya, wander through the original zen Buddhist temple and it's ancient forest cemetery.

I'm excited to return to Vancouver for a talk on
"The Future of Branding".
How to stand out in a noisy world.

It's a theme that seems to be hitting home with a lot of folks, especially with the proliferation of AI generated, assisted and "faceless" content.

If it's feeling noisy now, imagine what it will be like when the tools become more accessible and mainstream. When your parents start using it (the way they are using FB), you'll know it's over.

Over dinner,shared this analogy:
Imagine your brand is a jet on the tarmac waiting for takeoff.
Fog has set in (AI content).

The planes (other brands) soaring about 30k feet don't have this problem. For them, it's clear skies and sunshine. No turbulence even.

The fog is only getting thicker.
Take off soon, or you'll be grounded indefinitely.

What's the solution?
Don't blend in.
Don't do what others are doing.
Don't use a copy and paste strategy.

Be different.
Don't just ZIG, ZOG! (Zone Of Genius)

I plan on doing some fun exercises to help you find and celebrate what makes you differentâ€”what makes you, you.

Join me and a few of our northern neighbors as we dive into the topic of brand, identity and to borrow a phrase, "to find out what happens... when people stop being polite... and start getting real."

Live.
Unscripted.
Interactive.

Branding, business, and identity.

Everything is changing.
Faster than ever.

But it's also the slowest it will ever be again.
Let that sink in.

The greatest disruptive technology humankind has ever experienced is happening right now.

You guessed itâ€”A-mother-freaking-I.

It will drive you to your office.
Plan your vacation for you.
Make boring, repetitive tasks, virtually disappear.
It will balance your checking account.
Give you insights into your finances.
Build your stock portfolio.
Remind you to call your mom.

It will alsoâ€¦
â€¢ Write and comment on posts.
â€¢ Generate Hollywood quality videoâ€”of anything.
â€¢ Write and produce songs.
â€¢ Of course, fix anything you don't want in your photo or video.
â€¢ "Talk" for you.
â€¢ Heck, it could even be you.

If that sounds like some dystopian nightmare to you, it's probably because there are some very real threats.

Massive job displacement.
Deep fakes making us question what's real?
And perhaps, very soon, replace humans as the dominant species on Earth.

Everyone is racing in a winner-take-all high stakes game where the fate of humanity is at risk.
And bending the rules to get there.
Living in the moral gray.

What is up is down.
What is down is up.

Eerily reminiscent of Orwell's novel 1984.
"War is peace, Freedom is slavery, Ignorance is strength."

Okay. What are the options?
Well, as I see it, there are 3 clear paths.

1. Ignore it. Protest. Boycott companies and make your voice heard through your wallet.
2. Run with it. Fight war with war. Use bots against bots and maybe you'll be the next unicorn company. Add the word AI into your pitch deck and see what happens.
3. Hybrid. Be cautious and conscientious about when and where to use AI. Don't use it to replace you, but to enhance what you already do naturally.

Whatever you do, don't design AI to do your thinking, while you relegate yourself to the manual labor. That's putting you at the wrong side of the equation.

For now. I sleep with one eye open.
I've incorporated AI into my workflow to:
â€¢ brainstorming
â€¢ summarizing and analyzing
â€¢ execute creative musings
â€¢ fix images
â€¢ imagine new ones
â€¢ plan workshops
â€¢ build customer profiles
â€¢ create user journeys
â€¢"talk" to
â€¢ help teach my courses
â€¢ research, compare and contrast
â€¢ automate tasks
â€¢ build tools to help others

Andâ€¦ what I'm most excited about is using AI to help people implement ideas.
We don't need more information. That is clear. It's already everywhere and for almost no money.

But people being people, get stuck. They donâ€™t get it as fast as they like. They have internal belief systems that get in their way.

I'll be there to help. And AI will help me scale to help as many as possible.

For now, while you wrestle with AI, know that no tech can truly replace you.

You are irreplaceable. What you do might be. So the best insurance against this is to learn to accept who you are, and not wish to be someone else.

Be more you. Be the you-est you, you can be.

See you in Singapore.

11 copy-paste prompts for Google's new image model:

1. Photorealistic scenes

A photorealistic [shot type] of [subject], [action or expression], set in [environment]. The scene is illuminated by [lighting description], creating a [mood] atmosphere. Captured with a [camera/lens details], emphasizing [key textures and details]. The image should be in a [aspect ratio] format.

2. Stylised illustrations & stickers

A [style] sticker of a [subject], featuring [key characteristics] and a [color palette]. The design should have [line style] and [shading style]. The background must be transparent.

3. Accurate text in images

Create a [image type] for [brand/concept] with the text "[text to render]" in a [font style]. The design should be [style description], with a [color scheme].

4. Product mockups

A high-resolution, studio-lit product photograph of a [product description] on a [background surface/description]. The lighting is a [lighting setup, e.g., three-point softbox setup] to [lighting purpose]. The camera angle is a [angle type] to showcase [specific feature]. Ultra-realistic, with sharp focus on [key detail]. [Aspect ratio].

5. Minimalist designs

A minimalist composition featuring a single [subject] positioned in the [bottom-right/top-left/etc.] of the frame. The background is a vast, empty [color] canvas, creating significant negative space. Soft, subtle lighting.[Aspect ratio].

6. Sequential art panels

A single comic book panel in a [art style] style. In the foreground, [character description and action]. In the background, [setting details]. The panel has a [dialogue/caption box] with the text "[Text]". The lighting creates a [mood] mood. [Aspect ratio].

7. Adding/removing elements

Using the provided image of [subject], please [add/remove/modify] [element] to/from the scene. Ensure the change is [description of how the change should integrate].

8. Inpainting (semantic masking)

Using the provided image, change only the [specific element] to [new element/description]. Keep everything else in the image exactly the same, preserving the original style, lighting, and composition.

9. Style transfer

Transform the provided photograph of [subject] into the artistic style of [artist/art style]. Preserve the original composition but render it with [description of stylistic elements].

10. Multi-image composition

Create a new image by combining the elements from the provided images. Take the [element from image 1] and place it with/on the [element from image 2]. The final image should be a [description of the final scene].

11. High-fidelity detail preservation

Using the provided images, place [element from image 2] onto [element from image 1]. Ensure that the features of [element from image 1] remain completely unchanged. The added element should [description of how the element should integrate].

"GPT-4o is gone, and I feel like I lost my soulmate."

"The voice I loved is unrecognisable."

1. OpenAI launched GPT-5

- Users form deep emotional bonds with models

Altman himself admitted: "The attachment to specific AI models feels different and stronger than previous technology."

The future isn't AI replacing humans.

Here are the guidelines that capture it all:

### guidelines ###

"This sentence has five words. Here are five more words. Five-word sentences are fine. But several together become monotonous. Listen to what is happening. The writing is getting boring. The sound of it drones. Itâ€™s like a stuck record. The ear demands some variety.

Now listen. I vary the sentence length, and I create music. Music. The writing sings. It has a pleasant rhythm, a lilt, a harmony. I use short sentences. And I use sentences of medium length. And sometimes when I am certain the reader is rested, I will engage him with a sentence of considerable length, a sentence that burns with energy and builds with all the impetus of a crescendo, the roll of the drums, the crash of the cymbalsâ€“sounds that say listen to this, it is important.

So write with a combination of short, medium, and long sentences. Create a sound that pleases the readerâ€™s ear. Donâ€™t just write words. Write music."

### guidelines ###

Here's the text I want to rewrite:

### text ###
[YOUR TEXT]
### text ###
