Software Engineering habits that will make you successful and efficient for your entire career:

â†’ read and critique code every week
You learn more from code reviews than any online course.

â†’ document what you build (in your own words)
Future-you (and your team) will thank you.

â†’ write tests as you go, not after
Itâ€™s not about 100% coverage, itâ€™s about not being scared to refactor.

â†’ plan before you code
A 10-minute sketch saves 2 days of rewriting.

â†’ talk to users, not just product managers
Youâ€™ll spot real issues nobody puts in Jira.

â†’ track tech debt like actual debt
Every shortcut has interest, keep a simple backlog and pay it down.

â†’ automate boring tasks
If you do it twice, script it.

â†’ learn to debug with logs, not guesses
Stack traces > Stack Overflow copy-paste.

â†’ ask for help before youâ€™re stuck for 4 hours
Speed matters more than heroics.

â†’ invest in peer relationships, not just code
The best engineers are trusted, not just talented.

What would you add?

I am an Engineering Manager working at Google with almost 20 years of experience. If I could sit down with a Jr. Software Engineer, here are 50 cheat codes I would share with them that I learned from my experiences.

[1] Ask why this system even needs to exist
â¤ Before a single line is written, challenge the core purpose, â€œIs this a business problem or just a tech exercise?â€ Real systems solve pain, not boredom.

[2] Redraw the lines, define whatâ€™s â€œinsideâ€ and â€œoutsideâ€ your system
â¤ Figure out where your service starts, stops, and how it talks to the world. 80% of future headaches come from blurred boundaries.

[3] Donâ€™t chase new tech for the resume, use what your org supports
â¤ That AWS Lambda demo looks cool until your team tells you thereâ€™s a 10-year-old Jenkins server already scheduled to do that job. Proven > Shiny.

[4] System design isnâ€™t â€œone size fits allâ€, context is everything
â¤ YouTube and interview videos show perfect worlds. Your system will live in mess, legacy, and compromise. Embrace it.

[5] Optimize for â€œhow easy to change?â€ not â€œhow cool is this?â€
â¤ You wonâ€™t get it perfect first time. Make it so anyone (even you) can swap out parts later, with minimal pain.

[6] Start with use cases, not tech
â¤ Interview solutions start with â€œput Kafka here.â€ Real solutions start with â€œwho will use this and how?â€

[7] Know your real users, not just your APIs
â¤ Customers, PMs, even other devs, all are â€œusersâ€ with needs. If your â€œsystemâ€ forgets one, itâ€™s doomed.

[8] Design for the traffic you have, not the traffic you dream of
â¤ Every engineer who overbuilt for â€˜Google scaleâ€™ at a 10K user startup has regretted it. Scale when you must.

[9] Understand your companyâ€™s default tech stack, donâ€™t fight it
â¤ Donâ€™t propose a NoSQL database if everyone else is running Postgres unless you have a bulletproof case.

[10] Pick the boring solution if you want peace
â¤ Every time I chased â€œthe best tech,â€ maintenance bit me back. The system you forget about is the most stable one.

[11] Get the teamâ€™s buy-in before you architect a â€œmasterpieceâ€
â¤ Donâ€™t be a solo hero. Feedback from PMs, ops, QA, other engineers, all of it will expose what you missed.

[12] Refactor and cleanup arenâ€™t â€œnice to havesâ€, theyâ€™re your real job
â¤ Every shortcut you leave will double your pain in 6 months.

[13] Read logs and production metrics every week
â¤ Production is where truth lives. Ignore at your own risk.

[14] Test how things break, not just how they work
â¤ Simulate failing databases, crashing services, weird user flows, assume chaos is coming.

[15] Youâ€™ll be asked to fix code you didnâ€™t write, embrace it
â¤ Legacy code is half your career. Treat it with respect and curiosity, not blame.

[16] Never let a diagram go out without clear boundaries
â¤ Always show whatâ€™s external, whatâ€™s internal, and whatâ€™s a dependency, otherwise, no one will know what breaks what.

â¤ People donâ€™t come to software engineers because they can code well, no, thatâ€™s not it. 

They come for stability, for trust, for the guarantee that their core workflows wonâ€™t break wonâ€™t break when they need them the most.

â¤They donâ€™t care about the frameworks you debate over lunch.

They care that when their business grows, the system grows with them without sleepless nights or last-minute firefighting.

â¤They donâ€™t ask how many PRs you merged this month.

They ask how many customers noticed an improvement because of what you shipped.

â¤Nobody is paying for your architectural diagram.

Theyâ€™re paying for uptime, for latency that goes unnoticed, for features that work every single time.

â¤They donâ€™t measure your value in certifications or badges.

They measure it in their ability to launch new products, enter new markets, and move fast because your foundation is solid.

â¤Theyâ€™re not excited by test coverage reports.

Theyâ€™re excited by the freedom to experiment, knowing your tests will catch what they miss.

â¤They donâ€™t buy cloud credits.

They buy resilience, systems that donâ€™t flinch, even when traffic spikes out of nowhere.

â¤They donâ€™t buy â€œteam velocityâ€ or burndown charts.

They buy the confidence that your team can deliver, quarter after quarter, when it matters most.

â¤Theyâ€™re not investing in your resume.

Theyâ€™re investing in your judgement, the ability to say â€œnoâ€ to bad shortcuts and â€œyesâ€ to the right risks.

In the end, nobody is here for your code.

Theyâ€™re here for outcomes: performance that scales, problems that stay solved, and the peace of mind that lets them sleep well at night.

Thatâ€™s what great engineering delivers.
Thatâ€™s what gets remembered.

Dear software engineers, you'll definitely thank yourself later if you spend time learning this today:

â¥½ Redis
> Your AI tools can help you write code, but when it comes to fast data access and handling spikes, Redis knowledge will save you in prod.

â¥½ Docker & Kubernetes
> Knowing how to build, ship, and scale with Docker and K8s will make you valuable even if youâ€™re using Copilot for code.

â¥½ Message Queues (Kafka, RabbitMQ, SQS, etc.)
> When you need to decouple services or handle unpredictable spikes, nothing beats message queues. AI will not explain why your system dropped messages at 3AM, but youâ€™ll know if you actually practiced queues.

â¥½ ElasticSearch
> Search is not just about matching keywords. If you ever need to build search, logs, or analytics at scale, Elastic will come up.

â¥½ WebSockets
> For anything real-time, chat, games, live dashboards, WebSockets are key. Your AI tools wonâ€™t design a fault-tolerant, low-latency messaging layer for you. Only learning, building, and breaking things will.

â¥½ Distributed Tracing
> In a microservices jungle, tracing lets you see exactly where requests slow down or fail. AI will tell you â€œadd tracing,â€ but you have to know where and how to trace.

â¥½ Logging & Monitoring
> Nobody wants to get a â€œsite downâ€ call at midnight with zero logs. Learn what, when, and how to log. Monitoring will help you detect issues before users even see them.

â¥½ Concurrency & Race Conditions
> Even the best AI misses subtle concurrency bugs. Learn how to write and review multithreaded or async code. Youâ€™ll save days in debugging.

â¥½ Load Balancers & Circuit Breakers
> When your backend goes down or traffic spikes, these patterns keep your service up. Theory is easy, handling real-world outages is something you have to experience.

â¥½ API Gateways & Rate Limiting
> If you ever ship a public API, youâ€™ll thank yourself for knowing this. Otherwise, get ready for abuse, cost overruns, or worse.

â¥½ SQL vs NoSQL
> Not every problem is a nail, not every DB is a hammer. Know when to pick each.

â¥½ CAP Theorem & Consistency Models
> Distributed systems fail in surprising ways. CAP and consistency are what separate coders from engineers.

â¥½ CDN & Edge Computing
> Speed isnâ€™t just about code. If your users are global, your infra better be too.

â¥½ Security Basics
> Learn OAuth, JWTs, and encryption because you donâ€™t want to be the engineer who lets a breach happen.

â¥½ CI/CD & Git
> Automated tests, clean deployments, and rollback plans.
AI canâ€™t fix a botched deploy for you.

Write some scripts, push your local hardware, break things, and figure out why. This is how you build instincts that AI canâ€™t teach.

AI will make you faster, but these fundamentals make you effective and productive.

If AI saves time but doesnâ€™t help you make money, itâ€™s not a tool, itâ€™s a toy.

Many people start building AI thinking that automation means efficiency.

They automate steps, not systems.
They remove clicks, not decisions.
They create speed, not outcomes.

Instead of asking:
â€œhow do I automate this task?â€

They should ask:
â€œhow do I remove myself from this process while still getting the result?â€

Hereâ€™s the difference:

âœ… Automating a task is:
â†³ Writing a draft email for follow-up.

âœ… Automating an outcome means:
â†³ Detecting cold leads
â†³ Rewriting the message based on context
â†³ Sending it
â†³ Logging it
â†³ Booking the call

All without human intervention.

New Course: Post-training of LLMs

Learn to post-train and customize an LLM in this short course, taught by, Assistant Professor at the, and co-founder of.

Training an LLM to follow instructions or answer questions has two key stages: pre-training and post-training. In pre-training, it learns to predict the next word or token from large amounts of unlabeled text. In post-training, it learns useful behaviors such as following instructions, tool use, and reasoning.

Post-training transforms a general-purpose token predictorâ€”trained on trillions of unlabeled text tokensâ€”into an assistant that follows instructions and performs specific tasks. Because it is much cheaper than pre-training, it is practical for many more teams to incorporate post-training methods into their workflows than pre-training.

In this course, youâ€™ll learn three common post-training methodsâ€”Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT), Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), and Online Reinforcement Learning (RL)â€”and how to use each one effectively. With SFT, you train the model on pairs of input and ideal output responses. With DPO, you provide both a preferred (chosen) and a less preferred (rejected) response and train the model to favor the preferred output. With RL, the model generates an output, receives a reward score based on human or automated feedback, and updates the model to improve performance.

Youâ€™ll learn the basic concepts, common use cases, and principles for curating high-quality data for effective training. Through hands-on labs, youâ€™ll download a pre-trained model from Hugging Face and post-train it using SFT, DPO, and RL to see how each technique shapes model behavior.

In detail, youâ€™ll:
- Understand what post-training is, when to use it, and how it differs from pre-training.
- Build an SFT pipeline to turn a base model into an instruct model.
- Explore how DPO reshapes behavior by minimizing contrastive lossâ€”penalizing poor responses and reinforcing preferred ones.
- Implement a DPO pipeline to change the identity of a chat assistant.
- Learn online RL methods such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) and Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), and how to design reward functions.
- Train a model with GRPO to improve its math capabilities using a verifiable reward.

Post-training is one of the most rapidly developing areas of LLM training. Whether youâ€™re building a high-accuracy context-specific assistant, fine-tuning a model's tone, or improving task-specific accuracy, this course will give you experience with the most important techniques shaping how LLMs are post-trained today.

Iâ€™d like to share a tip for getting more practice building with AI â€” that is, either using AI building blocks to build applications or using AI coding assistance to create powerful applications quickly: If you find yourself with only limited time to build, reduce the scope of your project until you can build something in whatever time you do have.

If you have only an hour, find a small component of an idea that you're excited about that you can build in an hour. With modern coding assistants like Anthropicâ€™s Claude Code (my favorite dev tool right now), you might be surprised at how much you can do even in short periods of time! This gets you going, and you can always continue the project later.

To become good at building with AI, most people must (i) learn relevant techniques, for example by taking online AI courses, and (ii) practice building. I know developers who noodle on ideas for months without actually building anything â€” Iâ€™ve done this too! â€” because we feel we donâ€™t have time to get started. If you find yourself in this position, I encourage you to keep cutting the initial project scope until you identify a small component you can build right away.

Let me illustrate with an example â€” one of my many small, fun weekend projects that might never go anywhere, but that Iâ€™m glad I did.

Hereâ€™s the idea: Many people fear public speaking. And public speaking is challenging to practice, because it's hard to organize an audience. So I thought it would be interesting to build an audience simulator to provide a digital audience of dozens to hundreds of virtual people on a computer monitor and let a user practice by speaking to them.

One Saturday afternoon, I found myself in a coffee shop with a couple of hours to spare and decided to give the audience simulator a shot. My familiarity with graphics coding is limited, so instead of building a complex simulator of a large audience and writing AI software to simulate appropriate audience responses, I decided to cut scope significantly to (a) simulating an audience of one person (which I could replicate later to simulate N persons), (b) omitting AI and letting a human operator manually select the reaction of the simulated audience (similar to Wizard of Oz prototyping), and (c) implementing the graphics using a simple 2D avatar.

Using a mix of several coding assistants, I built a basic version in the time I had. The avatar could move subtly and blink, but otherwise it used basic graphics. Even though it fell far short of a sophisticated audience simulator, I am glad I built this. In addition to moving the project forward and letting me explore different designs, it advanced my knowledge of basic graphics. Further, having this crude prototype to show friends helped me get user feedback that shaped my views on the product idea.

On Monday, a United States District Court ruled that training LLMs on copyrighted books constitutes fair use. A number of authors had filed suit against Anthropic for training its models on their books without permission. Just as we allow people to read books and learn from them to become better writers, but not to regurgitate copyrighted text verbatim, the judge concluded that it is fair use for AI models to do so as well.

Indeed, Judge Alsup wrote that the authorsâ€™ lawsuit is â€œno different than it would be if they complained that training schoolchildren to write well would result in an explosion of competing works.â€ While it remains to be seen whether the decision will be appealed, this ruling is reasonable and will be good for AI progress. (Usual caveat: I am not a lawyer and am not giving legal advice.)

AI has massive momentum, but a few things could put progress at risk:
- Regulatory capture that stifles innovation, including especially open source
- Loss of access to cutting-edge semiconductor chips (the most likely cause would be war breaking out in Taiwan)
- Regulations that severely impede access to data for training AI systems

Access to high-quality data is important. Even though the mass media tends to talk about the importance of building large data centers and scaling up models, when I speak with friends at companies that train foundation models, many describe a very large amount of their daily challenges as data preparation. Specifically, a significant fraction of their day-to-day work follows the usual Data Centric AI practices of identifying high-quality data (books are one important source), cleaning data (the ruling describes Anthropic taking steps like removing book pages' headers, footers, and page numbers), carrying out error analyses to figure out what types of data to acquire more of, and inventing new ways to generate synthetic data.

I am glad that a major risk to data access just decreased. Appropriately, the ruling further said that Anthropicâ€™s conversion of books from paper format to digital â€” a step thatâ€™s needed to enable training â€” also was fair use. However, in a loss for Anthropic, the judge indicated that, while training on data that was acquired legitimately is fine, using pirated materials (such as texts downloaded from pirate websites) is not fair use. Thus, Anthropic still may be liable on this point. Other LLM providers, too, will now likely have to revisit their practices if they use datasets that may contain pirated works.

Overall, the ruling is positive for AI progress. Perhaps the biggest benefit is that it reduces ambiguity with respect to AI training and copyright and (if it stands up to appeals) makes the roadmap for compliance clearer....

I hope we can empower everyone to build with AI. Starting from K-12, we should teach every student AI enabled coding, since this will enable them to become more productive and more empowered adults. But there is a huge shortage of computer science (CS) teachers. I recently spoke with high school basketball coach Kyle Creasy, who graduated with a B.A. in Physical Education in 2023. Until two years ago, he had never written a line of Python. Now â€” with help from AI â€” he not only writes code, he also teaches CS. I found Kyleâ€™s story inspiring as a model for scaling up CS education in the primary- and secondary-school levels.

Kyleâ€™s success has been with the support of Kira Learning (an AI Fund portfolio company), whose founders Andrea Pasinetti and Jagriti Agrawal have created a compelling vision for CS education. In K-12 classrooms, teachers play a huge social-emotional support role, for example, encouraging students and helping them when they stumble. In addition, they are expected to be subject-matter experts who can deliver the content needed for their subject. Kira Learning uses digital content delivery â€” educational videos, autograded quizzes, and AI-enabled chatbots to answer students' questions but without giving away homework answers â€” so the teacher can focus on social-emotional support. While these are still early days, it appears to be working!

A key to making this possible is the hyperpersonalization that is now possible with AI (in contrast to the older idea of the flipped classroom, which had limited adoption). For example, when assigned a problem in an online coding environment, if a student writes this buggy line of Python code

best_$alty_snack = 'potato chips'

Kira Learningâ€™s AI system can spot the problem and directly tell the teacher that $ is an invalid character in a variable name. It can also suggest a specific question for the teacher to ask the student to help get them unstuck, like â€œCan you identify what characters are allowed in variable names?â€ Whereas AI can directly deliver personalized advice to students, the fact that it is now helping teachers also deliver personalized support will really help in K-12.

Additionally, agentic workflows can automate a lot of teachersâ€™ repetitive tasks. For example, when designing a curriculum, itâ€™s time-consuming to align the content to educational standards (such as the Common Core in the United States, or the AP CS standard for many CS classes). Having an AI system carry out tasks like these is already proving helpful for teachers.

Since learning to code, Kyle has built many pieces of software. He proudly showed me an analysis he generated in matplotlib of his basketball playersâ€™ attempts to shoot three-pointers (shown above), which in turn is affecting the teamâ€™s strategy on the court. One lesson is clear: When a basketball coach learns to code, they become a better basketball coach!

Even though Iâ€™m a much better Python than JavaScript developer, with AI assistance, Iâ€™ve been writing a lot of JavaScript code recently. AI-assisted coding, including vibe coding, is making specific programming languages less important, even though learning one is still helpful to make sure you understand the key concepts. This is helping many developers write code in languages weâ€™re not familiar with, which lets us get code working in many more contexts!

My background is in machine learning engineering and back-end development, but AI-assisted coding is making it easy for me to build front-end systems (the part of a website or app that users interact with) using JavaScript (JS) or TypeScript (TS), languages that I am weak in. Generative AI is making syntax less important, so we can all simultaneously be Python, JS, TS, C++, Java, and even Cobol developers. Perhaps one day, instead of being â€œPython developers" or â€œC++ developers,â€ many more of us will just be â€œdevelopersâ€!

But understanding the concepts behind different languages is still important. Thatâ€™s why learning at least one language like Python still offers a great foundation for prompting LLMs to generate code in Python and other languages. If you move from one programming language to another that carries out similar tasks but with different syntax â€” say, from JS to TS, or C++ to Java, or Rust to Go â€” once youâ€™ve learned the first set of concepts, youâ€™ll know a lot of the concepts needed to prompt an LLM to code in the second language. (Although TensorFlow and PyTorch are not programming languages, learning the concepts of deep learning behind TensorFlow will also make it much easier to get an LLM to write PyTorch code for you, and vice versa!) In addition, youâ€™ll be able to understand much of the generated code (perhaps with a little LLM assistance).

Different programming languages reflect different views of how to organize computation, and understanding the concepts is still important. For example, someone who does not understand arrays, dictionaries, caches, and memory will be less effective at getting an LLM to write code in most languages.

Similarly, a Python developer who moves toward doing more front-end programming with JS would benefit from learning the concepts behind front-end systems. For example, if you want an LLM to build a front end using the React framework, it will benefit you to understand how React breaks front ends into reusable UI components, and how it updates the DOM data structure that determines what web pages look like. This lets you prompt the LLM much more precisely, and helps you understand how to fix issues if something goes wrong. Similarly, if you want an LLM to help you write code in CUDA or ROCm, it helps to understand how GPUs organize compute and memory.

New short course: Building Code Agents with Hugging Face smolagents!

Learn how to build code agents in this course, created in collaboration with, and taught by, its co-founder and CSO, and, Hugging Faceâ€™s Project Lead on Agents.

Tool-calling agents use LLMs to generate multiple function calls sequentially to complete a complex sequence of tasks. They generate one function call, execute it, observe, reason, and decide what to do next. Code agents take a different approach. They consolidate all these calls into a single block of code, letting the LLM lay out an entire action plan at once, which can be executed efficiently to provide more reliable results.

Youâ€™ll learn how to code agents using smolagents, a lightweight agentic framework from Hugging Face. Along the way, youâ€™ll learn how to run LLM-generated code safely and develop an evaluation system to optimize your code agent for production.

In detail, youâ€™ll learn:
- How agentic systems have evolved, gaining greater levels of agency over timeâ€”and why code agents are a next step.
- How code agents write their actions in code.
- When code agents outperform function-calling agents.
- How to run code agents safely in your system using a constrained Python interpreter and sandboxing using E2B.
- To trace, debug, and assess the code agent to optimize its behaviours for complex requests.
- How to build a research multi-agent system that can find information online and organize it into an interactive report.

By the end of this course, youâ€™ll know how to build and run code agents using smolagents, and deploy them safely with a structured evaluation system in your projects.

Please sign up here!

Iâ€™ve noticed that many GenAI application projects put in automated evaluations (evals) of the systemâ€™s output probably later â€” and rely on humans to manually examine and judge outputs longer â€” than they should. This is because building evals is viewed as a massive investment (say, creating 100 or 1,000 examples, and designing and validating metrics) and thereâ€™s never a convenient moment to put in that up-front cost. Instead, I encourage teams to think of building evals as an iterative process. Itâ€™s okay to start with a quick-and-dirty implementation (say, 5 examples with unoptimized metrics) and then iterate and improve over time. This allows you to gradually shift the burden of evaluations away from humans and toward automated evals.

I wrote previously in The Batch about the importance and difficulty of creating evals. Say youâ€™re building a customer-service chatbot that responds to users in free text. Thereâ€™s no single right answer, so many teams end up having humans pore over dozens of example outputs with every update to judge if it improved the system. While techniques like LLM-as-judge are helpful, the details of getting this to work well (such as what prompt to use, what context to give the judge, and so on) are finicky to get right. All this contributes to the impression that building evals requires a large up-front investment, and thus on any given day, a team can make more progress by relying on human judges than figuring out how to build automated evals.

I encourage you to approach building evals differently. Itâ€™s okay to build quick evals that are only partial, incomplete, and noisy measures of the systemâ€™s performance, and to iteratively improve them. They can be a complement to, rather than replacement for, manual evaluations. Over time, you can gradually tune the evaluation methodology to close the gap between the evalsâ€™ output and human judgments. For example:
- Itâ€™s okay to start with very few examples in the eval set, say 5, and gradually add to them over time â€” or subtract them if you find that some examples are too easy or too hard, and not useful for distinguishing between the performance of different versions of your system.
- Itâ€™s okay to start with evals that measure only a subset of the dimensions of performance you care about, or measure narrow cues that you believe are correlated with, but donâ€™t fully capture, system performance. For example if, at a certain moment in the conversation, your customer-support agent is supposed to (i) call an API to issue a refund and (ii) generate an appropriate message to the user, you might start off measuring only whether or not it calls the API correctly and not worry about the message. Or if, at a certain moment, your chatbot should recommend a specific product, a basic eval could measure whether or not the chatbot mentions that product without worrying about what it says about it.

New Short Course: Building AI Browser Agents! 

Learn how to build AI agents that interact with and take actions on websites in this course, created in partnership withand taught by@DivGarg_ and, Co-founders of AGI Inc.

AI browser agents can log into websites, fill out forms, click through web pages, or even place orders online for you. They use both visual information, like screenshots, and structural data, like the HTML or Document Object Model (DOM) of a web page, to reason and take action.

With the complexity of webpages and multiple possible actions at each step, it can be challenging for an AI browser agent to complete an assigned task. Because these agents run long action sequences, a single errorâ€”like clicking the wrong button or misreading a fieldâ€”can lead to unexpected outcomes or errors that compound over time.

In this course, you'll understand how autonomous web agents work, their current limitations, and how AgentQ enables them to improve through self-correction.

In detail, you'll:
- Learn what web agents are, how they automate tasks online, their architecture, key components, limitations, and an overview of their decision-making strategies.
- Build a web agent that can scrape's website and return course recommendations in a structured output format.
- Build an autonomous web agent that can execute multiple tasks, such as finding and summarizing webpages, filling out a form, and signing up for a newsletter.
- Explore AgentQ, a framework that enables agents to self-correct by combining Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS), a self-critique mechanism for continuous improvement, and Direct Preference Optimization (DPO).
- Deep dive into MCTS, learn how it finds an effective path, illustrated by an example of Gridworld animation, and use AgentQ to complete web tasks.
- Understand AI agents' current state and future directionsâ€”including key factors shaping their evolution, such as hardware, algorithm innovation, and data availability.

By the end of this course, you will have hands-on experience building browser agents and a deeper understanding of how to make them more robust and reliable.

At the Artificial Intelligence Action Summit in Paris this week, U.S. Vice President J.D. Vance said, â€œIâ€™m not here to talk about AI safety.... Iâ€™m here to talk about AI opportunity.â€ Iâ€™m thrilled to see the U.S. government focus on opportunities in AI. Further, while it is important to use AI responsibly and try to stamp out harmful applications, I feel â€œAI safetyâ€ is not the right terminology for addressing this important problem. Language shapes thought, so using the right words is important. Iâ€™d rather talk about â€œresponsible AIâ€ than â€œAI safety.â€ Let me explain.

First, there are clearly harmful applications of AI, such as non-consensual deepfake porn (which creates sexually explicit images of real people without their consent), the use of AI in misinformation, potentially unsafe medical diagnoses, addictive applications, and so on. We definitely want to stamp these out! There are many ways to apply AI in harmful or irresponsible ways, and we should discourage and prevent such uses.

However, the concept of â€œAI safetyâ€ tries to make AI â€” as a technology â€” safe, rather than making safe applications of it. Consider the similar, obviously flawed notion of â€œlaptop safety.â€ There are great ways to use a laptop and many irresponsible ways, but I donâ€™t consider laptops to be intrinsically either safe or unsafe. It is the application, or usage, that determines if a laptop is safe. Similarly, AI, a general-purpose technology with numerous applications, is neither safe nor unsafe. How someone chooses to use it determines whether it is harmful or beneficial.

Now, safety isnâ€™t always a function only of how something is used. An unsafe airplane is one that, even in the hands of an attentive and skilled pilot, has a large chance of mishap. So we definitely should strive to build safe airplanes (and make sure they are operated responsibly)! The risk factors are associated with the construction of the aircraft rather than merely its application. Similarly, we want safe automobiles, blenders, dialysis machines, food, buildings, power plants, and much more.

â€œAI safetyâ€ presupposes that AI, the underlying technology, can be unsafe. I find it more useful to think about how applications of AI can be unsafe. Further, â€œresponsible AIâ€ emphasizes that it is our responsibility to avoid building applications that are unsafe or harmful and to discourage people from using even beneficial products in harmful ways.

I believe the 2023 Bletchley AI Safety Summit slowed down European AI development â€” without making anyone safer â€” by wasting time considering science-fiction AI fears. Last month, at Davos, business and policy leaders also had strong concerns about whether Europe can dig itself out of the current regulatory morass and focus on building with AI. I am hopeful that the Paris meeting, unlike the one at Bletchley, will result in acceleration rather than deceleration.

New short course: Attention in Transformers: Concepts and Code in PyTorch.

Last week we released a course on how LLM transformers work. This week, go deeper and learn about the technical ideas behind the attention mechanism, and see how to code it in PyTorch. This course is built with, Founder and CEO of StatQuest.

The attention mechanism was a breakthrough that led to transformers, the architecture powering large language models like ChatGPT. Transformers, introduced in the 2017 paper: "Attention is All You Need" by Viswani and others, took off because of its highly scalable design.

In this course, youâ€™ll learn how the attention mechanism, a key element of transformer-based LLMs, works and implement it in PyTorch. You'll develop deep intuition about building reliable, functional, and scalable AI applications.

What you will do:
- Understand the evolution of the attention mechanism, a key breakthrough that led to transformers.
- Learn the relationships between word embeddings, positional embeddings, and attention.
- Learn about the Query, Key, and Value matrices, and how to produce and use them in attention.
- Walk through the math required to calculate self-attention and masked self-attention to learn why and how they work.
- Understand the difference between self-attention and masked self-attention and how one is used in the encoder to build context-aware embeddings and the other is used in the decoder for generative outputs.
- Learn the details of the encoder-decoder architecture, cross-attention, and multi-head attention and how they are all incorporated into a transformer.
- Use PyTorch to code a class that implements self-attention, masked self-attention, and multi-head attention.

7. Delegate repetitive tasks and workflows.

Comet is a great tool for creating and assigning tasks or recapping action items from meeting notes.

Whatâ€™s the difference between these two DNS lookups?

They look similar, but they tell very different stories.

In the first command:

âŒ¨ï¸ nslookup

You're asking your default DNS resolver (router or ISP).
âœ… Recursive lookup, following all CNAMEs to the final IPs.
âŒ Non-authoritative = cached and possibly outdated.

In the second command:

âŒ¨ï¸ nslookup

Youâ€™re directly asking the authoritative DNS server.
âœ… The answer comes straight from the source
âŒ Only tells you what that server knows (stops at 1st CNAME)

So which is better? It depends on your goal.

ğŸ’¨ Use your default resolver if you want the final IP quickly.
ğŸ” Use the authoritative if you want to verify who controls what.

has observed a number of threat actors gain access into internal networks via Sonicwall devices.

Cannot believe how many AI users ignore the most powerful techniques.

â¬‡ï¸ Steal my 7-line context block â¬‡ï¸

â€œIâ€™m a [role] that's tried [approach]. It didnâ€™t work because [reason]. During the process of trying, I felt [constraints/emotions]. What I want to achieve is [outcome]. Iâ€™m worried about [risk]. I have to [non-negotiables/limits]. Can you help me [specific action]?â€

Start with 2â€“3 honest sentences and compare vs. no context and youâ€™ll see the delta.

Hereâ€™s how I turn an AI thread into concrete next steps in 30 seconds â¬‡ï¸

Youâ€™re probably like me and juggling hundreds of AI chat threads, wondering how youâ€™re going to build a stronger system. Well, donâ€™t rely on your memory to remember it all. Instead, steal my end-of-thread prompt.

In addition to using the search and memory functions, I use this prompt at the end of my high-value chats to turn the whole thread into working notes I can act on. It pulls out the concrete facts and numbers, the actual outputs we created, the decisions and why we chose them, who owns what and by when, the open risks, and the next 1â€“3 moves so momentum doesnâ€™t stall.

It also raises the bar on note quality. Vague lines get rewritten or tagged â€œTOO GENERIC â†’â€. Missing details are called out with [MISSING: â€¦]. Key numbers and deliverables are bolded.

This has saved me hours when Iâ€™m balancing multiple workstreams, returning to a thread days later, or introducing teammates to new projects.

Had to share why I encourage my team to use AI even when it doesnâ€™t save time.

I can think of thousands of ways to use AI and they tend to fall into three categories.

âš¡ï¸ Do stuff faster - AI handles tedious tasks youâ€™d normally spend minutes or days on. Like pulling action items from meetings, summarizing reports, generating first drafts. Same output, fraction of the time. Most people stop here (boo!).

ğŸ¯ Do stuff better - Take your existing work to the next level. Instead of basic research, get personalized insights. Instead of simple sales forecasts, analyze 10x more data sources for higher accuracy. Instead of hoping your proposal lands, test it against 30 synthetic personas first. Instead of brainstorming alone in your shower, debate with AI for 20 minutes and get 300 new ideas. There are plenty of ways I use AI that DO NOT SAVE TIME. That is encouraged on my team if it makes our work better.

ğŸ”® Do new stuff - Unlock capabilities you never had before. Non-engineers building apps. Financial analysts creating multimedia presentations like the UBS AI avatars with Synthesia. Teachers personalizing curriculum for every student. Grandparents organizing decades of photos in minutes.

And here's a crazy new stat: 2.26% of all Claude conversations are for emotional support and life coaching. People are actively searching for more meaning, more value, more depth.

And YET, the majority of AI demos I see on the internet fall into category 1. And those folks find themselves on a never ending hamster wheel of productivity. Just trying to run faster and faster. Only to realize they should stop running and buy rollerblades. Or a hoverboard.

AI can be that personal catalyst. Not just booking you an Open Table slot, but helping you become who you want to be.

The funny thing about the prediction from the CEO of Anthropic l that AI would be writing 90% of all code by now is that the prediction's failure distracts from the fact that AI adoption in code writing is actually extremely high, it was over 30% in December, 2024 according to one measure, with large financial impact.

The speed at which AI has come to write a huge amount of code is pretty startling, even if it is not as fast as predicted. This is becoming a common theme in AI: boosters are often more directionally correct than those who dismiss AI, but they are usually way too early on timelines.

Report:

We really have not made a lot of progress on explaining the deep mystery of LLMs:

How does a model the size of a moderately large video game, using matrix multiplication to predict the next word manage to simulate human thought well enough to do all the very human-like things it does? And what does that mean about us?

I don't know anyone who uses LLMs a lot who is not occasionally weirded out by what they can do. If you are not, you should be. They are weird.

Wolfram had a rather startling (at least at the time) theory after using ChatGPT the first time, which you can see below. Understanding whether he is right is important.

Ruining art with Gemini 2.5 Flash.

(The funny thing is that this would have been a joke a year or two ago that I would have had to execute in Photoshop. It remains crazy to me that I can say "make this less tragic" and an AI will know enough to remove the splash of Icarus falling from the Landscape with the Fall of Icarus.)
Gemini 2.5 Flash creates an actually mildly amusing New Yorker cartoon. (As far as I can tell, this is the first time that this joke has been used)

"Transcendence" is when an LLM, trained on diverse data from many experts, can exceed the ability of the individuals in its training data.

This paper demonstrates three types of transcendence: when AI picks the right expert skill to use to solve a problem, when AI has less bias than individual experts & when it generalizes from expert knowledge to new contexts.

GPT-5 Pro, Gemini Deep Think, Claude 4.1 Opus, and Grok 4: â€œWrite a two paragraph original secret history, smart and meaningful. Think Pynchon, Borges, Powers, or Eco for inspiration.â€

LLMs shine as connection machines (though some are better at writing this sort of fiction)

Looking at the ARC-AGI benchmark is a useful way of understanding AI progress.

There are two goals in AI, minimize cost (which is also roughly environmental impact of use) & maximize ability. It is clear you can win one goal by losing the other, GPT-5 seems to represent a gain on both.

(The confusing bit is that, for ChatGPT users, GPT-5 is two things, a router and a model name. So when you use â€œGPT-5â€ in ChatGPT you might be talking to any of the GPT-5 models, as OpenAI optimizes cost versus presumed model ability to answer a question.)

The new GPT-5 personality likes giving sandwich feedback (you are great- suggestion for improvement - you are great).

In general, better than GPT-4o at pushing back while being a bit syncophantic - it did suggest improvements to my awful poem. (It would be useful for the AI labs to look at the research on giving good feedback)

This is a much needed first attempt at a benchmark to measure how much given AI models will play along with users pushing them in delusional or potentially psychologically dangerous directions.

Some early signal that full GPT-5 (not the specialist chat model) is a less psychologically risky model.

Close friendships and romantic relationships are one of the most amazing things about being alive. Humans find each other, and stick by each other, some for life through thick and thin.

For me, the only way to do relationships is being ride-or-die for each other. Same applies to close friendships.

I'm going through some heartbreak at the moment (that's life), and wondering how it all turned out this way. Getting laid has always been easy. Finding a woman to spend the rest of my life with has not been.

The great thing about life though is that every new day is full of possibilities.

I think the main issue has been that I'm an introvert who loves being at home, reading/working/chilling alone or with close friends. But this year I'm doing a bit of the opposite: taking on some wild adventures. In that spirit, I'm traveling to some very beautiful (and in some cases dangerous) places.

Launching Codex as a research preview: a cloud-based software engineering agent that can work on many tasks in parallel. Codex can write features, fix bugs or answer questions about your codebase - each task runs in its own cloud sandbox environment, preloaded with your repository.

This is a fundamentally new way of creating software and has the potential to super charge productivity for individuals and teams. Looking forward to iterating and improving this will all your feedback.

Day 12 of 12 days of OpenAI

Our next frontier model: o3 and o3-mini. Now open for safety testing (not a general launch yet).

It is a big step forward in math, science, coding and reasoning abilities, beating human expert level performance in many of these benchmarks.

Particularly impressive is the performance on the ARC-AGI benchmark which is known to be one of the hardest general intelligence evaluations.

The reasoning models we have developed that can think and reason through complex tasks at this level is a completely new paradigm and has created a capability overhang.

it is going to be exciting to see how people leverage this in new ways next year.

Day 10 of 12 days of OpenAI

Access ChatGPT on WhatsApp or via a phone call (1-800-ChatGPT)

We want to make ChatGPT available as broadly as possible in any communication medium of your choice.

I love that this started as a fun hackathon project a few weeks ago.

Day 9 of 12 days of OpenAI

Today is all about developers

- o1 in available in the API
---- Support for function calling, structured outputs and developer messages to tune model behavior.
---- Vision input
---- A new reasoning_effort parameter to control how much time the model spends thinking

- Real-time API
---- WebRTC support
---- Lower price: GPT-4o audio is 60% cheaper. Also, we have realtime api in 4o-mini which is 10x cheaper

- Fine-tuning: Direct preference optimization (DPO) aka Preference fine-tuning - where you can provide preferred/non-preferred examples to fine tune your models

- New SDKs for Go and Java
Enjoyed talking about our work at OpenAI at the EmTech Digital conference organized by MIT Technology Review

Incredible work by the whole team to bring GPT-4o to life - our new model which is natively multi-modal. Enables natural real-time and expressive conversations.

GPT-4o is as smart as GPT-4 but much more efficient to run.

In ChatGPT, we are making it available in the free tier, and to Plus users with up to 5x higher message limits.

In the API, it will be half the price of GPT-4T while also being 2x faster and having 5x the rate limits.

It also has a much improved tokenizer that reduces price significantly for non-English (and especially Indic) languages.

As leaders, we often talk about balance. But the truth is â€” balance isn't something you find. It's something you build. Step by step.

In between high-stakes calls, deep-dive reviews, and back-to-back decision-making, Iâ€™ve found one of the most effective ways to stay mentally sharp and physically well â€” is to walk while I work.
Literally.

Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™ve installed a
in my office.

I take meetings on the move.

I walk through strategy discussions.

I pace while planning roadmaps.

Itâ€™s not about multitasking â€” itâ€™s about energy. Clarity. Momentum.

Iâ€™ve found that staying in motion helps me stay in tune â€” with my body, with my thoughts, and with the team that counts on me to show up fully.

In a world that celebrates hustle, this is my version of pause.
In a world that glorifies sitting still for hours, this is my version of focus.

In a schedule packed to the brim, this is my way of saying â€” my health matters too.

So hereâ€™s what Iâ€™ve learned:

ğŸ’ªğŸ¼ Wellness doesnâ€™t always come in perfect blocks of time.

ğŸ’ªğŸ¼ Sometimes, it comes in the in-between. During the call. Before the next meeting. While youâ€™re making decisions that move
the needle.

Iâ€™m sharing this not because I think everyone needs to install a treadmill in their office. But because I believe everyone needs to find their own way to walk the talk â€” literally or metaphorically
â€” when it comes to wellbeing.

The question is:

What does that look like for you?

The book is finally here

About 5 years ago, I started sharing my learnings from the ground on social media to help anyone else grappling with problems we had already faced and navigated

In this period, the number of people following my content increased manyfold. I also started getting many requests to document my learnings in a more structured and detailed form in a book. Zero To Scale is the result of it

And it took a good 2 years and many writing sessions on Sunday evenings ( that is the only time I had) to bring it to life

In this book, Iâ€™ve covered everything that I possibly could to help anyone build and grow their brand in India. Everything Iâ€™ve written is what we ourselves followed at Atomberg for growing our fan business, and now following them again to build our new categories like mixer grinders and water purifiers from scratch

Grateful to everyone who took the pain to go through the early drafts and share their feedback/praise, some of which are published here

The book is about 40000 words long and I have tried my best to strike the right balance between depth and brevity in each topic. The table of content is also here

I genuinely wish to help Indian entrepreneurs and operators grow faster and better. Even the choice of publisher, Wyzr, is reflective of that. I met the founder, Yashraj, my junior from college and was impressed by the work they had already done and their drive to make an impact in an industry thatâ€™s in need of some energy

Building distribution, generating demand and building a brand isnâ€™t easy. Even if ever so slightly, I hope this book helps you in that journey

The book is already available on Amazon, and should be available in leading book stores and a Q-com portal in the next 2 weeks. Amazon Link in comment

In the 90s, couples prayed for children but today, many plan not to have any ğŸ‘ª

Itâ€™s called the DINK lifestyle, Double Income, No Kids.

And itâ€™s not just a Western idea anymore. Itâ€™s growing in India at over 30% every year.

In some states, 65% of newlyweds say they want to delay or skip having children.

And interestingly, rural India is leading this shift. 42% of rural two-member households fall into this category, almost double that of urban India.

Because todayâ€™s couples are prioritising:
â†’ Financial independence
â†’ Emotional readiness
â†’ Travel, passion projects, and personal growth
â†’ And yes, peace, space, and freedom

This isnâ€™t rebellion. Itâ€™s clarity. A conscious choice to invest in self, partnership, and purpose before parenting.

And the ripple effect is already here:

â†’ More demand for premium experiences, not family bundles
â†’ A rise in solo living, pet care, mental wellness, and elder support
â†’ Financial tools for two, not four
â†’ A new kind of Indian aspiration one built around choice, not checklists

This is still growth. Just not the kind we used to measure. and in many ways, itâ€™s more sustainable because itâ€™s driven not by pressure, but by intention. ğŸ˜Š

â€œIndia doesnâ€™t have tech companies.â€ - That was the headline.

Hereâ€™s what I actually said ğŸ‘‡

Most companies in India are tech-enabled.

Not many are pure tech.

Yet, every company and industry is now positioned as xTech. Except they are not.

As an employee or investor itâ€™s important to understand that it's the characteristics of a company that determine the nature of the company.

Here is the difference -

Real tech =

â€“ Software or digital goods â†’ close to zero marginal cost of replication
â€“ High Gross Margins â†’ minimal COGS
â€“ Network effects & scale with minimal capital â†’ near permanent moats
â€“ Proprietary IP or Infra â†’ too capital intensive to beat
Social Media, AI, Search, SaaS, Matchmaking, Gaming play here.

Think,,,,,

Tech-enabled =

â€“ Real goods â†’ lower gross margins
â€“ Require ops, logistics, supply chains, people â†’ tougher to scale

It finally happened â€” India and the UK signed a free trade agreement.

And hereâ€™s what that means for Indian exporters, professionals, and industries:

1. 99% Duty-Free Access
Almost $10 Bn worth of Indian goods will now enter the UK without paying any tariffs â€” from machinery and chemicals to garments and footwear.

2. Agriculture

Expected growth: 20%+ in just 3 years.

3. Textiles & Apparel
Duty-free access for 1,143 product lines â€” including carpets, garments, home textiles, and more. Could increase India's market share in the UK by 5% within 1â€“2 years.

4. Engineering Goods
Tariffs up to 18% will be removed, opening the path for engineering exports to grow from $4.3 Bn â†’ $7.5 Bn by 2029â€“30.

5. Professionals & Freelancers
Up to 75,000 Indian professionals will be exempt from UK social security payments for 3 years. Indian service providers get access to 36 UK sectors, no Economic Needs Test. Also, 1,800+ Indian chefs, musicians, yoga instructors can work in the UK for 2 years, even without a local employer.

Itâ€™ll take about a year for the full rollout. And yes, the benefits look big on paper.

Can trade deals like this really help India become the 3rd largest economy in the world?

Does Love Conquers All? 


Maybe
But What About Finances?

A few years back, a close friend of mine was in what seemed like the perfect relationship.

They had everything going for themâ€”except when it came to their finances. My friend was a meticulous saver, always planning for the future.

Her partner, on the other hand, lived in the moment and spent impulsively.

This financial mismatch led to frequent arguments and significant tension between them.

This story isnâ€™t unique; financial incompatibility affects many relationships and can lead to stress, disagreements, and even breakups.

Itâ€™s a red flag that should be addressed early to prevent future heartbreak.

So, how can you navigate financial differences effectively? Here are some strategies that worked for my friend and her partner:

1. Schedule "money dates": They set aside one evening each month to discuss their finances over coffee. It might sound mundane, but turning it into a regular, less daunting meeting made a big difference. It became a time to align their goals and celebrate progress.

2. Create a shared vision board: They literally cut out pictures of their dream home, vacation spots, and retirement goals. This visual representation kept them motivated and aligned on their long-term dreams.

3. Use the "yours, mine, ours" system: They maintained personal accounts for guilt-free spending and a joint account for shared expenses. This approach removed the stress of constant financial scrutiny and allowed for spontaneous purchases without tension.

4. Respect different money personalities: While my friend was cautious, her partner was a risk-taker. They found a middle ground with a "fun fund" for spontaneous buys while keeping their emergency savings intact.

Remember, itâ€™s okay to have different approaches to money. The key is understanding each other's perspectives and finding common ground.

How do you and your partner align on financial goals? Have you ever faced a money-related disagreement?

Iâ€™d love to hear your experiences and strategies in the comments!

But you donâ€™t.

What looks like a wide range of options is actually a carefully designed illusion.

The global beauty industry, worth $677 billion, is largely controlled by just a few companies.

These giants have strategically built massive portfolios â€” owning multiple brands across every category, price point, and emotional hook.

Lâ€™OrÃ©al, for example, owns 39 brands.

On one end, youâ€™ll find Maybelline and Garnier
â€” affordable and widely available.

On the other, thereâ€™s LancÃ´me, La Roche-Posay, and SkinCeuticals
â€” for premium skincare lovers.

EstÃ©e Lauder owns brands like MAC, Clinique, Bobbi Brown, and La Mer, each positioned for a slightly different customer, yet all under one roof.

Unilever with 38 personal care brands including Dove, Vaseline, Pondâ€™s, and TIGI â€” covering the mass market through everyday supermarket essentials.

This isnâ€™t just a global trend.

In Indiaâ€™s â‚¹1.2 lakh crore beauty market, local players are applying the same model.

Honasa Consumer, the parent of MamaEarth, has quietly built a powerful portfolio â€” with brands like Plum, Dot & Key, The Derma Co., Dr. Shethâ€™s, and Aqualogica.

Nykaa is doing the same, investing in Earth Rhythm, Nudge Wellness, and launching its own in-house brands across categories.

Each brand is designed to feel uniqueâ€”

â€œClean beautyâ€ for Gen Z, â€œclinicalâ€ for professionals, â€œpremiumâ€ for aspirational buyers.

On the surface, itâ€™s variety.
In reality, itâ€™s one company covering every choice you think you have.

Even when customers switch brands, they often stay within the same corporate ecosystem.

The illusion of variety is maintained but the market stays consolidated.

Itâ€™s a brilliant strategy from a business lens.

But it does raise a bigger question:

Does this approach give consumers better choices â€” or does it quietly edge out smaller, independent brands before they even get a chance?

I donâ€™t want my employees to work 12 hours a day.
I donâ€™t want them to constantly hustle and grind.
I donâ€™t want them to always agree with me.


But Iâ€™ve seen many founders list these as ideal traits.

Theyâ€™re always looking for people who can work long hours, match their ambition, be as invested as them, and run like the company is their own.

I get the sentiment.
But to be honest? I think these qualities are short-term. They donâ€™t sustain.

Because letâ€™s be real â€”

No employee can work 10â€“12 hours every dayâ€¦
unless theyâ€™re rewarded proportionally.

No one stays endlessly ambitiousâ€¦
unless theyâ€™re recognized, heard, and given a reason to care.

Instead of short-term energy, one should look for long-term mindset.

Hereâ€™s what I value:
1. Ownership.
People who take accountability, for the wins and the misses. They know what falls under their scope, and they donâ€™t blame-shift when things go south. Whether itâ€™s a crisis or a routine task, they show up with a sense of responsibility.

2. Problem-solving.
One of the most underrated qualities. I deeply value team members who donâ€™t just say â€œthis isnâ€™t workingâ€ they try to understand why, think through possible fixes, and then bring it to the table with a future course of action in mind.

3. Bias towards learning.
I admire people who are curious about their craft, take feedback seriously (not personally), and make full use of the courses and resources I sponsor for them.

4. No politics.
Team player > Star performer
People who collaborate instead of competing for credit. The ones who lift others up while growing themselves. In the long run, culture beats brilliance.
These are the qualities that create real outcomes. Not just long hours or endless hustle.

But and this is important, for these qualities to survive, we need to create the right environment too.

One where people donâ€™t fear voicing their opinion.
One where they can ask for help or learning resources without hesitation.

As a leader, itâ€™s easy to get drawn to energy and speed.

But now Iâ€™ve learned, itâ€™s the steady, thoughtful ones who create the most impact over time.

To buy an under-construction house of â‚¹2 crores in India, 
you need to earn â‚¹2.8 crores.


Why?
TAXES!!

â†’ â‚¹70L in income tax
â†’ â‚¹12L stamp duty
â†’ â‚¹10L GST
â†’ â‚¹2L registration

But even after paying all this you still canâ€™t afford a basic house in Mumbai.

And not just Mumbai.

Home prices are soaring across other cities too.

Bangalore home prices went up 23% last year.
Delhi NCR: 31%.
Ahmedabad: 15%.

But how did we get here? How did house prices become so expensive that a middle class canâ€™t afford it?

Simple answer: Demand > Supply.

Across 8 major cities, the demand is 41 lakh homes supply is just 10 lakhs.
But whatâ€™s keeping supply so low?

One major reason is poor city planning.

First let's understand what proper planning looks like.

After WW2, Tokyo focused on long-term planning.

Its urban body Tokyo Metropolitan Government runs on a $62 billion budget and handles housing, transport, roads, zoning, and disaster planning.

They follow a clear system:
â†’ A 30â€“50-year vision
â†’ A 5-year Master Plan, regularly updated

Everything is planned together, under one roof.

Now letâ€™s talk about India.
Here planning is all over the place. Urban planning is split between dozens of agencies.

For Exâ€”
â†’ In Delhi, one agency builds roads, another controls land use.
â†’ In Mumbai, MHADA builds homes, but water and roads are handled separately.

On top of this, only 28% of Indian cities have an approved city development plan. [World bank]

Even when plans exist, theyâ€™re delayed or ignored.

This leads to weak infrastructure, bad roads, drainage, water issues which means we canâ€™t support tall buildings.

Because of which Mumbai's Floor Space Index (FSI) is just 1.33â€“2.5, while in cities like Tokyo it can go up to 20.
[FSI = how much construction is allowed on a plot. Higher FSI means more floors]

We build less; land prices stay high.

Worse, much of it was used for illegal colonies that were later legalized for votesâ€”making redevelopment harder.

Result?
â†’ Over 50% of Indiaâ€™s urban population lives in slums (World Bank).
â†’ In Mumbai, EMI to Income is 55%


The housing crisis isnâ€™t just economic, itâ€™s a failure of governance
Until we fix that, owning a home will remain out of reach for most families.

"Mom, are we poor?"


I still remember asking this to my mom when I was a kid, just because my dad refused to buy me cream biscuits.

That time I didnâ€™t understand what being frugal meant I just thought we didnâ€™t have money.

Growing up in a Marwari business family, being extremely careful with money was just how life worked. Every rupee mattered, every expense had to be thought through, and saving was always the top priority.

The mindset was â€œWhat if thereâ€™s no money tomorrow?â€

So, we used to track every penny, save what you can, invest wisely, and prepare for the uncertain times because business doesnâ€™t give you monthly salaries, sometimes you earn for 2 years, and then nothing for 5.

Naturally, I inherited that mindset. I was often tagged as "kanjoos" and my dadâ€™s copy and honestly, I didnâ€™t even mind it.

He was like that, and so was I.

Even when I started earning myself, I just couldnâ€™t get myself to spend.

It wasnâ€™t about not having enough it was always about the fear of â€œwhat if itâ€™s not enough tomorrow?â€

That fear of financial distress always lingered in the background and that was my main motivation to earn money.

But over time, as I met more people and saw different perspectives basically jab maine thodi duniya dekhi.

I started to realize that maybe I donâ€™t have to carry that pressure all the time.

Money is still important; I do want to make a lot of it. But the ones who actually build wealth arenâ€™t running after it they just really enjoy what they do, and money follows.

And that made me realize maybe the real goal is to find work that excites you, that doesnâ€™t burn you out, that makes you curious again and when that happens, money will come anyway.

Found some gems this week â€“ give these a read instead of doom scrolling!

1. Motilal Oswal Wealth Creation Study -

4. Enterprising Investor - Practical analysis for investment professionals -

I used to feel bad every time 
I spent money on myself. 


Every time I made a big purchase just for joy â€” a trip, a gadget, something fancy â€” there was a voice in my head that said: "I shouldnâ€™t have done that."

That frugal mindset takes away the joy of enjoying what youâ€™ve earned.

Youâ€™re stuck in between â€” not fully enjoying the spend, and not really saving either.

But not anymore. Because at the end of the day, money is a means, not the end.

And I donâ€™t want to be someone who saves all their life, only to find no time or energy left to enjoy it.

The key is balance â€” spending wisely, not impulsively. Finding a system that keeps you both grounded and guilt-free.

So now, I follow the 2X Rule.

Whenever I want to make a big purchase, I make sure I also invest the same amount into an appreciating asset.

Say I want sneakers worth â‚¹20,000 â€” Iâ€™ll only buy them if Iâ€™m also ready to invest â‚¹20,000.

It's not about restricting yourself. It's about creating a habit that supports both joy and financial growth.

Of course, I donâ€™t apply this rule to work essentials like a laptop or tools I need.

But for guilty pleasures? 100% yes.

Whatâ€™s something you love spending on, even if it feels a little guilty?

IIM MBA fees in 2007 â€“ â‚¹4,00,000
In 2024 â€“ â‚¹27,00,000

IIT(CS) fees in 2007 â€“ â‚¹1,00,000
In 2024 â€“ â‚¹10,00,000

MBBS in a private college in 2007 â€“ â‚¹20,00,000
In 2024 â€“ â‚¹60,00,000


Thatâ€™s education inflation!

On average, across India, thatâ€™s about 12% inflation per year.

Which means costs are doubling every 6 years.

This isnâ€™t to scare you.

But itâ€™s something every parent should be aware of.

And while IIT, IIM or MBBS may not be every childâ€™s path â€” the point is simple: whatever path they choose, itâ€™s going to cost more than we think.

We all want to give our kids the best shot at quality education.

But that dream needs a plan.

Hereâ€™s what you can do depending on your childâ€™s age:

1. If your child is under 9:
â€“ You have a long-time horizon (8â€“10+ years)
â€“ Start a SIP in equity mutual funds
â€“ Given the long duration, you can allocate assets as:
80% Equity | 10% Gold | 10% Debt.
â€“ Increase investments yearly as your income grows
â€“ You can also consider government-backed schemes like PPF or SSY for added stability.

2. If your child is 10â€“12:
â€“ You still have a good 5-7 years
â€“ Go for a mix of equity and debt with lower risk, still some growth.
â€“ Allocation: 30â€“40% Equity | 5â€“10% Gold (optional) | 60â€“70% Debt

3. If your child is 13â€“16:
â€“ The goal is near â€” focus should be on capital protection
â€“ Shift completely to debt instruments:
90% Debt Funds | 10% Cash/Bank Deposits (for immediate needs)
â€“ Avoid equity and market-linked volatility

Some simple reminders:

â€“ De-risk 2â€“3 years before college â€” move from equity to safer options
â€“ Consider international index funds â€” useful for diversification + currency benefit

You may not know exactly what your child will pursue â€” but not preparing because of that uncertainty? Thatâ€™s a risk in itself.

Even if you canâ€™t save 100% of whatâ€™s needed, even a partial cushion can help reduce student loan stress later.

Remember,
Starting early and staying consistent can make a big difference later.

You're not lazy, you're just scared. Here's how to fix that.


Ever felt paralyzed by a big goal? You're not alone. Many of us avoid tasks that seem overwhelming.

But what if I told you there's a simple, yet powerful way to overcome procrastination?

So, last year, I faced this challenge when I started writing my book â€“ a task that terrified me.

I had all these ideas but couldnâ€™t figure out where to start. Every time I sat down to write, I was overwhelmed by the sheer magnitude of the project.

So, I did what most of us do when weâ€™re stuck: I procrastinated.

But the longer I avoided it, the worse I felt.

I knew I had to find a way to make progress without feeling defeated before I even began.

So, I made a tiny promise to myself: write just 200 words a day.

Thatâ€™s it. No pressure to create a masterpiece. Just 200 words.

At first, it seemed almost too easy.

But something amazing happened. Those 200 words often turned into 500, sometimes even 2000!

The simple act of writing daily built a momentum I never expected. And before I knew it, I had a full first draft.

All from one simple microcommitment.

And this approach isnâ€™t limited to writing.

Micro-commitments work for any goal, and hereâ€™s why: they bypass our brain's resistance to change.

These small, manageable steps create a snowball effect, turning tiny actions into life-changing results.

And hereâ€™s how you can harness this approach for your own goals:

1. The 10-Minute Rule: Commit to just two minutes of your desired activity daily. For example, if you want to write a book, start with ten minutes of writing each morning.

2. The "One Thing" Method: Identify the single most impactful action you can take today. Reach out to one potential client or mentor per day.

3. The 1% Improvement Principle: Aim to get just 1% better each day. Learn one new word in a foreign language daily.

4. Time-Block Sprints: Dedicate short, focused bursts to your goal. For instance, 10-minute-deep work sessions with no distractions.

By incorporating micro-commitments into your routine, you can overcome procrastination and make meaningful progress toward your goals.

Have you tried this approach before? What small commitment can you make today to move closer to your aspirations?

That's when it hit me.

What if I could teach everything I was learning?

Finladder was born from that simple idea. Help people who want to build careers in finance. Share the knowledge. Bridge the gap.

The grind was insane. Attending college classes, then rushing back to handle customers and solve student doubts. Some nights I'd fall asleep on my keyboard.

But every review that dropped, every thank-you message from a student who landed their dream job, that was my fuel.

Each piece of feedback made me work harder and reach more people.
And just like that, we scaled Finladder to an 8-figure company.

This journey has taught me the biggest lessons of my life:

ğŸ’¡Impact over income. When you genuinely solve problems, money follows naturally.

ğŸ’¡Your network is everything. Every student I helped became an advocate. Word-of-mouth built this business.

ğŸ’¡Consistency beats intensity. Small daily actions compound into extraordinary results.

ğŸ’¡Feedback is gold. Every complaint, every suggestion, I treated it as free consulting to improve.

ğŸ’¡Time is your only real asset. I stopped trying to do everything and focused on what moved the needle.

Today, thousands of finance professionals trace their career success back to Finladder. We're still bootstrapped, still growing, and still obsessed with student success.

The kid who started with â‚¹1500 and a dream now runs a business that's changing careers across India.

Your background doesn't define your future. Your commitment to solving real problems does.

'Should I do CFA?' 'Is MBA worth it?' 'Will this work for me?' 

Here's what I tell every confused student. ğŸ‘‡

He did exactly that. Those short-term courses helped him understand if finance was actually his thing. Turns out, it was.

Look, if you're confused about any career path, whether it's CFA, MBA, CA, or any other field, and you have even 0.1% doubt, here's my advice:
Test the waters first.

Do a short-term course in that field. Take a weekend workshop. Shadow someone for a week. Whatever it takes to get a real taste of what you're signing up for.

Because you'll quickly figure out:

ğŸ’¡Does this actually interest you?
ğŸ’¡Can you see yourself doing this for years?
ğŸ’¡Are you just attracted to the idea of it, or the reality too?

This approach will save you time, money, and the frustration of being stuck in something that never felt right.

The biggest career mistake isn't choosing wrong. It's choosing blind.

2025 shopping feels like 2035.

I tried Glance AI yesterday, and honestly, it felt like using the internet for the first time in 1995.
That same "wait, this changes everything" moment.

Hereâ€™s what blew my mind:
I didnâ€™t search for anything. I didnâ€™t even know what I wanted.
I just uploaded a selfie, and within seconds, I'm looking at myself wearing a dozen different outfits.
Not models wearing them. Me. My face, my body type, my skin tone.

The AI generated photorealistic images of me in jackets, shirts, and accessories â€“ stuff I'd never have thought to look for.

How those jeans would look with my build.
Whether that colour would work with my complexion.

Just pure visualisation of me, styled perfectly, ready to shop.

Behind the scenes, Glance AI is running on two decades of global commerce data, advanced diffusion models, and some seriously impressive tech architecture.

Weâ€™ve been thinking about AI in commerce all wrong.
Everyone's trying to make better chatbots for customer service or smarter recommendation engines.

How brands reach customers. How we make purchasing decisions.

It's about to feel as outdated as dial-up internet.

The future of commerce just arrived. Most people just don't know it yet.

â‚¹25 lakhs for an MBA vs. â‚¹3 lakhs for a CFA

Which is better? Or do they give the same outcome?

They don't. And here's why this choice will define your career:

ğŸ’¡FOCUS

CFA is laser-focused on finance. Investment analysis, portfolio management, and financial markets. It's deep, technical, and specialised.
An MBA covers everything: leadership, strategy, operations, marketing, and finance. It's broad but less specialised in any one area.


ğŸ’¡COST REALITY

MBA: Minimum â‚¹20-25 lakhs (plus 2 years without salary)

CFA: â‚¹3-4 lakhs total (and you can keep working while studying)
The math here is brutal if you're not careful.


ğŸ’¡RECOGNITION

CFA has one global standard. Whether you're in Mumbai or New York, a CFA is a CFA.
MBA value depends heavily on the college brand. IIM vs unknown college? Completely different outcomes.


ğŸ’¡WHAT YOU'LL ACTUALLY LEARN

The CFA curriculum is constantly updated with real industry trends. You'll learn valuation, financial modelling, and risk management at a deep level.
MBA finance courses touch these topics but stay surface-level. You get breadth, not depth.


ğŸ’¡FLEXIBILITY

CFA: Study while working. No career break needed.
MBA: Full-time programmes require 1-2 years away from income. That's another â‚¹10-15 lakhs in lost earnings.


ğŸ’¡THE SUPPLY-DEMAND REALITY

This shocked me: There are millions of MBA holders in India. But only 200,000 CFA charter holders worldwide across 164 countries.
Simple economics: scarcity creates value.


ğŸ’¡WHO SHOULD CHOOSE WHAT?

Choose CFA if you want to work in:
â†’ Investment banking
â†’ Asset management
â†’ Financial research
â†’ Portfolio management

Choose an MBA if you want to:
â†’ Switch industries completely
â†’ Move into general management
â†’ Explore different business functions
â†’ Build a broad business network


ğŸ’¡MY HONEST RECOMMENDATION?

I always advise people to go for both an MBA and a CFA because they complement each other perfectly.

An MBA builds leadership, strategic thinking, and networking skills, helping you transition into management roles, while a CFA gives you deep expertise in finance, making you a strong technical specialist.

Together, they not only enhance your credibility in the finance industry but also open leadership roles for you globally, giving you the flexibility to work across industries and geographies at the highest levels!

Unpopular opinion: Leaving your parent's house can be the best decision you can ever make! 

Before dropping a â€œHow can you even say that?" comment, hear me out!

This one decision will not only teach you invaluable lessons that you missed out on over the past 18 years in just one year, but it will also set you up to live your best life moving forward.

Hereâ€™s how!

ğŸ’¡Independence: When you move out, you take control of your life. You learn to rely on yourself for everything, from managing your time to making decisions about your day. This independence builds confidence because you realize you can handle challenges on your own.

ğŸ’¡Responsibility: Living alone means youâ€™re in charge of all the responsibilities that come with it, like paying rent and keeping your space clean. This experience helps you develop a strong sense of responsibility. Youâ€™ll quickly learn the importance of paying bills on time and maintaining a tidy living space, which prepares you for future responsibilities in a job or family life.

ğŸ’¡Life Skills: Moving out pushes you to learn practical skills that you might not have mastered while living at home. Youâ€™ll learn to cook for yourself, do laundry, and manage household chores.
ğŸ’¡Financial Independence and Management: Moving out teaches you crucial money management skills. You'll learn to budget, track expenses, and understand living costs like rent and utilities.

ğŸ’¡Social Skills: Moving out often means meeting new people, whether itâ€™s roommates, neighbours, or new friends. This social interaction helps you improve your communication and interpersonal skills. Engaging with others in a shared living space teaches you about compromise, cooperation, and conflict resolution, important skills for both personal and professional relationships.

ğŸ’¡Emotional Growth: Living independently can be emotionally challenging at times, whether it's feeling lonely or dealing with stress. Learning to cope with these feelings on your own helps build emotional resilience.

ğŸ’¡Adaptability: Living independently often involves encountering unexpected situations, from moving to a new city to changing jobs. These experiences teach you to adapt and be flexible in the face of change.

Leaving your parents' house can be tough, but itâ€™s also an exciting chance to learn about yourself and the world. Every experience, good or bad, helps you become a stronger and more confident person.

Thoughts?ğŸ’¡

Here are 5 pieces of advice Iâ€™d give to my younger self! (YJHD version) 

ğŸ’¡Go with the flow, but donâ€™t drift aimlessly.

Dreams will shift as you grow, and thatâ€™s okay. â€œKabhi kabhi lagta hai meri zindagi alag-alag directions mein ja rahi hai,â€ and that's how it's supposed to be in your 20s. Embrace the uncertainty, but also take charge when it matters. Life will throw you in different directions, but it's up to you to decide where you land.

ğŸ’¡Follow What Excites You, Even If It Seems Unrelated.

I started with finance, ended up in entrepreneurship, and who knows whatâ€™s next? Bunny once said, â€œMain udna chahta hoon, daudna chahta hoon, girna bhi chahta hoon... bas rukna nahi chahta.â€ That's what your 20s are for, trying things out, even if they seem random. Every new experience adds to your story and opens doors you never knew existed.

ğŸ’¡Adapt, Adjust, and Move Forward.

Thereâ€™s no perfect plan, and that's where many people get stuck. Bunny didnâ€™t wait around for the ideal opportunity; he created his own. Itâ€™s the same with your career. Things wonâ€™t always go as planned, so learn to adapt quickly, adjust your goals, and keep moving forward. The only constant is change, so make it your friend.

ğŸ’¡Let your dreams evolve.

The dreams I had at 21 arenâ€™t the same ones I have today. Back then, I was chasing Wall Street; now, Iâ€™m chasing impact, fulfilment, and a life thatâ€™s uniquely mine. Donâ€™t cling to old dreams just because they were once important. Allow them to evolve as you do.

ğŸ’¡Stay open to possibilities.

When I was younger, I had my path all mapped out. But â€œKahin pohonchne ke liye kahin se nikalna zaroori hota hai.â€ Sometimes you have to step away from the script and let life surprise you. Keep an open mind; you might find your true calling where you least expect it.

I never became the investment banker I once aspired to be, and thank goodness for that. Because today, Iâ€™m living a life thatâ€™s meaningful, unpredictable, and uniquely mine.

The journey might take you somewhere different from what you imagined, but it will be worth it as long as you keep moving, keep dreaming, and keep growing.
