2022-2024: How do you manage 2 businesses and keep up with content on 3 platforms?

From networking events to family functions to friends reunions, almost everyone asks me the same question!

It all comes down to one thing: effective time management.â°

18-year-old Ishaan didnâ€™t know anything about it; just went with the flow; life disciplined me!

Here are the time-management strategies that help me stay productive and avoid burnout!

â³Apply the Eisenhower matrix:
Sort tasks into four categories: urgent and important, important but not urgent, urgent but not important, and neither. This method helps you focus on tasks that add the most value while pushing aside distractions.

â³Use the Pomodoro Technique:
Work for 25 minutes, then take a 5-minute break. Repeat this cycle, and after completing four cycles, take a longer break (15â€“30 minutes). This method helps maintain focus and prevents burnout.

â³Use the 2-Minute Rule for Small Tasks:
If a task takes two minutes or less, do it immediately. This keeps minor tasks from piling up and clears your schedule for more significant work.

â³Apply Time Blocking to High-Energy Periods:
Instead of just blocking out time on your calendar, match your most demanding tasks to the times of day when you have the most energy. This makes difficult tasks easier and leaves less mentally taxing work for low-energy times.

â³Apply Parkinsonâ€™s Law:
Set tighter deadlines for tasks to force yourself to focus and complete them faster. Parkinsonâ€™s Law states that "work expands to fill the time available," so giving yourself less time can boost productivity.

â³Follow the Rule of Three:
At the start of each day, identify the three most important tasks you need to accomplish. By focusing on just three big things, you can keep your priorities clear and your workload manageable.

On Sales, Profits, and Funding

Why We Don't Have Sales Targets at Finology?

Actually, we do, but they're more like a guide; they exist for inspiration. Nothing happens if we don't meet them, and no particular individual is made a scapegoat.

Why?

We don't want to sell to people who don't want us.
Customers who want us will buy from us anyway.
Our job is to create wonderful products that solve problems.

Everything else, the customer should decide for themselves without them feeling like we are sitting on their heads to give us their money.

Why Not Sell Aggressively?

I like to flip this question: "Why sell aggressively?"
I won't have a logical answer, because for Finology, selling aggressively is not needed:

1. We are bootstrapped.
2. We have always been profitable at the group level.
3. We don't have a large team.
4. Our distribution is free, and word of mouth is good.
5. We don't have an exit plan.
6. We work from Raipur. Our expenses are limited.
7. We are not desperate for growth at any cost.

All these factors allow us to focus on doing what we do well without worrying about the competition or a VC fund.

"You can afford this because you have a sizable social media presence."

We have it because we have worked on building it for the last 6 years.
It didn't happen on its own; we were not born with it.
So yes, it is our strength. If we can build it, you can too.

"You will never be a unicorn."

Agreed, to be a unicorn, you need validation from the public or private markets.

You need to take funding at a certain valuation, dilute equity, give up board seats to outsiders, and your company becomes more about satisfying the investors than solving problems.

Yes. We will never be a unicorn, not because our growth will be limited, but because our growth will certainly be slower. I don't think there is a limit to it, just because we refuse to take outside money.

We will never be a unicorn because we will probably never raise funds. Without that, price discovery doesn't happen, as no third party has validated your valuation.

Also, I think that it's more of a vanity metric.
Just because you have reached a billion-dollar valuation, why should it be treated any differently than, say, someone at 999 million or 950 million?
Why such an obsession with a particular number?

What's the harm in being well funded and using it to be a loss leader if it creates wealth?

Wealth and money should help you buy more freedom, not more stress.
The more the valuation, the bigger the hustle to justify it, provide an exit, and get more funding for future growth.

Company culture is ruined, everyone is chasing numbers, and customer experience is compromised.

We don't want to win, rule, or capture the world. We don't want more of your wallet or attention. We just want you to use our products at a reasonable price to earn financial freedom.

Until next time,
Pranjal
Finology - The Financial Freedom Company

At Finology, we donâ€™t and will never do these things - 

- Cold calls
- Cold Emails
- Monetising User data
- Sponsored Opinion
- Sales Targets to team members

With the community and trust that we have built, we grow steadily and sustainably. And we love it that way.

Thank you to everyone

Over the last decade (FY14â€“24), money managed by Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs) has grown very fast, at about 60% CAGR. 
In comparison, PMS AUM grew at around 16% CAGR.

What's surprising is that AIFs require a much higher minimum investmentâ‚¹1 crore, compared to â‚¹50 lakh for PMS.

So why are wealthy Indians choosing AIFs over PMS?

1. AIFs are pooled funds like mutual funds that are invested in alternative assets.
2. Category III AIFs invest in both listed and unlisted companies, derivatives, and use complex trading strategies (like hedge funds).
3. They can borrow or use leverage up to twice their fund size to try to earn better returns.
4. Taxes depend on how the AIF is set up (trust or LLP).

Fund managers have more freedom; unlike mutual funds, they don't have to follow rules about company size or market caps.

1. PMS means you get your own customised stock portfolio held in your own demat account.
2. You pay tax as per your personal income tax rate.
3. Primarily invested in listed stocks.
4. There are no lock-in periods; you can take your money out anytime.

Why are Category III AIFs becoming more popular?

1. You don't have to deal with demat or custody accounts; the fund handles everything.
2. The fund pays taxes, so you don't have to worry about complicated tax filings like in PMS.
3. Lock-in periods and exit fees can be negotiated, making it more investor-friendly.
4. NRIs find it simpler to invest in AIFs than PMS, which has complex rules for them.
5. AIFs offer access to unlisted shares, structured debt, and other special investments, helping diversify your portfolio and get better returns for the risk taken.

Did you know that today we celebrate National Space Day?

The simple truth: any journey, however long, begins with the willingness to take that first step. To look at the vast expanse of space and dare to imagine walking among the stars is the ultimate moonshot, the impossible made possible. If we dream and persist, outcomes become inevitable. The greatest distance we travel is not to the stars, but from doubt to possibility.

India's space story began not with grandeur, but with faith. Dr. Vikram Sarabhai, Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, and others looked beyond budgets and hierarchies. They believed extraordinary potential lived within Indian minds.

Whenlaunched Aryabhata in 1975, it showed that possibility knows no boundaries. The Chandrayaan missions proved what happens when a nation refuses to accept that greatness belongs only to the wealthy. And Mangalyaan? At $74 million, costing less than a Hollywood film, it placed India among the worldâ€™s leading space powers, proving smart thinking, not big spending, can reach Mars.

What makes Indiaâ€™s space journey extraordinary is how it was achieved:

â–¶ï¸ Using geography, launches from the east-coast harness Earthâ€™s rotation for efficiency
â–¶ï¸ Turning constraints into creativity, finding alternatives when resources were scarce
â–¶ï¸ Making collaboration a strength, scientists, entrepreneurs, and policymakers building together

Equally inspiring is the rise of women leaders:

â–¶ï¸ Ritu Karidhal, â€œRocket Woman of India,â€ key to Mangalyaan and Chandrayaan-2
â–¶ï¸ Muthayya Vanitha, the first woman project director of a lunar mission
â–¶ï¸ Nandini Harinath, scientist on 14+ missions
â–¶ï¸ Anuradha TK, among the first women to lead satellite projects
â–¶ï¸ Tessy Thomas, the â€œMissile Woman of India"

The global space economy is projected to reach $1 trillion by 2040. And India is shaping this future through visionary companies & remarkable leaders.

â–¶ï¸launched the first private Indian rocket.
â–¶ï¸is advancing propulsion.
â–¶ï¸is pioneering 3D-printed rocket engines.
â–¶ï¸, aportfolio company, is tackling orbital debris with space traffic management.

Momentum is matched by policy. Indiaâ€™s first dedicated space fund is not just capital; it institutionalizes belief. It connects research with markets, mentors with founders, and capital with bold ideas.

As we stand at this inflection point, space exploration reminds us it is ultimately about human exploration, our quest to understand our place in the cosmos & push beyond boundaries once thought permanent.

That is the meaning of National Space Day: not only a celebration of technology, but of the human spirit that transforms dreams into reality.

Dreams and nightmares have always fascinated humans and scientists. As they are said to be carrying hidden meanings and subconscious messages.

About 95% of dreams are forgotten within five minutes of waking up. But then, these aren't just random brain blips.

Did you know - we spend about 2 hours dreaming each night and an average person has 4-6 dreams per night? They can last anywhere from a few seconds to 20-30 minutes. And some people dream exclusively in black and white (about 12% of people).

Extensive work has been done over the years to decipher the purpose and power of dreams. While dreams can happen during various sleep stages, itâ€™s during REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep that the most vivid and surreal experiences unfold. Some studies even hint that dreaming plays a role in problem-solving and emotional processing, subtly helping us sort out our feelings and ideas overnight.

Scientists have explored a new frontier of the mind. They tried creating a dialogue between two peopleâ€™s dreams using advanced devices that track brain waves and monitor sleep patterns in real-time.

Hereâ€™s how it unfolded:

â¡ï¸ Participants in the experiment were fitted with equipment to track their brain activity and guide them through lucid dreaming.
â¡ï¸ During this state, scientists transmitted a word in a unique language called "Remmyo" to one participant.
â¡ï¸ Through monitoring and brain stimulation, they established a two-way communication channel, allowing dreamers to respond to questions and even influence each otherâ€™s dreams.

Imagine being able to relay a message mid-dream what could that mean for human connection and our understanding of shared subconscious experiences?

While weâ€™re not quite at the level of sharing full conversations or orchestrating shared dreamscapes like in the movie â€˜Inceptionâ€™, and god forbid manipulating dreams, this research cracks open the door to that possibility.

Makes me wonder if we could eventually download our dreams like movies.

Mathematician Ramanujan claimed that he solved many complex mathematical problems with answers received in his dreams.

Almost every venture capitalist is looking for that founder who â€˜dreams bigâ€™.

We often say Sweet dreams, without the benefit of the science of dreaming.

Many across India are familiar with the unique, divine taste of the Tirupati prasadam, a cherished gift from friends & family returning from the holy pilgrimage. Its special flavor is often attributed to the purity of its preparation and the sacred intention behind it. The Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) strictly controls the procurement of ingredients to maintain this unparalleled quality & taste, earning the unwavering trust of millions of devotees.

What many may not know is that one of its key ingredients is ghee from ğ˜•ğ˜¢ğ˜¯ğ˜¥ğ˜ªğ˜¯ğ˜ª, the beloved dairy brand from Karnataka. The familiar blue-&-white packet in our refrigerator is a part of the everyday rituals.

But before Nandini , milk was scarce, farmers trapped in poverty, & the state was importing milk powder, a bitter irony for a land dotted with cattle.

In 1974, the Karnataka Dairy Development Corporation (KDDC) was launched to fix that. By 1983, the brand â€˜Nandiniâ€™ was born. A year later, KDDC became the Karnataka Milk Federation (KMF).

The obstacles were daunting: Rocky terrain. Scattered farms. No cold chains. Yet, the cooperative model took root.

Today, Nandini is Indiaâ€™s second-largest dairy cooperative:
â€¢ â‚¹17,000+ crore turnover (FY 2023)
â€¢ 2.6 M farmers
â€¢ 26,000+ village-level societies
â€¢ ~8.5 M litres of milk collected daily

And itâ€™s not just milk. Nandini now offers 18 product categories: ghee, paneer, curd, sweets, flavored milk, chocolate, butter, ice cream, eco-friendly milk packets & cattle feed.

Quality? Every litre undergoes multi-stage testing for adulteration, antibiotics & spoilage at the source and chilling plants. Theyâ€™ve earned the trust of millions by not cutting corners.

In 2020, when COVID crashed milk prices, private players slashed what they paid farmers. Nandini didnâ€™t. They kept paying full rates, absorbing losses to protect livelihoods. When we put people first, we build systems that endure.

Some curious facts:
â€¢ Nandini pioneered biodegradable packaging in Bengaluru
â€¢ Vertical milk pouch expansion (1.05L at proportional cost)  a consumer-first move
â€¢ Its brand value is now $1.079 billion, among Indiaâ€™s top 5 F&B names
â€¢ Farmers are paid directly and fairly, earnings are insulated from market volatility

Thereâ€™s no single â€œfounder,â€ but generations of rural leaders, policymakers, and cooperative members made this success possible.

A few months ago, Prada walked Kolhapuri chappals down the runway at Milan. The global fashion world gasped, rushing to buy a pair. Meanwhile, most Indians have a pair of these in their home, wondering what the sudden global interest is all about.

When trends hijack our wallets and feeds, are we really buying value, or simply responding to stimuli? I am firmly convinced, it is the stimuli, and however vigilant, I am being manipulated every day through algorithms pushing products and content at me.

A recent Stanford study of 35,000+ people found that deactivating Facebook or Instagram for just six weeks led to:
âœ… A 4% increase in people reporting they felt â€œhappy often.â€
âœ… Significant drops in anxiety and depression.
âœ… Well-being gains comparable to those offered by 15â€“22% of cognitive therapy.
âœ… The most significant boost for women under 25.

Even when many switched to other apps, they still felt better. It wasnâ€™t screen time, it was about the addictive content we consume.

So hereâ€™s the deeper question Iâ€™ve been mulling over: What are we actually buying into? We like to believe weâ€™re making choices. But more often, weâ€™re reacting to stimuli: powerful, repetitive, emotional nudges that speak to our primal need to belong. Itâ€™s a complex cocktail of belonging, identity, aspiration, and the primal desire to be part of the tribe.

Itâ€™s the same reason animals display feathers, scents, or rituals. To establish dominance, attract food, acceptance into the pack or win the female.

Weâ€™re not so different. We just use avocado toast and reels instead of mating calls. And even when we know weâ€™re being manipulated, we smile for the photo, add a filter, and post it anyway.

The real irony? I hate matcha, but I swear by avocado toast. And yes, Iâ€™ve probably posted about the perfect avocado toast more than once. So even when we think we are above one mad trend, we are probably adding to another.

We're all in it, the smart, the mindful, the skeptical. Sometimes, the only choice left is to laugh at our own patterns. and occasionally unplug and ask: â€œIs this truly me or just my reaction to the feed?â€

This picture, by the way, is Avacado from my backyard, on fresh sourdough, sprinkled with Zatar and Sumac. It is a great breakfast.

Back in 2014, Christopher Nolanâ€™s Interstellar painted a future where humanity reaches for the stars in search of survival.

Once the space economy was for Isac Asimov books (any Foundation fans?) and sci-fi movies. But if you look at the numbers today, itâ€™s a trillion-dollar reality. The future is unfolding as an empire-building mission.

From asteroid mining to lunar colonies, from space tourism to interplanetary internet, the race is on. But what are we really chasing? Expansion or escape?

SpaceX is aiming for a human mission to Mars by 2027, while NASAâ€™s Artemis program is sketching blueprints for a sustainable lunar base by the 2030s. The safe return of astronauts Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore from extended missions reaffirms that human endurance in space is no longer a barrier.

Space tourism is moving from fiction books to reality. Virgin Galactic has already sold 800+ tickets at $450,000 a piece.

Space-based solar power could reshape the energy industry, beaming limitless renewable energy from space to Earth, too. I met companies interested in putting large datacenters in space, bringing a new reality to cloud computing by putting it literally in the cloud! This could transform latency, security, and global connectivity, reshaping our digital experiences radically.

Meanwhile, the billionaires may become trillionaires on space opportunity. Asteroid mining, once a thought experiment, is now an industry in the making with 700 quintillion dollars worth of metals floating in the abyss waiting to be claimed.

Thereâ€™s also a silent crisis that is building above us. More than 34,000 pieces of space debris are orbiting Earth. They are threatening satellites and future missions.

-backeddelivers accurate and real-time orbital insights to ensure safer space operations, whereas startups likeandare racing to clean up before orbital traffic spirals out of control.

But as technology accelerates, a larger question looms: who owns space?

The Outer Space Treaty of 1967 was written when the Moon landing was still a dream. Today, private companies and nations are testing their limits, setting the stage for geopolitical tensions beyond Earthâ€™s atmosphere. The next space race seems all about control.

One thing is certain: the cosmos is the next frontier of ambition, greed, and survival.
We left footprints on the Moon, but our hearts stayed Earthbound. Are we explorers, or just wanderers chasing power?

Can you read this? It might just be a life-saving skill. It spells: Morse Code.

Most of us have heard of Morse Code but rarely think about its relevance. Itâ€™s that language of dots and dashes that was the worldâ€™s first binary communication system long before computers and 1s and 0s.

Invented in the 1830s by Samuel Morse, it was originally designed for the telegraph. Before telephones existed, this was our first instant messaging system for long distances.

At its heart, itâ€™s deceptively simple:
Dot (Â·) = one unit of time
Dash (â€“) = three units
Pauses between letters and words are coded too. But its impact? Anything but simple.

In 1844, Samuel Morse sent the first long-distance message:
â€œWhat hath God wroughtâ€
.-- .... .- - / .... .- - .... / --. --- -.. / .-- .-. --- ..- --. .... -
between Washington and Baltimore.

In 1901, the first transatlantic message wasnâ€™t a letter or a phone call, it was Morse Code, beamed from the US to Europe, bouncing off the atmosphere.

SOS (Â·Â·Â· â€“â€“â€“ Â·Â·Â·) became the universal distress signal, famously used by the Titanic.
NASA has used Morse Code for deep-space communications where standard radio transmissions struggle.

Though no longer mandatory for maritime operators, Morse Code is far from dead. It thrives among ham radio enthusiasts. Why? It cuts through static better than voice. Needs minimal power. Can be tapped, flashed, or even blinked.

There are thousands of amateur radio clubs worldwide. Many host Morse practice nets, competitions to see who can decode fastest, and even classes for newcomers.

Why would anyone still use it?
1. Emergencies: When voice fails, a flashlight or tapping can say SOS.
2. Military survival training: Soldiers learn to blink or tap messages when captured.
3. Tech inspiration: Morse was the original compression system, paving the way for digital code.

A fun fact: In the United States, the final commercial Morse code transmission was on July 12, 1999. It signed off poetically with Morseâ€™s original message: â€œWhat hath God wrought.â€

Remember Interstellar? A watch transmits Morse to solve a vital equation that saves humanity. Morse reminds us that not all systems need to be complex. Sometimes simple, elegant, and usable is exactly what you need.

For funâ€”can you decode these?
.... . .-.. .-.. --- / ..-. .-. --- -- / -.- .- .- .-.. .- .- .-. ..

--. . -. .. ..- ...
And hereâ€™s a classic:
143 â€“ a popular Morse shorthand â¤ï¸
Drop your answers in the comments!
Hint: Iâ€™m no genius, just a fan with a Morse translator!

At its IPO in 1986, Microsoft generated $61 million in annual revenue with a market capitalization of $777 million. Today, Microsoftâ€™s most recent quarterly revenue (Q3 FY25) is over $70 billion. Its full-year revenue for 2024 was $236.6 billion. And its market capitalization now sits around $3.6 trillion.

For companies, there is often only growth or decline.

Think of BlackBerry or Nokia. Once market leaders. Now largely irrelevant.

Revenue is one measure of growth, but the underlying drivers that translate to future revenue are much more multifaceted.

So how should we evaluate growth? Revenue alone is not an indicative metric.

Current market share or dominance doesnâ€™t promise longevity.

What matters is whatâ€™s deeper, harder to measure, but essential to the future.

The brand is another important metric for every business. It buys time, trust, and resilience.

You donâ€™t need to know Amulâ€™s revenue to trust and buy their products. Itâ€™s in every kitchen, across generations. For the record, Amul is aiming to become a â‚¹1 trillion brand by 2025-26. Thatâ€™s legacy in motion.

We often default to metrics we can track:
* Revenue
* User Acquisition
* Valuation Milestones
* Market Share

Structural growth is about discipline, reach, reliability, & scale. Think why you buy from brands like Amazon, TATA, or LIC.

You may or may not love these brands, but you use them. Thatâ€™s a value metric; operational excellence & trust in the service make them essential.

Then there are brands like boAt. It didnâ€™t chase premium positioning. It understood the youth mindset. Durable, stylish, affordable products paired with clever, lifestyle-first marketing.

Growth isnâ€™t a single thing. Itâ€™s both the visible & the invisible. The numbers you share in decks, validated by accountants. But what the customers say about you is the story behind those numbers. The intangibles that translate to future revenue.

Compounding growth is based on strong numbers today and investing in new markets and technologies for tomorrow. Taking bold risks in an ever-changing world should be part of an organisationâ€™s DNA.

My job as a VC is less about valuing todayâ€™s metrics & more about understanding the intangibles that drive the possibility of exponential growth.

When I hear your story, I want to hear the past, the present, & the future.

The ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜€ğ˜ is why you started this company; what problem or insight sparked the journey?

The ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ is how youâ€™ve translated that idea into action; what youâ€™ve built, delivered, and earned customer trust.

The ğ—³ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² is how you see compounding your business; how youâ€™ll grow markets, deepen moats, and create lasting value.

And that story has to address what truly drives growth for your business. Why investing now is likely to create compounding returns in the years ahead.

What do you think about growth? Would love to hear your take.

"OfBusiness is not a business, it's a Cash Printing Machine.." 

..words that a seasoned VC who'd make >1000x investment return on it, told me last month.

Most founders talk revenue, growth, valuation, burn - high energy at length..

But very few I've met, talk "real levers" for cash-printing scale with 3-4 levels depth

Knowing numbers isnâ€™t same as talking key levers, ratios, & their probabilities.

Take an example of Lenskart.
Everyone sees >$5B valuation. But the boring part..

1. Avg receivables in last 5 yrs: From 150 days â†’ 30 days. âœ“Cash collects fast

2. Avg payables: From 40 daysâ†’130+ days. âœ“Cash leaves slow

3. Inventory â‰  Guesswork.
~99.5% accuracy across 1100+ stores, daily track. âœ“Zero waste, leaks.

4. High Margins = Only Reality.
EPO (Earnings Per Order) Obsession.

5. Data is religion. Every click, each footfall, returns, reviews, vs peer KPIs?
âœ“Measured. Optimized. Compounded.

Results?
Â» Add ~â‚¹2K Cr new revenue each yr in last 3 yrs, FY24 ~â‚¹5.4K Cr rev (15% profit)
Â» Cash on books: ~â‚¹600 Cr!

PB didnâ€™t just raise funding. He built a machine to multiply capital, & print cash.

Similar
who've also built cash printing machines? OfBusiness, Groww, Astrotalk, Infoedge,..

â€º Hereâ€™s 5 quick levers & ratios the best founders master, & rest learn too late:

â€¢ Rule of 40 = Revenue Growth % + EBITDA %
âœ“ Healthy? >40% , Below? Burn to die.

â€¢ Cohort Retention: If your Day 30, 60, 90 retention looks like a cliff.. leaky bucket.

â€¢ Burn Multiple = Net Burn / Net New ARR.
âœ“ Steady? < 1.5x , Deadly? > 2.5x .

â€¢ Gross Margin per Employee = Total GM pool / Headcount.
âœ“ Benchmark to your global mkt leader. Bloated teams = Shrinking margins.

â€¢ Growth Efficiency Index (GEI) = Net New ARR / Sales & Marketing Spend
âœ“ Healthy >0.75 , Elite >1 , Below 0.5 = buying growth, not earning it.

Revenue is vanity. EBITDA is sanity. Cash flow is reality.

Founders that print cash, chase levers.
VCs that print cash, chase masters of levers.

Some places leave you inspired not just by their scale but by the sheer vision and execution behind them. Vantara is one such place. 

Built with the purpose of rescuing and rehabilitating endangered and distressed animals, Vantara is spread over 3,500 acres, supported by a team of 3,700 expertsâ€”veterinarians, biologists, naturalists, dieticians, caretakers, feeders, and admin staff.

The scale is staggering. 105 cheetahs, 1,000 crocodiles, 400 elephants, and thousands of other species call this sanctuary home.

Imagine driving through landscapes where cheetahs and zebras move freely around your vehicle, a sight reminiscent of the African jungles.

The logistics behind this effort are mind-blowingâ€”over 300 cargo planes transported animals from different parts of the world.

With 45+ medical facilities, the center offers endoscopies, X-rays, blood tests, and even performed cataract surgery on an elephant.

Every detail is meticulously managedâ€”birds and animals have customized diet charts, fruits are hand-cut to ensure quality, and each enclosure has a QR code system for real-time updates by doctors, trainers, and feeders.

Among the many animalsâ€”lions, tigers, rhinos, reptiles, fishes, dogs, and moreâ€”two that stood out for me were the Cassowary bird and the majestic Indian Akhal-Teke horse, both rare and stunning in their own way.

But what truly sets Vantara apart is its vision. Itâ€™s one thing to say, â€œI will build the worldâ€™s largest zoo,â€ simply scaling up an existing concept.

But to imagine and create one of the worldâ€™s largest animal rescue centers, from scratch, requires an entirely different level of thinking.

If you ever want to expand your imagination, see what vision backed by execution can achieve, then Anant Ambani's Vantara is the place!

40 LPA job offer means 3 Lakh monthly salary, right? 

WRONG.

Hereâ€™s why.

Most freshers donâ€™t understand the difference between CTC and in-hand salary.

Here's an example of what your 40 LPA job offer actually looks like.

- Base salary: 12 Lakhs
- Joining bonus: 6 Lakhs
- Employee Stock Option Plan (ESOPs): 15 Lakhs
- Performance bonus: 4 Lakhs
- Retention bonus: 1 Lakh
- Allowances: 2 Lakhs

Letâ€™s break down each component:

- Base salary: in-hand salary (1L/month, 85k post tax).
- Joining bonus: one-time, only for the 1st year.
- ESOPs: equity shares of the company are given.
- Performance bonus: for achieving all target metrics.
- Retention bonus: given when you stay for 1 or 2 years.
- Allowances: include meal vouchers and travel claims.

Green flags in your finances mean green lights in your love life.

I'm grateful that my relationship with CA Deepak Bhati is financially healthy, but I know that many couples struggle with red flags.

Talking about finances can be difficult, but it's important to do it. Financial problems are one of the leading causes of divorce, and these red flags are the reasons why:

- They refuse to talk about finances. This is a big red flag. If your partner is unwilling to discuss finances with you, it's a sign that they may be hiding something. Or, it could mean that they're not very good at managing their money.

- They hide their spending habits. If your partner is always making excuses for why they can't show you their receipts, or if they're constantly buying new things without telling you, it's a sign that they're not being honest with you about their spending.

- Gambling problems or any other addiction that is expensive. If your partner has a gambling problem or any other addiction that is expensive, it can put a huge strain on your finances. It's important to talk to your partner about their addiction and get them help if needed.

- They are in charge of the money. If your partner is in charge of the money and you have no access to it, it's a red flag. This could mean that they're controlling your finances or that they're not being transparent with you about how they're spending your money.

- They have zero concern for their or your financial future. If your partner doesn't save for retirement or if they're constantly racking up debt, it's a sign that they're not thinking about the future. This could lead to financial problems down the road.

If you see any of these red flags in your relationship, it's important to talk to your partner about them.

And if you're lucky enough to have a financially green-flag relationship like mine, cherish it! Financial compatibility is one of the most important factors in a successful relationship.

12 years ago, I lived near a dump in Laxmi Nagar, Delhi. There were often cockroaches in my house.

To go to office: I would walk to Akshardham Metro station. And, the line would stretch (sometimes) even outside the station during peak office hours.

To beat this traffic, I would leave early, carry a physical book. I read 1 book every week standing/sitting in a metro. That's how I learnt to read fast.

I stayed back at my office for as long as possible & prepared for GMAT (so that I didn't have to come back home to a dump). Did this for 1.5 years: and, I ended up getting a 99th%ile, the highest achievable score.

I had no real plans of applying to study abroad. I just couldn't afford it (I wanted to but couldn't afford). But, I knew that if I aced the GMAT, I could teach foreign clients, who would pay well.

99th percentile score gave that ticket. So I started teaching. Got some private clients. And, I moved to a better place.

Life started changing bit-by-bit: my student (who was applying for an Executive MBA) encouraged me to apply abroad. So I did. And, got into some of the best programs with scholarships.

At 26, I took my first international flight. And, I moved to Singapore. I saw what better life was. No one in my family had travelled abroad up-to this point.

Here is the most important lesson I learnt along the way:-

You are responsible for your own life. The day you start assigning responsibility to others to improve "your" life, is the day you lose control.

India is ranked 4th on GDP. But, Singapore is ranked 27th. 
So is India richer than Singapore? 

Here is a quick backstory:-

By 2047, we will be a 40 Tr$ economy.
And, by this point, we will be a developed economy.

This is a matter of great celebration. NO DOUBT.
And, we should be proud.

Having said this, if you look around, you will find that India ranks around 140th on GDP/Capita. No one seems to even talk about this number (like ever!).

This means that while India is growing GDP wise, an 'average' Indian is still quite poor.

Question comes WHY?

[1] Our GDP comes from domestic consumption, not exports. For decades we have run, trade deficit, not trade surplus (i.e we import more and export less)

[2] Singapore on the other hand, runs a trade surplus. In 2021 for example, they had a trade surplus of 126Bn$, which is almost 32% of their GDP.

[3] Interestingly, Japan, Germany, China (three countries which are ahead of us in terms of GDP), all run trade surplus (generally)

US is the only exception that runs a trade deficit (like India). But, they are a special case as they hold the reserve currency.

They can print their fake money and buy real goods from the world to the extent they want. And, still not cause a panic.

So to cut the long-story short, I don't know if India is richer than Singapore. May be it is, may be it is not.

Logically speaking, I don't know if a country can truly become rich without running a trade surplus.

Even if we look at history, this holds true. For 1700 years, India controlled 25-33% of world's wealth. Even during this phase, India was a net exporter of finished good.

Point is: Economics is complex. And, I am giving you all this info, so that you can understand the picture more holistically.

My goal is promote rational thinking. As this is becoming a dying art in the times of fake media narratives.

Gold canâ€™t be created or destroyed. Thatâ€™s why itâ€™s been valuable for thousands of years.

Itâ€™s 2025 and people are buying gold like crazy as an investment. But hereâ€™s something most donâ€™t know:

Modern physics can actually make gold in labs. For example, at CERNâ€™s Large Hadron Collider, smashing lead together creates tiny bits of gold. But itâ€™s not something we can do at scale or cheaply yet.

The game-changer? Nuclear fusion.

A US startup, Marathon Fusion, says their fusion reactors can turn mercury into gold by hitting it with neutrons. This could produce tons of gold for every gigawatt of fusion power. Suddenly, fusion energy is not just clean powerâ€”itâ€™s a gold factory.

AI is growing at 25%+ CAGR
Generational wealth is being built in AI. 

If you invest in AI firms in 2025: you will either build massive wealth or you will wipe out 90% of your capital. So which one is it?

Many are comparing the current AI revolution (2025) to DotCom bubble (early 2000s)

- VCs were running after DotCom firms. Same now with AI.
- Governments running to build DotCom infra (fibre optics, research etc) -- same now with AI.
- Businesses pivoting to DotCom. Same now with AI.

So will the AI revolution end like the DotCom crash?

My answer is a NO.

Reason: during the DotCom bubble, there was massive inflation of supply infrastructure. Here is an important paragraph you should read:-

By early 2000s: Telecom companies raised almost $2 trillion in equity and $600 billion in debtâ€”much of this capital was spent building more than 80 million miles of fiber optic cable in the U.S. alone. By 2005, as much as 85% of those cables were still unused (â€œdark fiberâ€). This led to plummeting bandwidth prices and eventually, serious financial losses and bankruptcies in the telecom sector.

The supply was built well ahead of the demand.

Demand << supply

What about 2025? NVIDIA is selling out its entire inventory in months. There is not enough supply yet. M7 and LLMs are demanding faster compute.

Demand >> supply

AI is still the foremost play in investing right now.
Nations are going AI first.
As an investor, you should go AI first too.

I am building a portfolio for my kids. And, it is based on 1 fundamental truth:- 

"Technology supremacy leads to economic supremacy".

We have seen this since the start of human civilization.

Here is a 5 sentence crash course:-

Consider the first major civilization: Sumerians. They excelled at Engineering Hydraulics and Copper weapons. Akkadians, replaced them: who built more advanced weaponry and irrigation systems. Fast forward: Romans, Egyptians, Dutch, Spanish, British, India (during its Golden Age), all had tech supremacy.

So comes the question: who holds tech supremacy in 2025?

- Grok/Gemini/Open AI is competing for AI (LLM) supremacy.
- Waymo/Tesla competing for self driving cars
- Meta is creating a 3D world.
- US is building a crypto reserve (despite their currency dominating 85%+ forex).
- Space X/Rocket Lab: getting closer to space exploration.
- CRISPER/Intellia/BEAM dominating gene editing.

Most of these are public companies in which you can invest today.

Will Chinese firms replace these? I don't know. Maybe. But, there is no sensible structure to invest in Chinese firms. Eg. Huawei and DeepSeek (two Crown Jewels) of China-- you can't really invest.

So if your building a portfolio for kids: give them high quality firms that are likely to be leaders of the tech world.

This is the simplest (yet most powerful) investment thesis.

The best way to learn investing is to invest. 

1) Start with 1% of your net-worth. Pick up the challenge of investing it in the markets.

2) In year 1: take the challenge of NOT losing this money. Even if you make 0% returns, it is fine.

Buy Index, buy some bluechips. Read, iterate. Take courses, read books.

3) In year 2: go a level deeper. Try rotating your capital. If you see gains, bring 5% of your net worth in the market. Again, don't worry about returns.

4) In year 3&4: figure YOUR style of investing. Do you trade well? Do you sing trade? Are you investing long-term? Are you buying growth vs value? Should you trade options etc.

5) Time & your experiences are your best teacher.

Most people don't learn investing because its painful.

But, the cost of NOT learning how to invest is the lifelong commission that you end up paying.

And, this really adds up, if you do the math -- you will see. (But, most people would be too lazy to run this math).

Let's admit it-- no one taught us how to spend money. 
For most of us: our parents came from humble backgrounds.

Seeing them save money constantly, rubbed on us.
And, it shaped our world view.

Many of us carried those lessons into our adulthood.
And, became lifelong savers.

I am a case study: I honestly, can spend a lot of money now.
But, I think thrice before buying a 250Rs Greek Yogurt.
(Of course I buy it now, but that change took time)

I was coached to "save"
So I became a "saver".

But, there was another breed of humans, who grew alongside with us.
Let's call them "spenders"

They got influenced far more than us with fast cars, flashy phones and big houses. Instagram played its role in fanning those desires.

It changed the core of who they were.
I'm not judging. As there is no right answer to "how much should you spend"

Saying things like: "oh, spend within your limits", begets the question: what is the "limit"?

You can't carry your wealth in your afterlife. So the American way of borrowing & dying kind of appeals to me. It looks logical.

But, it also brings the stress of carrying the burden of debt: when you are alive and kicking.

So the answer to spending is not really: how much you should spend?
The answer really is: how much stress do you wish to take when you are alive?

The cost of spending is the loss of freedom.
Seems poetic. Because it is.

Forget Silicon Valley. Googleâ€™s next big bet could be users in Nagpur. Or Mumbai. Or Kolhapur.

GenZ is abandoning Google in the US, and it may just mean that India becomes the biggest market for the search engine giant. Hereâ€™s my hypothesis.

According to data by Forbes and TechCrunch, GenZ is now using platforms like TikTok, Reddit, YouTube and Pinterest to search for and discover products.

The reason? They value trusted, authentic content over sponsored results.
People are saying Google will slowly lose market share in the search category.

But hereâ€™s whatâ€™s getting missed: this shift isnâ€™t happening everywhere.
In India, the story is very different, and it might just define Google's future.

Hereâ€™s why.

Out of the 4 platforms mentioned,

- TikTok has zero users in India. Which means it has no impact on Google search

- Reddit has 10x more users in the US than in India. The migration (when it happens) will not even be a drop in the ocean for Google

- YouTube is owned by Google, and India has nearly double the number of YouTube users compared to USA (491 million vs 253 million).

Add to it, Indiaâ€™s massgive GenZ population and cheap data - and it becomes clear that Googleâ€™s fastest-growing user base could be not California, but Vizag, Bhubaneshwar or Bhopal.

What do you think? Will India be Google's major focus?

As I write this on a Sunday morning, I can't help but be appalled at how cruel our society has become.

The latest controversy with Andy Byron and Kristin Cabot from Astronomer has already ruined two families. But here we are, adding fuel to the fire.

Some say that the two deserve the backlash for cheating on their partners. And I'm not here to debate whether or not they do.

But their families?

Do they deserve this mockery?

Imagine being in their place. Imagine your partner was caught cheating in a Coldplay concert and went viral on the intenet. And imagine that private pain become a public spectacle - An incident that was made into thousands of memes.

Every scroll you do brings fresh jokes, heated debates, and wild accusations.

And it doesn't stop there. The media circles like vultures throughout the day. And then they write articles that dig into your personal life.

All of this while you're reeling with the biggest shock of your life - that your partner, someone you raised your kids with - is cheating on you.

What's worse? Even brands joined this circus. One company made a "funny video" about how their tool helped Astronomer's employees get more productive, which gave the CEO and HR head more time to "fraternise".

Not cool, man.

Where is our collective EQ? When did mockery become entertainment? And how and when did we become so insensitive as a race?

Iâ€™m not saying people shouldn't be held accountable. But letâ€™s not forget the collateral damage. Behind every meme that we're using to entertain ourselves for 2 seconds, there are two families grieving.

If nothing else, letâ€™s stop turning someoneâ€™s worst moment into punchlines for likes!

- Flawless grammar
- Clear structure, and
- Zero independent thought

If youâ€™re from a middle-class Indian family and donâ€™t have a fancy college degree, your margin for error is very low. And chances for building wealth, lower.

- You canâ€™t quit your job to chase your passion.
- You canâ€™t throw money at risky ideas.
- You canâ€™t afford to â€œfind yourself.â€

Because ğ’”ğ’ğ’ğ’†ğ’ğ’ğ’† out there depends on you. A parent. A spouse. A kid. Or all of them.

And so you work hard. You save. You stay safe.

But playing safe rarely builds real wealth.

So what do you do when you canâ€™t take big risks?

1) Join an early-stage startup with ESOPs. Yes, your salary may be lower than peers. But if the startup takes off, you win big.

2) Build content on something you know deeply. No need to quit your job. Just 1 hour a day. The internet has 5.5 billion people who can consume your content. Over time, it all compounds.

3) Learn to invest better. A 2.5% higher return than your peers can mean 40â€“50% more wealth in the long-term.

In all of this, if you lose, you lose about 10-15%. But if you win, you quadruple your wealth.

These things sound small. But thatâ€™s the point - theyâ€™re doable. And they stack up.

We may not have generational wealth. But we do have one thing: Hunger.

Our job is to build that springboard our parents never had.

Entrepreneurship cost me more than I imagined - I thought I was just risking a few years of salary. But I didn't realise I was risking decades of financial compounding. And a part of myself.

While I did consider â€œnot earning any salary for a few yearsâ€ as the worst case scenario before starting, no one told me about the compounding cost of entrepreneurship. Had I continued to get a salary and continued my SIPs, I'd be sitting on a 7-figure boost to my net worth today, only from the investment returns.

And thatâ€™s a problem - With entrepreneurship, no one tells you that even if you return to a job, youâ€™ll most likely earn lesser than your peers. Because sadly, the Indian job market is still anchored to your â€œlast drawn salary.â€ Two years as a founder can set you back way more than you realise.

No one tells you how it rewires your brain. I used to leave work on time back in 2019-2020, and have a life after. But Jackfruit kind of made me a workaholic. Now on some weekends, I get anxious if I havenâ€™t opened my laptop.

That shift..feels permanent.

But do I regret starting up? Absolutely not! The experience I gained is priceless!

I only wish someone had told me that the opportunity cost of starting up isnâ€™t just your salary. Itâ€™s a lot more - money, mental health, and living with the sting of watching your peers stay ahead, for a large part of your career.

Iâ€™d have been better prepared then.

My advice to new entrepreneurs would be - If you're planning to start something, go in with eyes wide open. Whatâ€™s your real worst-case scenario? Have you mapped it completely?

Letâ€™s talk about the things you donâ€™t get warned about.

If you hate (or have hated) your manager because all they do is take meetings and reviews, then this post is for you. Just hear me out, and maybe youâ€™ll get a different perspective.

I was talking to a friend the other day. Both of us have had a similar career trajectory - about 12/13 years of working, started as an individual contributor, then got a small team, and now leading an entire function.

She has the exact same schedule as me - Our day starts and ends with meetings. We barely get time to work on our individual stuff because most part of the day, weâ€™re working on guiding the team, taking reviews of ongoing projects, planning the teamâ€™s next sprint/calendar/project, putting out fires, and ensuring that folks in the team get along with each other.

All of this, while being on top of everything so that at any point, we know exactly whatâ€™s going on in our function..

At times I feel like Iâ€™ve been hit by some memory loss disease, because I donâ€™t remember something that my teammate told me 2 days ago. Then I realise that there are 199 other things I had as well, and my brain has only a finite capacity after all.

The funny part is - All of this comprises just one line in our 2-pager job description - â€œManage and mentor the team to achieve their goalsâ€

Now, most people think that the only thing managers do is â€œtake meetings and reviewsâ€. But thatâ€™s how theyâ€™re supposed to do their job, isnâ€™t it?

As a manager, a lot of times I crave for the work I used to do as an Individual Contributor - writing content, analyzing data from performance campaigns, or just designing something cool on Canva. Unfortunately, I canâ€™t do all of that now because of all these â€œother thingsâ€.

I used to think it gets easier as you move up the ladder. But the middle of the ladder is crazy - Youâ€™re neither at the top to focus your energy only on strategy, nor are you at the bottom to just focus on your own tasks. Youâ€™re supposed to do both. And that needs a massive amount of context switching, which drains your energy.

Okay, no. This isnâ€™t a post cribbing about life as a manager. Itâ€™s about putting out thoughts from that perspective, so that teams can empathise with their managers.

Do I miss my work as an individual contributor? Of course I do! Because as a manager, you rarely create stuff on your own - you mostly enable the team to do it.

But do I dislike being a manager? Absolutely not. The satisfaction of grooming younger folks, taking game-changing decisions, and just making the entire machine run, hits differently.

Like Monica says - It sucks. But youâ€™re gonna love it ğŸ˜‰

Everyoneâ€™s talking about AI taking jobs. But hereâ€™s what nobody talks about - ğ€ğˆ ğ°ğ¢ğ¥ğ¥ ğšğœğ­ğ®ğšğ¥ğ¥ğ² ğœğ«ğğšğ­ğ ğ¦ğ¨ğ«ğ ğ¨ğ©ğ©ğ¨ğ«ğ­ğ®ğ§ğ¢ğ­ğ¢ğğ¬ ğ­ğ¡ğšğ§ ğ¢ğ­ ğğğ¬ğ­ğ«ğ¨ğ²ğ¬. Sounds counterintuitive? Let me explain..

Today, AI agents are automating end-to-end processes. And tasks that used to take weeks now take a couple of hours.

This means faster delivery. Which also means lesser people needed to do the same job.

Which in turn means that if you needed a team of 20 to solve a problem earlier, youâ€™ll now just need a team of, maybe 3.

â€œWell, youâ€™re telling me stuff I already know. How does this create more opportunities?â€ you ask?

Well, hereâ€™s where things get interesting - Very small, niche problems that were not economically feasible to solve because of high manpower costs, suddenly become viable, thanks to AI.

So weâ€™ll now be able to see extremely niche problems being solved at a fraction of the cost.

Think of a loan recovery platform running with just an AI agent that calls small-ticket loan defaulters and converses with them for repayment. Such a company will need only 5 employees because they have an AI program that can work 24x7.

Or an AI-based legal tech platform that can draft basic legal agreements based on inputs given to it, in minutes. It will need a couple of senior lawyers to handle more complex agreements, but all basic agreements can be done with AI.

Or a personal AI agent that tracks an individualâ€™s health and suggests them steps to get fitter, every day.

All these (small ticket loan recovery, legal agreements, personalised healthcare assistants) are problems that startups could not solve till now because they needed a lot of manual effort, and the revenue was not in proportion to the manpower cost.

But now, AI agents take care of all this. At scale.

Which means, weâ€™ll see a lot of niche use cases being solved by AI - New business cases that we never saw till today will emerge.

And yet, nobody is talking about this. The narrative is still around how "AI will take jobs".

Well, itâ€™s going to be a fascinating world to live in, and Iâ€™m super excited to see what the future holds.

Thereâ€™s a constant narrative these days that people will now need to retire by 45, because there wonâ€™t be enough jobs for them after that. But I donâ€™t think itâ€™s true - thereâ€™s a lot more nuance to it.

If we look at knowledge and experience required in a job, some roles require more knowledge and hard skills, than experience or soft skills. Think graphic designing. Analytics. Accounting.

In such jobs, obviously youâ€™ll get better with experience, but the improvement will probably be marginal, not exponential.

Other jobs that donâ€™t depend on hard skills per se, are the ones that need something more.

Think Sales. Consultancy. Project management.

These roles require an interplay of people skills, conflict resolution, teamwork, effective communication and more.

These are not things that can be learnt from books, YouTube or LinkedIn. Theyâ€™re things that need you to understand how people behave in different situations.

They need ğğ±ğ©ğğ«ğ¢ğğ§ğœğ.

So, yes. Itâ€™s going to be difficult to look for jobs after say, 40. But to say that people will now retire at 45 is an exaggeration, honestly.

I donâ€™t think the value of experience has gone down just yet. It probably never will.

If youâ€™re a 30-something whoâ€™s worried about this though, the best way to deal with it is to look for roles that need soft skills more than hard skills - that way, your journey will be much more easier :)

The Nifty has fallen by almost 12% since its all-time high, and people are panicking. But what if I told you that it happens every year, and is nothing new?

No, this isnâ€™t technical analysis. Hear me out.

If youâ€™ve read â€œOne up on wall streetâ€, by Peter Lynch, he mentions about the average stock fluctuation every year. And I was intrigued to see how true it was.

So I did an analysis of Nifty 50 for 23 years (January 2000 till December 2022). I captured the yearly high and low for each year, and calculated the fluctuation between both.

He lost â‚¹15,000 on his very first stock.

He took a â‚¹75 Lakh home loan when his salary was just â‚¹15 Lakhs.

Is it possible to turn a â‚¹4 lakh investment into a $90,000 starting salary?

For many Indian CAs dreaming of a global career, this isn't just a question, it's the entire game plan.

In my latest podcast, I sat down with(CA, CPA), who made this exact journey from Mumbai to PwC in New York. We went beyond the dream and crunched the actual numbers behind the US CPA pathway.

Hereâ€™s the real, unfiltered breakdown:

ğŸ’° The Investment: The total cost for the CPA, including exam fees and good coaching, comes to about â‚¹3.5 - 4 lakhs.

ğŸ“ˆ The Immediate ROI: A starting salary in a major US city like New York can range from $80,000 - $90,000 (~â‚¹70 Lakhs). In India, a CPA can expect a starting package of â‚¹12-15 lakhs.

â° The Challenge: Itâ€™s a race against time. You have just 18 months to clear all 4 tough sections once you pass your first one.

ğŸ—½ The Reality Check: That high salary comes with high expenses. Mohit shared that rent alone in NYC can be $2,500/month (over â‚¹2 Lakhs!), and a simple lunch can cost $20.

But the most valuable stat he shared wasn't about money. It was about the visa. He revealed how the L1A inter-company transfer can lead to a green card in just ~3 years, bypassing the 15-20 year wait that many face on an H1B visa.

Seeing the numbers laid out like this is powerful. But as Mohit wisely pointed out, the numbers only get you in the door. Itâ€™s your performance, your adaptability, and your leadership that truly build a long-term global career.

A huge thank you to Mohit for such a transparent, data-packed session. If you want the full story behind these numbers, this episode is a must-watch.

What New York taught me? 

1. Work Life Balance â€“ people start working early, and want to end work early. Having personal time is given a big priority. Mostly, people will start at 8.30 / 9 AM and end their day by 5.30 / 6 PM, so that they can have their personal time too. Most of the people I met used to get free by evening, and did not work on weekends at all.

2. Small Talks â€“ I think a lot of people indulge into small talks, and people are very approachable. It is very easy to start a conversation with anyone in a subway train, or a bus, or on the street because of the open culture. I made 2 friends when I was in a subway while going to Manhattan, and they guided me where to get down etc. as I was new in the city.

3. Being independent â€“ you have to do almost everything on your own, right from filling the fuel in your car to cleaning the car from inside, to washing your clothes, to cooking your food â€“ there is no concept of spoonfeeding! This is primarily because of labour is very expensive, and no one would want to spend thousands of dollars on hiring a househelp.

Travel outside your place, and see what the real world looks like!

Your perspective will surely change.

Travelling to different parts of the world is the most underrated thing â€“ it really broadens your mindset and changes your perspective!

The U.S. economy is in real trouble â€” just look at the latest jobs report.

With 300+ million people, the U.S. historically added about 150,000 jobs a month, roughly in line with population growth.

Then came the pandemic crash of spring 2020: 1.4 million jobs lost in March, 20 million in April.

The rebound followed: millions of jobs added monthly in summerâ€“fall 2020. In 2021 growth slowed, but in 2022 job creation surged to 400,000â€“900,000 a month â€” two to four times the historical norm.

By 2023, things leveled at 200â€“250k a month. In 2024, sometimes closer to 100k, still solid. Toward the end of Bidenâ€™s term, the pace accelerated again â€” some months above 300k.

Then, January 5: a new president. Winterâ€“spring: job growth cooled to 100â€“120k.

Then came tariffs and deportations from farms and construction sites. May saw just 19k new jobs â€” the weakest in decades outside the pandemic. June: â€“13k â€” catastrophic. July: 79k â€” historically low again.

The response? Fire the head of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Blame the â€œbad numbers.â€ Appoint your own guy.

Didnâ€™t help. The new chief reported only +22k in August â€” and revised June and July down even further.

The biggest losses? Manufacturing. Exactly where tariffs were supposed to â€œbring jobs back.â€

The excuse? â€œWeâ€™re building a record number of factories. Imports are banned. Everything will be made in the U.S. Just wait.â€ Yet construction is also down. Where are all those workers?

The truth is simple: the economy runs on stability. Tariffs, new laws, even new ministries â€” business can adapt.

What kills growth is chaos. One thing in the morning, another by noon, something else by evening, and tomorrow â€” no one knows.

Wild swings â€” cuts one day, threats to allies the next, hugs with enemies after â€” leave businesses unable to plan or invest.

Trumpâ€™s policies are killing the U.S. economy.

Source: adapted from Vasyl Taras
